The actor reasonably believes the conduct constituting the offense is required or authorized by a court order or warrant; or
The actor reasonably believes the conduct constituting the offense is required or authorized by law to assist a public official in the performance of their official duties.
This defense is not available in a situation that is expressly addressed by another available defense, affirmative defense, or exclusion from liability.
This defense is not available when the conduct constituting the offense is the use of deadly force, unless that use of deadly force:
Is expressly authorized by law; or
Occurs in the lawful conduct of war.

section.heading: Defense of self or another person.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes:
The actor or another person is in imminent danger of a physical contact, bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; and
The conduct constituting the offense:
Will protect against the harm; and
Is necessary in degree.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This defense is not available when:
In fact, the actor uses or attempts to use deadly force, unless the actor reasonably believes:
The actor or another person is in imminent danger:
Of a serious bodily injury, a sexual act, confinement, or death; or
While in their individual dwelling unit, of a bodily injury or a sexual contact; and
The conduct constituting the offense:
Will protect against the harm; and
Is necessary in degree;

The actor purposely, through conduct other than speech or presence alone, provokes or brings about the situation requiring the defense and, in fact, does not withdraw or make reasonable efforts to withdraw; or
The actor is reckless as to the fact that they are protecting themselves or another from lawful conduct.

para.heading: Use of deadly force by a law enforcement officer.
para.text: When, in fact, the actor is a law enforcement officer who uses or attempts to use deadly force, a factfinder shall consider the totality of the circumstances, including all of the following when determining whether the actor satisfies the requirements of the defense:
The reasonableness of the law enforcement officer's belief and actions from the perspective of a reasonable law enforcement officer;
The law enforcement officer's training and experience;
Whether the complainant:
Possessed or appeared to possess, either on their person or in a location where it is readily available, a dangerous weapon; and
Refused to comply, after being afforded an opportunity to comply, with a lawful order to surrender any suspected dangerous weapons;

Whether the law enforcement officer engaged in de-escalation measures, including taking cover, waiting for back-up, requesting support from mental health, behavioral health, or social workers, trying to calm the complainant, or using non-deadly force, prior to the use of deadly force;
Whether any conduct by the law enforcement officer increased the risk of a confrontation resulting in deadly force being used; and
Whether the law enforcement officer made all reasonable efforts to prevent a loss of a life, including abandoning efforts to apprehend the complainant.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes:
Real or tangible personal property is in imminent danger of damage, taking, trespass, or misuse; and
The conduct constituting the offense:
Will protect against the harm; and
Is necessary in degree.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This defense is not available when:
In fact, the actor uses or attempts to use deadly force;
The property is land that is property of another, unless the actor has or reasonably believes they have the effective consent of a property owner to protect the land; or
The actor is reckless as to the fact that they are protecting themselves or another from lawful conduct.

section.heading: Special responsibility for care, discipline, or safety defenses.

para.heading: Parental defense.
para.text: It is a defense to offenses under Chapters 2 and 3 of this title that:
In fact, the actor reasonably believes that:
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
The actor is either:
A parent, or a person acting in the place of a parent under civil law, who is responsible for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; or
Acting with the effective consent of such a parent or such a person;

The actor engages in the conduct constituting the offense with intent to safeguard or promote the welfare of the complainant, including the prevention or punishment of the complainant's misconduct; and
In fact, such conduct:
Is reasonable, under all the circumstances; and
Either:
Does not create a substantial risk of, or cause, death or serious bodily injury; or
Is the performance or authorization of a lawful cosmetic or medical procedure.

para.heading: Guardian defense.
para.text: It is a defense to offenses under Chapters 2 and 3 of this title that:
In fact, the actor reasonably believes that:
The complainant is an incapacitated individual; and
The actor is either:
A court-appointed guardian to the complainant; or
Acting with the effective consent of such a guardian;
The actor engages in the conduct constituting the offense with intent to safeguard or promote the welfare of the complainant, including the prevention of the complainant's misconduct; and
In fact, such conduct:
Is reasonable under all the circumstances;
Is permitted under civil law controlling the guardianship; and
Either:
Does not create a substantial risk of, or cause, death or serious bodily injury; or
Is the performance or authorization of a lawful cosmetic or medical procedure.

para.heading: Emergency health professional defense.
para.text: It is a defense to offenses under Chapters 2 and 3 of this title that:
In fact, the actor reasonably believes that:
The complainant is presently unable to give effective consent;
The actor is either:
A licensed health professional; or
A person acting at a licensed health professional's direction;
The conduct charged to constitute the offense is the performance or authorization of a lawful medical procedure;
The medical procedure is administered or authorized in an emergency;
No person who is legally permitted to consent to the medical procedure on behalf of the complainant can be timely consulted; and
There is no legally valid standing instruction by the complainant declining the medical procedure;
The actor engages in or authorizes the medical procedure with intent to safeguard or promote the physical or mental health of the complainant; and
In fact, a reasonable person wishing to safeguard the welfare of the complainant would consent to the medical procedure.

para.heading: Limited duty of care defense.
para.text: It is a defense to offenses under Chapters 2 and 3 of this title that:
In fact, the actor reasonably believes that the actor has a responsibility, under civil law, for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant;
The actor engages in the conduct constituting the offense with intent that the conduct:
Is necessary to fulfill the actor's responsibility to the complainant; and
Is consistent with the welfare of the complainant; and
In fact, such conduct:
Is reasonable, under all the circumstances; and
Does not create a substantial risk of, or cause, death or serious bodily injury; and
The defenses in subsections (a)–(c) of this section do not apply to the actor's conduct.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: The defenses in this section do not apply to:
Offenses in Subchapter III of Chapter 2 of this title (Sexual Assault and Related Provisions); and
Offenses in Subchapter VI of Chapter 2 of this title (Human Trafficking).

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense that, in fact:
The actor reasonably believes:
A person communicated to the actor that the person will cause the actor or a third person to suffer a criminal bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; and
The actor or third person is in imminent danger of the communicated harm; and
The communication would cause a reasonable person of the same background and in the same circumstances as the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This defense is not available when, in fact:
The actor recklessly brings about the situation requiring a choice of harms;
Negligence is the culpable mental state for an objective element of the offense, and the actor is negligent in bringing about the situation requiring a choice of harms; or
The conduct constituting the offense is an escape from a correctional facility or officer under § 22A-4401, and the actor does not make reasonable efforts to safely return to official custody.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense that:
In fact, the offense is a predicate possessory or distribution offense;
The actor possesses or distributes the item with intent, exclusively and in good faith, to do one or more of the following:
Permanently relinquish control over the item to a law enforcement officer or prosecutor for appropriate and lawful action;
Permanently relinquish control over the item to the actor's supervisor or a person in charge of the location where the item was found for appropriate and lawful action;
Seek legal services from an attorney or provide legal services as an attorney;
Seek medical services from a licensed health professional or provide medical services as a licensed health professional;

Investigate the circumstances surrounding the item's possession, acquisition, or use by a specific person when the actor has a responsibility, under civil law, for the health, welfare, or supervision of the person; or
Permanently dispose of the item; and
In fact, the actor does not possess the item longer than is reasonably necessary to engage in the conduct specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate possessory or distribution offense" means:
Possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition under § 7-2502.01a;
Possession of a stun gun under § 7-2502.15;
Carrying an air or spring gun under § 7-2502.17;
Carrying a pistol in an unlawful manner under § 7-2509.06;
Possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory under § 22A-5103;
Carrying a dangerous weapon under § 22A-5104; or
Possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person under § 22A-5107.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense that, in fact, a law enforcement officer acting under color or pretense of official right, or a person cooperating with a law enforcement officer acting under color or pretense of official right:
Purposely commanded, requested, tried to persuade, or otherwise induced the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense; or
Purposely commanded, requested, tried to persuade, or otherwise induced a third party to engage in conduct constituting a criminal offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the third party would command, request, try to persuade, or otherwise induce one or more additional persons to engage in or assist the conduct; and
In fact, the command, request, effort to persuade or otherwise induce an additional person in subparagraph (A) of this paragraph induces the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This defense is not available when, in fact, the actor is predisposed to engage in the specific conduct constituting the offense and the actor is merely afforded the opportunity or means to engage in such conduct.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense in a criminal proceeding that, in fact, as a result of a mental disability, the actor:
Lacked substantial capacity to conform their conduct to the requirements of the law; or
Lacked substantial capacity to recognize the wrongfulness of their conduct.

para.heading: Effect of defense.
para.text: An actor who is acquitted solely because of mental disability shall be committed under § 24-501.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "mental disability" means an abnormal condition of the mind, regardless of its medical label, that affects mental or emotional processes and either substantially impairs a person's ability to regulate and control their conduct or substantially impairs a person's ability to recognize the wrongfulness of their conduct.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: This section shall not be construed to create or limit a court's authority, on its own initiative, to order a psychiatric examination or to raise a mental disability defense.
Each offense subject to this title is classified as a:
Class 1 felony;
Class 2 felony;
Class 3 felony;
Class 4 felony;
Class 5 felony;
Class 6 felony;
Class 7 felony;
Class 8 felony;
Class 9 felony;
Class A misdemeanor;
Class B misdemeanor;
Class C misdemeanor;
Class D misdemeanor; or
Class E misdemeanor.

para.heading: Authorized dispositions.
para.text: Unless otherwise expressly specified by statute, upon conviction for an offense subject to this title, a court may sentence a person to sanctions that include:
A term of imprisonment under § 22A-603;
A fine under § 22A-604;
Probation under § 16-710;
Restitution or reparation under § 16-711;
Community service under § 16-712;
A sentencing alternative under § 24-903; and
Work release under § 24-241.01.

para.heading: Limitations on both fine and imprisonment.
para.text: A court may sentence a person to either imprisonment under § 22A-603 or a fine under § 22A-604, but not both, upon conviction for the following statutes prosecuted by the Attorney General for the District of Columbia:
[RESERVED.];
[RESERVED.].
Unless otherwise expressly specified by statute, the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for an offense subject to this title is:
For a Class 1 felony, 45 years;
For a Class 2 felony, 40 years;
For a Class 3 felony, 30 years;
For a Class 4 felony, 24 years;
For a Class 5 felony, 18 years;
For a Class 6 felony, 12 years;
For a Class 7 felony, 8 years;
For a Class 8 felony, 4 years;
For a Class 9 felony, 2 years;
For a Class A misdemeanor, 1 year;
For a Class B misdemeanor, 180 days;
For a Class C misdemeanor, 60 days;
For a Class D misdemeanor, 10 days; and
For a Class E misdemeanor, no imprisonment.

para.heading: Authorized fines.
para.text: Unless otherwise expressly specified by statute, the maximum fine for an offense subject to this title is:
For a Class 1 felony, $1 million;
For a Class 2 felony, $750,000;
For a Class 3 felony, $500,000;
For a Class 4 felony, $250,000;
For a Class 5 felony, $100,000;
For a Class 6 felony, $75,000;
For a Class 7 felony, $50,000;
For a Class 8 felony, $25,000;
For a Class 9 felony, $10,000;
For a Class A misdemeanor, $5,000;
For a Class B misdemeanor, $2,500;
For a Class C misdemeanor, $1,000;
For a Class D misdemeanor, $500; and
For a Class E misdemeanor, $250.

para.heading: Alternative fines for pecuniary loss or gain, or organizational actors.
para.text: A court may fine an actor who has been found guilty of an offense subject to this title:
Up to twice the pecuniary loss or pecuniary gain when:
The offense, in fact, results in either pecuniary loss to a person other than the actor, or pecuniary gain to any person; and
The information or indictment alleges the amount of the pecuniary loss or pecuniary gain and that the actor is subject to a fine double the amount of the pecuniary loss or pecuniary gain; or

Up to 3 times the amount otherwise provided by statute for the offense when the actor, in fact, is an organizational actor and the information or indictment alleges the actor is an organizational actor and is subject to a fine 3 times the maximum amount otherwise authorized.

para.heading: Limits on fines.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law:

A court shall not impose a fine that would impair the ability of a person who has been found guilty to make restitution or leave the person without sufficient means for reasonable living expenses and family obligations; and
A person who is eligible for appointed counsel under § 11-2601 shall not be subject to a fine under subsection (a) of this section.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "organizational actor" means any actor other than a natural person, including a trust, estate, fiduciary, partnership, company, corporation, association, organization, union, government, government agency, or government-owned corporation, or any other legal entity.

section.heading: Charging and proof of penalty enhancements.

para.heading: Charging of penalty enhancements.
para.text: An offense subject to this title is not subject to a general penalty enhancement under this subchapter or any other penalty enhancement expressly specified by statute unless notice of the penalty enhancement is specified in the information or indictment for the offense.

para.heading: Standard of proof for penalty enhancements.
para.text: Except for the establishment of prior convictions under § 23-111, an offense is not subject to a general penalty enhancement under this subchapter or any other penalty enhancement expressly specified by statute unless each objective element and culpable mental state of the penalty enhancement is proven beyond a reasonable doubt.

para.heading: Felony repeat offender penalty enhancement.
para.text: A felony repeat offender penalty enhancement applies to an offense subject to this title when, in fact:
The actor commits a felony offense under Chapter 2 of this title, or an enhanced first degree or enhanced second degree burglary offense under § 22A-3801(a), (b), or (d)(4); and

At the time of the offense, the actor has at least one prior conviction for a felony offense under Chapter 2 of this title, an enhanced first degree or enhanced second degree burglary offense under § 22A-3801(a) or (b) and (d)(4), or a comparable offense, that was:
Committed within 10 years of the offense being enhanced; and
Not committed on the same occasion as the offense being enhanced.

para.heading: Misdemeanor repeat offender penalty enhancement.
para.text: A misdemeanor repeat offender penalty enhancement applies to an offense subject to this title when, in fact:
The actor commits a misdemeanor offense under Chapter 2 of this title; and

At the time of the offense, the actor has at least 2 prior convictions for misdemeanor offenses under Chapter 2 of this title, or comparable offenses, or at least one prior conviction for a felony offense under Chapter 2 of this title, an enhanced burglary offense under § 22A-3801, or a comparable offense, that were:
Committed within 10 years of the offense being enhanced; and
Not committed on the same occasion as one another or the offense being enhanced.

para.heading: Proceedings to establish prior convictions.
para.text: No person shall be subject to additional punishment for a felony or misdemeanor repeat offender penalty enhancement under this section unless the requirements under § 23-111 are satisfied.

A felony repeat offender penalty enhancement under subsection (a) of this section increases the maximum authorized term of imprisonment and fine for the offense above the otherwise authorized penalty classification:
For a Class 1 or Class 2 felony, by 6 years and $50,000;
For a Class 3 or Class 4 felony, by 4 years and $40,000;
For a Class 5 or Class 6 felony, by 2 years and $30,000;
For a Class 7 or Class 8 felony, by 1 year and $20,000; and
For a Class 9 felony, 180 days and $10,000.

A misdemeanor repeat offender penalty enhancement under subsection (b) of this section increases the maximum authorized term of imprisonment and fine for the offense above the otherwise authorized penalty classification:
For a Class A or Class B misdemeanor, by 60 days and $500; and
For a Class C, Class D, or Class E misdemeanor, by 10 days and $50.

para.heading: Multiple penalty enhancements.
para.text: A penalty enhancement under this section shall be in addition to, and shall not limit application of, additional penalty enhancements specified elsewhere in this title; provided, that the determination of the offense class under subsection (d) of this section shall be based on the offense penalty before application of any additional penalty enhancements.

para.heading: Pretrial release penalty enhancement.
para.text: A pretrial release penalty enhancement applies to an offense subject to this title when, in fact, at the time the actor commits the offense, the actor is on pretrial release under § 23-1321.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a penalty enhancement under this section does not apply to an offense of:
Contempt under § 11-741;
Third degree escape from a correctional facility or officer under § 22A-4401(c);
Tampering with a detection device under § 22A-4402(a)(1)(B); or
Violation of a condition of pretrial release under § 23-1329.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: A pretrial release penalty enhancement increases the maximum authorized term of imprisonment and fine for an offense subject to this title above the otherwise authorized penalty classification:
For a Class 1 or Class 2 felony, by 6 years and $50,000;
For a Class 3 or Class 4 felony, by 4 years and $40,000;
For a Class 5 or Class 6 felony, by 2 years and $30,000;
For a Class 7 or Class 8 felony, by 1 year and $20,000;
For a Class 9 felony, by 180 days and $10,000;
For a Class A or B misdemeanor, by 60 days and $500; and
For a Class C, Class D, or Class E misdemeanor, by 10 days and $50.

para.heading: Multiple penalty enhancements.
para.text: A penalty enhancement under this section shall be in addition to, and shall not limit application of, additional penalty enhancements specified elsewhere in this title; provided, that the determination of the offense class under subsection (c) of this section shall be based on the offense penalty before application of any additional penalty enhancements.

para.heading: Hate crime penalty enhancement.
para.text: A hate crime penalty enhancement applies to an offense subject to this title when the actor commits the offense with the purpose, in whole or part, of threatening, physically harming, damaging the property of, or causing a pecuniary loss to any person or group because of prejudice against the perceived race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, sexual orientation, homelessness, physical disability, political affiliation, or gender identity or expression of any person or group.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a penalty enhancement under this section does not apply to an offense of an act of terrorism under § 22A-2701.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: A hate crime penalty enhancement increases the penalty classification for an offense subject to this title by one class; except, that, for a Class 1 felony, the maximum authorized term of imprisonment increases by 6 years, and fine for the offense increases by $50,000.

para.heading: Multiple penalty enhancements.
para.text: A penalty enhancement under this section shall be in addition to, and shall not limit application of, additional penalty enhancements specified elsewhere in this title.

section.heading: Hate crime penalty enhancement civil provisions.

para.heading: Civil provisions on data collection and publication.

para.text: The Metropolitan Police Department shall afford each crime victim the opportunity to submit with their complaint a written statement that contains information to support a claim that the conduct that occurred is a crime subject to a hate crime penalty enhancement under § 22A-608.

The Mayor shall collect and compile data on the incidence of crime subject to a hate crime penalty enhancement under § 22A-608; except, that such data shall be used for research or statistical purposes and shall not contain information that may reveal the identity of an individual crime victim.
The Mayor shall publish an annual summary of the data collected under paragraph (2) of this subsection and transmit the summary and recommendations based on the summary to the Council.

Irrespective of any criminal prosecution or the result of a criminal prosecution, a civil cause of action in a court of competent jurisdiction for appropriate relief shall be available for any person who alleges that they have been subjected to conduct that constitutes a criminal offense committed with the purpose, in whole or part, of threatening, physically harming, damaging the property of, or causing a pecuniary loss to any person or group because of prejudice against the person's or group's perceived race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, sexual orientation, homelessness, physical disability, political affiliation, or gender identity or expression as, in fact, that term is defined in § 2-1401.02(12A).
In a civil action under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the relief available shall include:
An injunction;
Actual or nominal damages for economic or non-economic loss, including damages for emotional distress;
Punitive damages in an amount to be determined by a jury or a court sitting without a jury; and
Reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.

An actor's parent, or a person acting in the place of a parent under civil law, who is responsible for the health, welfare, or supervision of the actor shall be liable for any damages that an actor under 18 years of age is required to pay in a civil action brought under paragraph (1) of this subsection, if any act or omission of the parent or person acting in the place of a parent under civil law contributed to the conduct of the actor.

section.heading: Abuse of government power penalty enhancement.

para.heading: Penalty enhancement.
para.text: An abuse of government power penalty enhancement applies to an offense subject to this title when the actor:
In fact, commits an offense under Chapter 2 or 3 of this title;
Knowing that they are a public official; and
Recklessly engages in the conduct constituting the offense under color or pretense of official right.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a penalty enhancement under this section shall not apply to an offense of:
Sexual abuse by exploitation under § 22A-2303; or
Blackmail under § 22A-2403(a)(2)(A).

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: An abuse of government power penalty enhancement increases the penalty classification for an offense subject to this title by one class except, for a Class 1 felony, the maximum authorized term of imprisonment and the fine for the offense increases by 6 years and $50,000.

para.heading: Multiple penalty enhancements.
para.text: A penalty enhancement under this section shall be in addition to, and shall not be construed to limit application of, additional penalty enhancements specified elsewhere in this title.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree murder when the actor purposely, with premeditation and deliberation, causes the death of another person.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree murder when the actor:
Knowingly causes the death of another person;
Recklessly, with extreme indifference to human life, causes the death of another person; or

Negligently causes the death of another person, other than an accomplice, by committing the lethal act in the course of and in furtherance of committing or attempting to commit an offense that is, in fact:
First or second degree robbery under § 22A-2201;
Carjacking under § 22A-2202;
First degree assault under § 22A-2203;
First degree assault on a law enforcement officer under § 22A-2204;
First degree sexual assault under § 22A-2301;
First or second degree sexual abuse of a minor under § 22A-2302;
First or second degree kidnapping under § 22A-2401;
First or second degree arson under § 22A-3601;
Enhanced first degree burglary under § 22A-3801; or
First degree criminal abuse of a minor under § 22A-2501 when the actor knowingly causes serious bodily injury.

para.heading: Self-induced intoxication.
para.text: An actor shall be deemed to have consciously disregarded the risk required to prove that the actor acted with extreme indifference to human life in subsection (b)(2) of this section if due to self-induced intoxication, in fact, the actor was unaware of the risk, but would have been aware had the actor been sober.
First degree murder is a Class 2 felony.
Second degree murder is a Class 4 felony.

para.heading: Mandatory minimum sentence for first degree murder.
para.text: Unless expressly provided by any other provision of law, a person convicted of murder in the first degree shall not be released from prison prior to the expiration of 24 years from the date of the commencement of the sentence.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense and the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that the decedent is a protected person;
Commits the murder with the purpose of harming the decedent because of the decedent's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official;
Commits the murder with intent to avoid or prevent a lawful arrest or effecting an escape from official custody;
Knowingly commits the murder for hire;
Knowingly inflicts extreme physical pain or mental suffering for a prolonged period of time immediately prior to the decedent's death;
Knowingly mutilates or desecrates the decedent's body;
In fact, commits the murder after substantial planning;
By knowingly shooting from a vehicle that is being driven at the time of the shooting; or

Commits the murder with the purpose of harming the decedent because the decedent was or had been a witness in any criminal investigation or judicial proceeding, or the decedent was capable of providing or had provided assistance in any criminal investigation or judicial proceeding.

para.heading: Evidence of extreme pain, mental suffering, mutilation, or desecration.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an actor charged with penalty enhancements under subsection (d)(3)(E) or (F) of this section shall be subject to a bifurcated criminal proceeding with the same jury or factfinder serving in both stages of the proceeding. In the first stage of the proceeding, the factfinder must determine if the actor committed either first degree murder as defined under subsection (a) of this section or second degree murder as defined under subsection (b) of this section. In the first stage of the proceeding, evidence of penalty enhancements under subsection (d)(3)(E) or (F) of this section is inadmissible except if such evidence is relevant to determining whether the actor committed first degree murder or second degree murder. In the second stage of the proceeding, after the actor has been found guilty of either first degree murder or second degree murder, the factfinder may consider any evidence relevant to penalty enhancements under subsection (d)(3)(E) or (F) of this section.
The presence of mitigating circumstances is a defense to liability under subsections (a) and (b)(1) and (2) of this section. Mitigating circumstances means:

Acting under the influence of an extreme emotional disturbance for which there is a reasonable cause as determined from the viewpoint of a reasonable person in the actor's situation under the circumstances as the actor believed them to be;
Acting with an unreasonable belief that the use of deadly force was necessary to prevent a person from unlawfully causing imminent death or serious bodily injury to the actor or another person; or
Any other legally recognized partial defense which substantially diminishes either the actor's culpability or the wrongfulness of the actor's conduct.

para.heading: Effect of mitigation defense.
para.text: If the government fails to prove the absence of mitigating circumstances beyond a reasonable doubt, but proves all other elements of murder, the actor is not guilty of murder, but is guilty of voluntary manslaughter.

para.heading: No accomplice liability for felony murder.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 22A-210, no person shall be liable as an accomplice to second degree murder under subsection (b)(3) of this section.

para.heading: Felony murder merger.
para.text: Multiple convictions for second degree murder under subsection (b)(3) of this section and an offense listed in subsection (b)(3)(A)–(H) of this section merge when arising from the same act or course of conduct and the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Voluntary manslaughter.
para.text: An actor commits voluntary manslaughter when the actor:
Knowingly causes the death of another person;
Recklessly, with extreme indifference for human life, causes death of another person; or

Negligently causes the death of another person, other than an accomplice, by committing the lethal act in the course of and in furtherance of committing or attempting to commit an offense that is, in fact:
First or second degree robbery under § 22A-2201;
Carjacking under § 22A-2202;
First degree assault under § 22A-2203;
First degree assault on a law enforcement officer under § 22A-2204;
First degree sexual assault under § 22A-2301;
First or second degree sexual abuse of a minor under § 22A-2302;
First or second degree kidnapping under § 22A-2401;
First or second degree arson under § 22A-3601;
Enhanced first degree burglary under § 22A-3801; or
First degree criminal abuse of a minor under § 22A-2501 when the actor knowingly causes serious bodily injury.

para.heading: Involuntary manslaughter.
para.text: An actor commits involuntary manslaughter when the actor recklessly causes the death of another person.

para.heading: Self-induced intoxication.
para.text: An actor shall be deemed to have consciously disregarded the risk required to prove that the person acted with extreme indifference to human life in subsection (a)(2) of this section if due to self-induced intoxication, in fact, the actor was unaware of the risk, but would have been aware had the actor been sober.
Voluntary manslaughter is a Class 5 felony.
Involuntary manslaughter is a Class 7 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification for voluntary manslaughter and involuntary manslaughter is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the decedent is a protected person; or
With the purpose of harming the decedent because of the decedent's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official.

para.heading: No accomplice liability for felony murder.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 22A-210, no person shall be liable as an accomplice to voluntary manslaughter under subsection (a)(3) of this section.

para.heading: Felony murder merger.
para.text: Multiple convictions for voluntary manslaughter under subsection (a)(3) of this section and another offense listed in subsection (a)(3)(A)–(H) of this section merge when arising from the same act or course of conduct and the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits negligent homicide when the actor negligently causes the death of another person.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Negligent homicide is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree robbery when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over the property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person physically present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death;
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present; or
Removing property from the hand or arms of the complainant;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property; and
In the course of the robbery, recklessly causes serious bodily injury to another person, other than an accomplice.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree robbery when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over the property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death;
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present; or
Removing property from the hand or arms of the complainant;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property; and
Either:
In the course of the robbery, recklessly causes significant bodily injury to another person, other than an accomplice; or
In fact, the property has a value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree robbery when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over the property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death;
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present; or
Removing property from the hand or arms of the complainant;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that an owner of the property gives effective consent to the actor to take or exercise control over the property.
First degree robbery is a Class 6 felony, but notwithstanding § 22A-603, the maximum term of imprisonment for first degree robbery is 14 years.
Second degree robbery is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree robbery is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for first degree robbery.
para.text: The maximum penalty for first degree robbery shall be increased by 6 years when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
By using or displaying what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for second degree robbery.

para.text: The penalty classification of second degree robbery shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
The maximum penalty for second degree robbery shall be increased
by:
Two classes if the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or

Ten years if the actor commits the offense under subsection (b)(3)(A) of this section by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon and the display or use of the dangerous weapon directly or indirectly causes the injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for third degree robbery.

para.text: The maximum penalty for third degree robbery shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
The maximum penalty for third degree robbery shall be increased by:
Four years if the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or

Eight years if the actor commits the offense under subsection (c)(1)(A) of this section by displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon and the display or use of the dangerous weapon directly or indirectly causes the injury to the complainant.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree carjacking when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death; or
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property;
In fact, the property is a motor vehicle; and
In the course of the carjacking, the actor recklessly causes serious bodily injury to another person, other than an accomplice.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree carjacking when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death; or
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property;
In fact, the property is a motor vehicle; and
In the course of the carjacking, the actor recklessly causes significant bodily injury to another person, other than an accomplice.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree carjacking when the actor:
Knowingly takes or exercises control over property of another that the complainant possesses within the complainant's immediate physical control by:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or another person physically present;

Communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person present to suffer bodily injury, a sexual act, a sexual contact, confinement, or death; or
Applying physical force that moves or immobilizes another person present;
With intent to deprive the complainant of the property; and
In fact, the property is a motor vehicle.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that an owner of the motor vehicle gives effective consent to the actor to take or exercise control over the motor vehicle.
First degree carjacking is a Class 5 felony.
Second degree carjacking is a Class 7 felony.
Third degree carjacking is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for first degree carjacking.
para.text: The penalty classification for first degree carjacking shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
By using or displaying what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for second degree carjacking.
para.text: The maximum penalty for second degree carjacking shall be increased by:
Six years when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
By using or displaying what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or

Two classes when the actor commits the offense under subsection (b)(4) of this section, by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon and the display or use of the dangerous weapon directly or indirectly causes the injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements for third degree carjacking.
para.text: The penalty classification of third degree carjacking shall be increased by:
One class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
By using or displaying what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or

Two classes when the actor commits the offense under subsection (b)(1)(A) or subsection (c)(1)(A) of this section by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon and the display or use of the dangerous weapon directly or indirectly causes the injury to the complainant.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree assault when the actor purposely:
Causes serious and permanent disfigurement to the complainant; or
Destroys, amputates, or permanently disables a member or organ of the complainant's body.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree assault when the actor recklessly, with extreme indifference to human life, causes serious bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree assault when the actor recklessly causes significant bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree assault when the actor recklessly causes bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.
It is a defense to liability under subsections (a) and (b) of this section that, in fact:
The injury is caused by a lawful cosmetic or medical procedure;
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
The actor reasonably believes that:

The complainant is 18 years of age or older, and the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to cause the injury;
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is 18 years of age or older; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority gives effective consent to the actor to cause the injury; or
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is under 18 years of age; and
The complainant gives effective consent to the actor to cause the injury.
It is a defense to liability under subsections (c) and (d) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
The actor reasonably believes that:

The complainant is 18 years of age or older, and the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor either to cause the injury or to engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the injury is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity;
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is 18 years of age or older and is more than 4 years older than the complainant; and

A person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority gives effective consent to the actor either to cause the injury or to engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the injury is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity; or
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is either under 18 years of age or is 18 years of age or older and not more 4 years older than the complainant; and

The complainant gives effective consent to the actor to either to cause the injury or to engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the injury is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity.

para.heading: Self-induced intoxication.
para.text: An actor shall be deemed to have consciously disregarded the risk required to prove the actor acted with extreme indifference to human life in subsection (b) of this section if due to self-induced intoxication, in fact, the actor was unaware of the risk, but would have been aware had the actor been sober.
First degree assault is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree assault is a Class 7 felony.
Third degree assault is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree assault is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of second degree assault shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person, other than a law enforcement officer;
By displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a public safety employee or District official.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of third degree assault shall be increased by:
One class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person, other than a law enforcement officer;
By displaying or using what, in fact, is an imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a public safety employee or District official; or
Two classes when the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of fourth degree assault shall be increased by:
One class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person, other than a law enforcement officer;
By recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is an imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a public safety employee or District official; or
Three classes when the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon.

section.heading: Assault on a law enforcement officer.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree assault on a law enforcement officer when the actor:
Purposely:
Causes serious and permanent disfigurement to the complainant; or
Destroys, amputates, or permanently disables a member or organ of the complainant's body; and
Engages in conduct specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection either:
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer; or
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a law enforcement officer in the course of their official duties.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree assault on a law enforcement officer when the actor:
Recklessly, with extreme indifference to human life, causes serious bodily
injury to the complainant; and
Engages in conduct specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection either:
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer; or
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a law enforcement officer in the course of their official duties.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree assault on a law enforcement officer when the actor:
Recklessly causes significant bodily injury to the complainant; and
Engages in conduct specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection either:
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer; or
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a law enforcement officer in the course of their official duties.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree assault on a law enforcement officer when the actor:
Recklessly causes bodily injury to the complainant; and
Engages in conduct specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection either:
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer; or
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a law enforcement officer in the course of their official duties.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.
It is a defense to liability under subsections (a) and (b) of this section that, in fact:
The injury is caused by a lawful cosmetic or medical procedure; and
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to cause the injury.

It is a defense to liability under subsections (c) and (d) of this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor either to cause the injury or to engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the injury is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity.

para.heading: Self-induced intoxication.
para.text: An actor shall be deemed to have consciously disregarded the risk required to prove the actor acted with extreme indifference to human life in subsection (b) of this section if due to self-induced intoxication, in fact, the actor was unaware of the risk, but would have been aware had the actor been sober.

First degree assault on a law enforcement officer is a Class 6 felony; except that, notwithstanding § 22A-603, the maximum term of imprisonment for first degree assault on a law enforcement officer is 14 years.
Second degree assault on a law enforcement officer is a Class 6 felony.
Third degree assault on a law enforcement officer is a Class 8 felony.
Fourth degree assault on a law enforcement officer is a Class A misdemeanor.

The maximum penalty for second degree assault on a law enforcement officer shall be increased by 2 years when the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon.

The maximum penalty for third degree assault on a law enforcement officer shall be increased by 6 years when the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon.

The maximum penalty for fourth degree assault on a law enforcement officer shall be increased by 4 years when the actor commits the offense by recklessly displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal threats when the actor:

Knowingly communicates to a person other than a co-conspirator or accomplice, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor immediately will cause the complainant or another person to suffer a criminal death, serious bodily injury, sexual act, or confinement;
With intent that the communication be perceived as a serious expression that the actor would cause the harm; and
In fact, the communication would cause a reasonable person in the complainant's circumstances to believe that the harm would occur.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal threats when the actor:

Knowingly communicates to a person other than a co-conspirator or accomplice, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor will cause the complainant or another person to suffer a criminal bodily injury or sexual contact;
With intent that the communication be perceived as a serious expression that the actor would cause the harm; and
In fact, the communication would cause a reasonable person in the complainant's circumstances to believe that the harm would occur.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal threats when the actor:

Knowingly communicates to a person other than a co-conspirator or accomplice, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor will cause the complainant or another person to suffer a criminal loss or damage to property;
With intent that the communication be perceived as a serious expression that the actor would cause the harm; and
In fact, the communication would cause a reasonable person in the complainant's circumstances to believe that the harm would occur.
First degree criminal threats is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree criminal threats is a Class B misdemeanor.
Third degree criminal threats is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person;
By displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree offensive physical contact when the actor:
Knowingly causes the complainant to come into physical contact with bodily fluid or excrement;
With intent that the physical contact be offensive to the complainant; and
In fact, a reasonable person in the situation of the complainant would regard it as offensive.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree offensive physical contact when the actor:
Knowingly causes the complainant to come into physical contact with any person or any object or substance;
With intent that the physical contact be offensive to the complainant; and
In fact, a reasonable person in the situation of the complainant would regard it as offensive.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability that, in fact:
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
The actor reasonably believes that:
The complainant is 18 years of age or older, and the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to:
Cause the physical contact; or
Engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the physical contact is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity;
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is 18 years of age or older and is more than 4 years older than the complainant; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority gives effective consent to the actor to:
Cause the physical contact; or
Engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the physical contact is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity; or
The complainant is under 18 years of age and:
The actor is either under 18 years of age or is 18 years of age or older and not more 4 years older than the complainant; and
The complainant gives effective consent to the actor to:
Cause the physical contact; or
Engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the physical contact is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity.
First degree offensive physical contact is a Class B misdemeanor.
Second degree offensive physical contact is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree sexual assault when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act;
In one or more of the following ways:
By causing bodily injury to the complainant, or by using physical force that moves or immobilizes the complainant;
By communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor will cause:
The complainant to suffer a bodily injury, confinement or death; or
A third party to suffer a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; or
By administering or causing to be administered to the complainant, without the complainant's effective consent, a drug, intoxicant, or other substance:
With intent to impair the complainant's ability to express willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual act; and
In fact, the drug, intoxicant, or other substance renders the complainant:
Asleep, unconscious, substantially paralyzed, or passing in and out of consciousness;
Substantially incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual act; or
Substantially incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual act.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree sexual assault when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act;
In one or more of the following ways:
By making a coercive threat, explicit or implicit; or
When the complainant is:
Asleep, unconscious, or passing in and out of consciousness;

Incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual act or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the sexual act, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness;
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual act; or
Substantially paralyzed.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree sexual assault when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact;
In one or more of the following ways:
By causing bodily injury to the complainant, or by using physical force that moves or immobilizes the complainant;
By communicating to the complainant, explicitly or implicitly, that the actor will cause:
The complainant to suffer a bodily injury, confinement or death; or
A third party to suffer a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; or
By administering or causing to be administered to the complainant, without the complainant's effective consent, a drug, intoxicant, or other substance:
With intent to impair the complainant's ability to express unwillingness to engage in the sexual contact; and
In fact, the drug, intoxicant, or other substance renders the complainant:
Asleep, unconscious, substantially paralyzed, or passing in and out of consciousness;
Substantially incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual contact; or
Substantially incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual contact.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree sexual assault when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact;
In one or more of the following ways:
By making a coercive threat, explicit or implicit; or
When the complainant is:
Asleep, unconscious, or passing in and out of consciousness;

Incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual contact or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the sexual contact, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness;
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual contact; or
Substantially paralyzed.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under subsections (a)(2)(A) and (B), (b)(2)(A) and (B), (c)(2)(A) and (B), and (d)(2)(A) and (B) of this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
First degree sexual assault is a Class 4 felony.
Second degree sexual assault is a Class 5 felony.
Third degree sexual assault is a Class 7 felony.
Fourth degree sexual assault is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor:
Recklessly causes the sexual act or sexual contact by displaying or using what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon;
Knowingly acts with one or more participants that are physically present at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact; or
Recklessly causes serious bodily injury to the complainant immediately before, during, or immediately after the sexual act or sexual contact; or
At the time of the sexual act or sexual contact:
In fact, the complainant is under 12 years of age, and the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant;
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 16 years of age and, in fact, the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant;

The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age and the fact that the actor is in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant, and, in fact, the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant;
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is 65 years of age or older and, in fact, the actor is under 65 years of age and at least 10 years younger than the complainant; or
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a vulnerable adult.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 12 years of age; and
The actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 16 years of age; and
The actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act;
While in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
The actor is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 12 years of age; and
The actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 16 years of age; and
The actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Sixth degree.
para.text: An actor commits sixth degree sexual abuse of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact;
While in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant; and
In fact:
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
The actor is, in fact, 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant.

para.heading: Affirmative defenses.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section for conduct involving only the actor and the complainant that, in fact, the actor and the complainant are in a marriage or domestic partnership at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact.
First degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 4 felony.
Second degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 5 felony.
Third degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 6 felony.
Fourth degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 6 felony.
Fifth degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 7 felony.
Sixth degree sexual abuse of a minor is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of first, second, fourth, and fifth degree sexual abuse of a minor shall be increased by one class when the actor:
Recklessly causes the sexual act or sexual contact by displaying or using what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon;
Knowingly acts with one or more participants that are physically present at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact;
Recklessly causes serious bodily injury to the complainant immediately before, during, or immediately after the sexual act or sexual contact; or
Knows at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact that the actor is in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of third and sixth degree sexual abuse of a minor shall be increased by one class when the actor:
Recklessly causes the sexual act or sexual contact by displaying or using what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon;
Knowingly acts with one or more participants that are physically present at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact; or
Recklessly causes serious bodily injury to the complainant immediately before, during, or immediately after the sexual act or sexual contact.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree sexual abuse by exploitation when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act;
In one or more of the following situations:

The actor is a coach, not including a coach who is a secondary school student; a teacher, counselor, principal, administrator, nurse, or security officer at a secondary school, working as an employee, contractor, or volunteer, and is reckless as to the fact that:
The complainant:
Is an enrolled student in the same secondary school; or
Receives educational services or attends educational programming at the same secondary school; and
The complainant is under 20 years of age;
The actor knowingly and falsely represents that the actor is someone else with whom the complainant is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship;
The actor is, or purports to be, a healthcare provider, a health professional, or a religious leader described in § 14-309, and:
Falsely represents that the sexual act is for a bona fide medical, therapeutic, or professional purpose;
Commits the sexual act during a consultation, examination, treatment, therapy, or other provision of professional services; or

Commits the sexual act while the complainant is a patient or client of the actor, and is reckless as to the fact that the mental, emotional, or physical condition of the complainant is such that the complainant is impaired from declining participation in the sexual act;
The actor:

Knowingly works as an employee, contractor, or volunteer at or for a hospital, treatment facility, detention or correctional facility, group home, or institution housing persons who are not free to leave at will; and
Is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is:
A ward, patient, client, or prisoner at that institution;
Awaiting admission to that institution; or
In transport to or from that institution; or
The actor knowingly works as a law enforcement officer, and is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is:
In official custody or detained for a legitimate police purpose;
Detained pending or following:
A charge or conviction of an offense, or an allegation or finding of juvenile delinquency;
Commitment as a material witness; or
Civil commitment proceedings, extradition, deportation, or exclusion; or
On probation or parole.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree sexual abuse by exploitation when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact;
In one or more of the following situations:

The actor is a coach, not including a coach who is a secondary school student; a teacher, counselor, principal, administrator, nurse, or security officer at a secondary school, working as an employee, contractor, or volunteer, and is reckless as to the fact that:
The complainant:
Is an enrolled student in the same secondary school; or
Receives educational services or attends educational programming at the same secondary school; and
The complainant is under 20 years of age;
The actor knowingly and falsely represents that the actor is someone else with whom the complainant is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship;
The actor is, or purports to be, a healthcare provider, a health professional, or a religious leader described in § 14-309, and:
Falsely represents that the sexual contact is for a bona fide medical, therapeutic, or professional purpose;
Commits the sexual contact during a consultation, examination, treatment, therapy, or other provision of professional services; or

Commits the sexual contact while the complainant is a patient or client of the actor, and is reckless as to the fact that the mental, emotional, or physical condition of the complainant is such that the complainant is impaired from declining participation in the sexual contact;
The actor:

Knowingly works as an employee, contractor, or volunteer at or for a hospital, treatment facility, detention or correctional facility, group home, or institution housing persons who are not free to leave at will; and
Is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is:
A ward, patient, client, or prisoner at that institution;
Awaiting admission to that institution; or
In transport to or from that institution; or
The actor knowingly works as a law enforcement officer, and is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is:
In official custody or detained for a legitimate police purpose;
Detained pending or following:
A charge or conviction of an offense, or an allegation or finding of juvenile delinquency;
Commitment as a material witness; or
Civil commitment proceedings, extradition, deportation, or exclusion; or
On probation or parole.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor and the complainant are in a marriage or domestic partnership at the time of the sexual act or sexual contact.
First degree sexual abuse by exploitation is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree sexual abuse by exploitation is a Class 8 felony.

section.heading: Sexually suggestive conduct with a minor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits sexually suggestive conduct with a minor when the actor:
In fact, is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant; and:
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 16 years of age; or
The actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Knows that the actor is in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant; and
The actor:
Purposely engages in:
A sexual act that is visible to the complainant;
A sexual contact that is visible to the complainant; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus that is visible to the complainant;
Knowingly:
Engages in one of the following with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to one of the following:
Touching or kissing any person, either directly or through the clothing; or
Removing clothing from any person;
With intent to cause the sexual arousal or sexual gratification of any person; or
Knowingly engages in a sexual act or sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section for conduct involving only the actor and the complainant that, in fact, the actor and the complainant are in a marriage or domestic partnership at the time of the prohibited conduct.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Sexually suggestive contact with a minor is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Enticing a minor into sexual conduct.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits enticing a minor into sexual conduct when the actor:
Knowingly commands, requests, or tries to persuade the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact;
In fact, is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant, and:
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 16 years of age; or
The actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Knows that the actor is in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant; or
In fact, is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the purported age of the complainant, and:
The complainant is a law enforcement officer who purports to be a person under 16 years of age; and
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the purported age of the complainant is under 16 years of age.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section for conduct involving only the actor and the complainant that, in fact, the actor and the complainant are in a marriage or domestic partnership at the time of the prohibited conduct.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Enticing a minor into sexual conduct is a Class 9 felony.

section.heading: Arranging for sexual conduct with a minor or person incapable of consenting.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits arranging for sexual conduct with a minor or person incapable of consenting when the actor:
Knowingly:
As a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant;
Gives effective consent to a third party to:
Engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact with or for the complainant; or
Cause the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact with or for the third party or any other person;
In one of the following situations:
The actor is reckless as to:
The fact that the complainant is under 16 years of age; and
