The fact that the third party or other person is at least 4 years older than the complainant;
The actor:
Is reckless as to:
The fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; and
The fact that the third party or other person is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant; and
Knows that the third party or other person is in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant; or
The actor is reckless as to:

The fact that the complainant is incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual act or sexual contact or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the sexual act or sexual contact, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness; or
The fact that the complainant is incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual act or sexual contact.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Arranging for sexual conduct with a minor or person incapable of consenting is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree nonconsensual sexual conduct when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual act;
Reckless as to the fact that the actor lacks the complainant's effective consent.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree nonconsensual sexual contact when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with the complainant or causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a sexual contact;
Reckless as to the fact that the actor lacks the complainant's effective consent.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor uses deception, unless it is deception as to the nature of the sexual act or sexual contact.
First degree nonconsensual sexual conduct is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree nonconsensual sexual conduct is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree incest when the actor:
In fact, is 16 years of age or older;
Knowingly engages in a sexual act with another person who is a:
Parent, grandparent, great-grandparent, child, grandchild, great-grandchild, sibling, parent's sibling, a sibling's child, or a child of a parent's sibling, whether related by:
Blood or adoption; or
Marriage or domestic partnership, either while the marriage or domestic partnership creating the relationship exists, or after such marriage or domestic partnership ends; or
A half-sibling related by blood; and
Obtains the consent of the other person by undue influence.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree incest when the actor:
In fact, is 16 years of age or older;
Knowingly engages in a sexual contact with another person who is a:
Parent, grandparent, great-grandparent, child, grandchild, great-grandchild, sibling, parent's sibling, a sibling's child, or a child of a parent's sibling, whether related by:
Blood or adoption; or
Marriage or domestic partnership, either while the marriage or domestic partnership creating the relationship exists, or after such marriage or domestic partnership ends; or
A half-sibling related by blood; and
Obtains the consent of the other person by undue influence.
First degree incest is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree incest is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Civil provisions on the duty to report a sex crime.

para.heading: Duty to report a sex crime.
para.text: A person who is, in fact, 18 years of age or older, and is aware of a substantial risk that a person under 16 years of age is being subjected to, or has been subjected to, a predicate crime, shall immediately report such information or belief in a call to 911, a report to the Child and Family Services Agency, or a report to the Metropolitan Police Department.
A person does not have a duty to report a predicate crime under subsection (a) of this section when the person is, in fact:
Subjected to a predicate crime by the same person alleged to have committed a predicate crime against the person under 16 years of age;

A lawyer or a person employed by a lawyer when the lawyer or employee is providing representation in a criminal, civil, or delinquency matter, and the information or basis for the belief arises solely in the course of that representation;

A religious leader described in § 14-309, when the information or basis for the belief is the result of a confession or penitential communication made by a penitent directly to the religious leader if:
The penitent made the confession or penitential communication in confidence;
The confession or penitential communication was made expressly for a spiritual or religious purpose;
The penitent made the confession or penitential communication to the religious leader in the religious leader's professional capacity; and
The confession or penitential communication was made in the course of discipline enjoined by the church or other religious body to which the religious leader belongs; or
A sexual assault counselor, when the information or basis for the belief is disclosed in a confidential communication, unless the sexual assault counselor is aware of a substantial risk that:
A sexual assault victim is under 13 years of age;

A perpetrator or alleged perpetrator of the predicate crime in subsection (a) of this section is in a position of trust with or authority over the sexual assault victim or, if the confidential communication was made prior to the applicability date of the Revised Criminal Code Reform Act of 2022, passed on 2nd reading on November 15, 2022 (Enrolled version of Bill 24-416), in a significant relationship, as that term was defined in former § 22-3001(10), with the sexual assault victim;
or
A perpetrator or alleged perpetrator of the predicate crime in subsection (a) of this section is more than 4 years older than the sexual assault victim.
No legal privilege, except the privileges set forth in this subsection, shall apply to the duty to report in subsection (a) of this section.

para.heading: Relationship to § 4-1321.02.
para.text: This section shall not be construed as altering the special duty to report by persons specified in § 4-1321.02(b).

para.heading: Civil violation.
para.text: A person commits failure to report a sex crime involving a person under 16 years of age when the person:
Is, in fact, 18 years of age or older;
Knows that they have a duty to report a predicate crime involving a person under 16 years of age under subsection (a) of this section; and
Fails to carry out this duty.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under subsection (d) of this section that the person fails to report a predicate crime under subsection (a) of this section because the person, in fact, reasonably believes that they are a survivor of an intrafamily offense, as that term is defined in § 16-1001(8).
Failure to report a sex crime involving a person under 16 years of age is a civil violation subject to a civil fine of $300.
A violation of subsection (d) of this section shall not constitute a criminal offense or a delinquent act, as that term is defined in § 16-2301(7).

para.heading: Judicial venue.
para.text: Adjudication of a civil violation under this section shall occur in the Office of Administrative Hearings pursuant to § 2-1831.03(b-6).

para.heading: Immunity for good faith report of a sex crime.

para.text: Any person who in good faith makes a report under this section shall have immunity from liability, civil or criminal, that might otherwise be incurred or imposed with respect to the making of the report or any participation in any judicial proceeding involving the report. In all civil or criminal proceedings concerning the person under 16 years of age who is the subject of the report, or resulting from the report, good faith shall be presumed unless rebutted.

Any person who makes a good-faith report under this section and, as a result thereof, is discharged from the person's employment or in any other manner is discriminated against with respect to compensation, hire, tenure, or terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, may commence a civil action for appropriate relief. If the court finds that the person was required to report under this section, in good faith made a report, and was discharged or discriminated against as a result, the court may issue an order granting appropriate relief, including reinstatement with back pay. The District may intervene in any action commenced under this subsection.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Confidential communication" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 14-312.
"Predicate crime" means any conduct that constitutes:
An offense under Subchapter III of Chapter 2 of this title;

Forced commercial sex under § 22A-2602, trafficking in forced commercial sex under § 22A-2604, sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting under § 22A-2605, or commercial sex with a trafficked person under § 22A-2608;

Creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor under § 22A-2807, possession of an obscene image of a minor under § 22A-2808, arranging a live sexual performance of a minor under § 22A-2809, or attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor under § 22A-2810; or
Trafficking in commercial sex under § 22A-5403.
"Sexual assault counselor" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1907(10).
"Sexual assault victim" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1907(11).

section.heading: Admission of evidence in sexual assault and related cases.

para.heading: Reputation or opinion evidence of complainant's past sexual behavior inadmissible.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, in a criminal case under this subchapter, reputation or opinion evidence of the past sexual behavior of the complainant is not admissible.

para.heading: Admissibility of other evidence of complainant's past sexual behavior.

para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, in a criminal case for an offense under this subchapter, evidence of a complainant's past sexual behavior, other than reputation or opinion evidence, is not admissible, unless such evidence is:
Admitted in accordance with paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) of this subsection and is constitutionally required to be admitted; or
Admitted in accordance with paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) of this subsection and is evidence of:

Past sexual behavior with persons other than the actor, offered by the actor upon the issue of whether the actor was or was not, with respect to the complainant, the source of semen or bodily injury; or

Past sexual behavior with the actor where the consent or effective consent of the complainant is at issue and is offered by the actor upon the issue of whether the complainant gave consent or effective consent to the sexual behavior that is the basis of the criminal charge.

If the actor plans to offer under paragraph (1) of this subsection, evidence of specific instances of the complainant's past sexual behavior, the actor shall make a written motion to offer such evidence not later than 15 days before the date on which the trial in which such evidence is to be offered is scheduled to begin, except that the court may allow the motion to be made at a later date, including during trial, if the court determines either that the evidence is newly discovered and could not have been obtained earlier through the exercise of due diligence or that the issue to which such evidence relates has newly arisen in the case. Any motion made under this paragraph, and the accompanying offer of proof, shall be filed under seal and served on all other parties and on the complainant.

The motion described in paragraph (2) of this subsection shall be accompanied by a written offer of proof. If the court determines that the offer of proof contains evidence described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the court shall order a hearing in chambers to determine if such evidence is admissible. At such hearing, the parties may call witnesses, including the complainant, and offer relevant evidence. If the relevancy of the evidence which the actor seeks to offer in the trial depends upon the fulfillment of a condition of fact, the court, at the hearing in chambers, or at a subsequent hearing in chambers scheduled for such purpose, shall accept evidence on the issue of whether such condition of fact is fulfilled and shall determine such issue.

If the court determines on the basis of the hearing described in paragraph (3) of this subsection that the evidence which the actor seeks to offer is relevant and that the probative value of such evidence outweighs the danger of unfair prejudice, such evidence shall be admissible in the trial to the extent an order made by the court specifies evidence which may be offered and areas with respect to which the complainant may be examined or cross-examined.

para.heading: Prompt reporting.
para.text: Evidence of delay in reporting an offense under this subchapter to a public authority shall not raise any presumption concerning the credibility or veracity of a charge under this subchapter.

para.heading: Privilege inapplicable for spouses or domestic partners.
para.text: Laws attaching a privilege against disclosure of communications between spouses or domestic partners are inapplicable in prosecutions under this subchapter where the actor is or was married to the complainant, or is or was a domestic partner of the complainant, or where the complainant is a person under 16 years of age.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "past sexual behavior" means sexual behavior other than the sexual behavior with respect to which an offense under this subchapter is alleged.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree kidnapping when the actor:
Knowingly and substantially confines or moves the complainant;
By means of:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or by using physical force;
Making an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
Deception; or
With acquiescence of the complainant, when the actor is:
Reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is an incapacitated individual; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement; or
In fact, 18 years of age or older and reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is under 16 years of age and 4 years younger than the actor; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement; and
With intent to:
Hold the complainant for ransom or reward;
Use the complainant as a shield or hostage;
Facilitate the commission of any felony or flight thereafter;
Inflict death or serious bodily injury upon the complainant;
Commit a sexual offense defined in Subchapter III of this chapter against the complainant;
Cause any person to believe that the complainant will not be released without suffering death, serious bodily injury, or a sex offense defined in Subchapter III of this chapter;
Permanently leave a person with legal authority over the complainant without custody of the complainant; or
Confine or move the complainant for 72 hours or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree kidnapping when the actor:
Knowingly and substantially confines or moves the complainant;
By means of:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or by using physical force;
Making an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
Deception; or
With acquiescence of the complainant, when the actor is:
Reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is an incapacitated individual; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement; or
In fact, 18 years of age or older and reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is under 16 years of age and 4 years younger than the actor; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement; and
With intent to:
Inflict bodily injury upon the complainant; or
Cause any person to believe that the complainant will not be released without suffering bodily injury.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under subsection (a)(3)(G) and (H) of this section when the complainant is, in fact, under 18 years of age and the actor is either:
A close relative or a former legal guardian who had authority to control the complainant's freedom of movement who:
Acts with intent to assume full responsibility for the care and supervision of the complainant; and
Does not cause bodily injury or use an explicit or implicit coercive threat to cause the confinement or movement; or
A person who reasonably believes they are acting at the direction of a close relative who:
Acts with intent that the close relative will assume full responsibility for the care and supervision of the complainant; and
Does not cause bodily injury or use an explicit or implicit coercive threat to cause the confinement or movement.
First degree kidnapping is a Class 5 felony.
Second degree kidnapping is a Class 7 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person;
By recklessly causing the confinement or movement by displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official.

para.heading: Multiple convictions for related offenses.
para.text: Multiple convictions for first degree kidnapping or second degree kidnapping and another offense merge when arising from the same act or course of conduct and when the confinement or movement was incidental to commission of the other offense, and the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits criminal restraint when the actor knowingly and substantially confines or moves the complainant:
By means of:
Causing bodily injury to the complainant or by using physical force;
Making an explicit or implicit coercive threat; or
Deception; or
By any means, including with acquiescence of the complainant, when the actor is:
Reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is an incapacitated individual; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement; or
In fact, 18 years of age or older and reckless as to the facts that:
The complainant is under 16 years of age and 4 years younger than the actor; and
A person with legal authority over the complainant who is acting consistent with that authority has not given effective consent to the confinement or movement.
It is a defense that the complainant is, in fact, under 18 years of age, and the actor is:
A close relative or a former legal guardian who had authority to control the complainant's freedom of movement who:
Acts with intent to assume full responsibility for the care and supervision of the complainant; and
Does not cause bodily injury or use an explicit or implicit coercive threat to cause the confinement or movement; or
A person who reasonably believes they are acting at the direction of a close relative who:
Acts with intent that the close relative will assume full responsibility for the care and supervision of the complainant; and
Does not cause bodily injury or use an explicit or implicit coercive threat to cause the confinement or movement.
It is a defense to liability under subsection (a)(2) of this section that, in fact, the actor:
Is a transportation worker who moves the complainant while in the course of the worker's official duties; or
Is a person who moves the complainant solely by persuading the complainant to go to a location open to the general public to engage in a commercial or other legal activity.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (a)(1)(C) of this section that the actor, in fact:
Lacks the complainant's effective consent solely because of deception by the actor; and
Does not confine or move the complainant with intent to use bodily injury or an explicit or implicit coercive threat if the deception should fail.

It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (a)(2) of this section that the actor, in fact, reasonably believes that a person with legal authority over the complainant would have given effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.
Criminal restraint is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a protected person;
By recklessly causes the confinement or movement by displaying or using what, in fact, is a dangerous weapon or imitation dangerous weapon; or
With the purpose of harming the complainant because of the complainant's status as a law enforcement officer, public safety employee, or District official.

para.heading: Multiple convictions for related offenses.
para.text: Multiple convictions for criminal restraint and another offense merge when arising from the same act or course of conduct and when the confinement or movement was incidental to commission of the other offense, and the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits blackmail when the actor:
Purposely causes another person to commit or refrain from any act;
By communicating, explicitly or implicitly, that if the person does not commit or refrain from the act, any person will:
Take or withhold action as a public official, or cause a public official to take or withhold action;
Accuse another person of a crime;

Expose a secret, publicize an asserted fact, or distribute a photograph, video or audio recording, regardless of the truth or authenticity of the secret, fact, or item, that tends to subject another person to, or perpetuate:
Hatred, contempt, ridicule, or other significant injury to personal reputation; or
Significant injury to credit or business reputation;
Significantly impair the reputation of a deceased person;
Notify a federal, state, or local government agency or official of, or publicize, another person's immigration or citizenship status;
Restrict a person's access to a controlled substance that the person owns, or restrict a person's access to prescription medication that the person owns; or
Engage in conduct that, in fact, constitutes:
An offense against persons under Chapter 2 of this title; or
A property offense under Chapter 3 of this title.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(2)(C) this section for communicating that, in fact, any person will engage in legal employment or business actions.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section for causing a person to do any of the following:
Transfer, use, give control over, or consent to damage property;
Remain in or move to a location; or
Give consent for a person to enter or remain in a location.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section committed by means of the conduct specified in subsection (a)(1)(A)-(F) this section that:

The actor, in fact, reasonably believes the threatened official action to be justified, or the accusation, secret, or assertion to be true, or that the photograph, video, or audio recording is authentic, and
Engages in the conduct with the purpose of compelling the other person to:
Desist or refrain from criminal or tortious activity or behavior harmful to any person's physical or mental health,
Act or refrain from acting in a manner reasonably related to the wrong that is the subject of the accusation, assertion, invocation of official action, or photograph, video or audio recording; or
Refrain from taking any action or responsibility for which the actor believes the other unqualified.

It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Blackmail is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal abuse of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
Purposely causes serious mental injury to the complainant; or
Recklessly causes serious bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal abuse of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Causes significant bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal abuse of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
Causes serious mental injury to the complainant; or
In fact, commits a predicate offense against persons against the complainant.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (b) and (c) of this section that the actor, in fact:
Is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
Reasonably believes that a person with legal authority over the complainant, acting consistent with that authority, would give effective consent to the injury or the conduct constituting the offense.
First degree criminal abuse of a minor is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree criminal abuse of a minor is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree criminal abuse of a minor is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate offense against persons" means:
Fourth degree assault under § 22A-2203(d);
Criminal threats under § 22A-2205;
Offensive physical contact under § 22A-2206;
Criminal restraint under § 22A-2402;
Stalking under § 22A-2801; or
Electronic stalking under § 22A-2802.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal neglect of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Created, or failed to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience serious bodily injury or death.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal neglect of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Created, or failed to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience:
Significant bodily injury; or
Serious mental injury.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal neglect of a minor when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is under 18 years of age; and
Engages in one of the following:
Knowingly leaves the complainant in any place with intent to abandon the complainant; or
Recklessly:

Fails to make a reasonable effort to provide food, clothing, shelter, supervision, medical services, medicine, or other items or care essential for the physical health, mental health, or safety of the complainant; or

Creates, or fails to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience bodily injury from consumption of alcohol, or consumption or inhalation, without a valid prescription, of a controlled substance or marijuana.

para.heading: Exclusions from liabili
para.text: ty.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section for conduct that, in fact, constitutes surrendering a newborn child in accordance with Chapter 14A of Title 4.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (b) and (c)(2)(B) of this section that the actor, in fact:
Is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
Reasonably believes that a person with legal authority over the complainant, acting consistent with that authority, would give effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.
First degree criminal neglect of a minor is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree criminal neglect of a minor is a Class A misdemeanor.
Third degree criminal neglect of a minor is a Class B misdemeanor.

section.heading: Criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Either:
Purposely causes serious mental injury to the complainant; or
Recklessly causes serious bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Causes significant bodily injury to the complainant.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Either:
Causes serious mental injury to the complainant; or
In fact, commits a predicate offense against persons against the complainant.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.
It is a defense to liability under subsection (a)(2)(B) of this section that, in fact:
The injury is caused by:
A lawful cosmetic or medical procedure; or
An omission;
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and

The actor reasonably believes that the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to cause the injury or engage in the omission that causes the injury.
It is a defense to liability under subsections (b) and (c) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to:
Cause the injury;
Engage in the omission that causes the injury; or
Engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's infliction of the injury is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity.
First degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree criminal abuse of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate offense against persons" means:
Fourth degree assault under § 22A-2203(d);
Criminal threats under § 22A-2205;
Offensive physical contact under § 22A-2206;
Criminal restraint under § 22A-2402;
Stalking under § 22A-2801; or
Electronic stalking under § 22A-2802.

section.heading: Criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Creates, or fails to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience serious bodily injury or death.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Creates, or fails to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience:
Significant bodily injury; or
Serious mental injury.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that:
The actor has a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant; and
The complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
Either:

Fails to make a reasonable effort to provide food, clothing, shelter, supervision, medical services, medicine, or other items or care essential for the physical health, mental health, or safety of the complainant; or

Creates, or fails to mitigate or remedy, a substantial risk that the complainant would experience bodily injury from consumption of alcohol, or consumption or inhalation, without a valid prescription, of a controlled substance or marijuana.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor's conduct is specifically permitted by a District statute or regulation.
It is a defense to liability under subsection (a) of this section that, in fact:
The risk is caused by:
A lawful cosmetic or medical procedure; or
An omission;
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and

The actor reasonably believes that the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct that constitutes the offense.
It is a defense to liability under subsections (b) and (c) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is not a person with legal authority over the complainant; and
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant, or a person with legal authority over the complainant acting consistent with that authority, gives effective consent to the actor to:
Engage in the conduct that constitutes the offense; or
Engage in a lawful sport, occupation, or other concerted activity, and the actor's creation, or failure to mitigate or remedy, the risk is a reasonably foreseeable hazard of that activity.
First degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class A misdemeanor.
Third degree criminal neglect of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits forced labor when the actor:
Knowingly causes a person to provide services;
By means of debt bondage or making an explicit or implicit coercive threat.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section for, in fact, communicating that any person will engage in legal employment actions, such as threats of termination, demotion, reduced pay or benefits, or scheduling changes, in order to compel an employee to provide labor or services.
Forced labor is a Class 5 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; or
By holding the complainant, or causing the complainant to provide services, for more than 180 days.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits forced commercial sex when the actor:
Knowingly causes the complainant to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person;
In one or more of the following ways:
By using physical force that causes bodily injury to, overcomes, or restrains any person;
By making a coercive threat, explicit or implicit;
By debt bondage; or
By administering or causing to be administered to the complainant, without the complainant's effective consent, a drug, intoxicant, or other substance:
With intent to impair the complainant's ability to express willingness or unwillingness to engage in the commercial sex act; and
In fact, the drug, intoxicant, or other substance renders the complainant:
Asleep, unconscious, substantially paralyzed, or passing in and out of consciousness;
Substantially incapable of appraising the nature of the commercial sex act; or
Substantially incapable of communicating unwillingness to engage in the commercial sex act.
Forced commercial sex is a Class 4 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age, or, in fact, the complainant is under 12 years of age; or
By recklessly holding the complainant, or causing the complainant to provide commercial sex acts, for a total of more than 180 days.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits trafficking in labor when the actor:
Knowingly recruits, entices, houses, transports, provides, obtains, or maintains by any means, a person;
With intent that, as a result, the person will be caused to provide services by means of debt bondage or an explicit or implicit coercive threat.
Trafficking in labor is a Class 6 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; or
By holding the complainant, or causing the complainant to provide services, for a total of more than 180 days.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits trafficking in forced commercial sex when the actor:
Knowingly recruits, entices, houses, transports, provides, obtains, or maintains by any means, the complainant;
With intent that, as a result, the complainant will be caused to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person in one or more of the following ways:
By physical force that causes bodily injury to, overcomes, or restrains any person;
By an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
By debt bondage; or
By a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, administered to the complainant without the complainant's effective consent.
Trafficking in forced commercial sex is a Class 6 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense:
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age, or, in fact, the complainant is under 12 years of age; or
By recklessly holding the complainant, or causing the complainant to provide commercial sex acts, for a total of more than 180 days.

section.heading: Sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting when the actor:
Knowingly recruits, entices, houses, transports, provides, obtains, or maintains by any means the complainant;
With intent that the complainant, as a result, will be caused to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person; and
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is:
Under 18 years of age;

Incapable of appraising the nature of the commercial sex act or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the commercial sex act, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness; or
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the commercial sex act.
Sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting is a Class 5 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense is increased by one class when the actor commits the offense and recklessly holds the complainant, or causes the complainant to provide commercial sex acts, for a total of more than 180 days.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree benefiting from human trafficking when the actor:
Knowingly obtains any financial benefit or property;
By participating in a group of 2 or more persons;

Reckless as to the fact that the group is engaging in conduct that, in fact: constitutes forced commercial sex under § 22A-2602, trafficking in forced commercial sex under § 22A-2604, or sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting under § 22A-2605; and
The actor's participation in the group furthers, in any manner, the conduct that constitutes a human trafficking offense.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree benefiting from human trafficking when the actor:
Knowingly obtains any financial benefit or property;
By participation in a group of 2 or more persons;
Reckless as to the fact that the group is engaging in conduct that, in fact: constitutes forced labor under § 22A-2601 or trafficking in labor under § 22A-2603; and
The actor's participation in the group furthers, in any manner, the conduct that constitutes a human trafficking offense.
First degree benefiting from human trafficking is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree benefiting from human trafficking is a Class 7 felony.

section.heading: Misuse of documents in furtherance of human trafficking.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree misuse of documents in furtherance of human trafficking when the actor:
Knowingly destroys, conceals, removes, confiscates, or possesses any actual or purported government identification document, including a passport or other immigration document of any person;
With intent to restrict the person's liberty to move or travel in order to maintain performance of a commercial sex act by the person.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree misuse of documents in furtherance of human trafficking when the actor:
Knowingly destroys, conceals, removes, confiscates, or possesses any actual or purported government identification document, including a passport or other immigration document of any person;
With intent to restrict the person's liberty to move or travel in order to maintain the services of the person.
First degree misuse of documents in furtherance of human trafficking is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree misuse of documents in furtherance of human trafficking is a Class 9 felony.

section.heading: Commercial sex with a trafficked person.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree commercial sex with a trafficked person when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a commercial sex act;
When a coercive threat, explicit or implicit, or debt bondage by another person causes the complainant to submit to or engage in the commercial sex act;
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age, or, in fact, the complainant is under 12 years of age.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree commercial sex with a trafficked person when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a commercial sex act;
When either:
An explicit or implicit coercive threat, or debt bondage by another person causes the complainant to submit to or engage in the commercial sex act; or
The complainant is recruited, enticed, housed, transported, provided, obtained, or maintained for the purpose of causing the person to submit to or engage in the commercial sex act; and:
The actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age;

Incapable of appraising the nature of the commercial sex act or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the commercial sex act, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness; or
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the commercial sex act; or
The complainant is, in fact, under 12 years of age.
First degree commercial sex with a trafficked person is a Class 3 felony.
Second degree commercial sex with a trafficked person is a Class 4 felony.

para.heading: Forfeiture penalty.
para.text: In imposing sentence on any person convicted of a violation of this subchapter, the court may order, in addition to any sentence imposed, that the person shall forfeit to the District of Columbia:
Any interest in any property, real or personal, that was used or planned to be used to commit or to facilitate the commission of the violation; and
Any property, real or personal, constituting or derived from any proceeds that the person obtained, directly or indirectly, as a result of the violation.

para.heading: Property subject to forfeiture.
para.text: The following shall be subject to forfeiture to the District of Columbia and no property right shall exist in them:
Any property, real or personal, that was used or planned to be used to commit or to facilitate the commission of an offense under this subchapter; and
Any property, real or personal, which constitutes or is derived from proceeds traceable to an offense under this subchapter.

In a criminal case in which a person is accused of forced commercial sex under § 22A-2602, trafficking in forced commercial sex under § 22A-2604, sex trafficking of a minor or adult incapable of consenting under § 22A-2605, or benefiting from human trafficking under § 22A-2606, reputation or opinion evidence of the past sexual behavior of the alleged victim is not admissible. Evidence of an alleged victim's past sexual behavior other than reputation or opinion evidence also is not admissible, unless such evidence other than reputation or opinion evidence is admitted in accordance with § 22A-2310(b) and is constitutionally required to be admitted.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "past sexual behavior" means sexual behavior other than the sexual behavior with respect to which an offense under this subchapter is alleged.

An individual who is a victim of an offense prohibited by § 22A-2601, § 22A-2602, § 22A-2603, § 22A-2604, § 22A-2605, § 22A-2606, § 22A-2607, or § 22A-2608 may bring a civil action in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. The court may award actual damages, compensatory damages, punitive damages, injunctive relief, and any other appropriate relief. A prevailing plaintiff shall also be awarded attorney's fees and costs. Treble damages shall be awarded on proof of actual damages where a defendant's acts were willful and malicious.

Any action for recovery of damages arising out of an offense in this subchapter may not be brought after 5 years from when the victim knew, or reasonably should have been aware, of any act constituting an offense in this subchapter, or if the offense occurred while the victim was less than 35 years of age, the date that the victim turns 40 years of age, whichever is later.

If a person entitled to sue is imprisoned, insane, or similarly incapacitated at the time the cause of action accrues, so that it is impossible or impracticable for the person to bring an action, then the time of the incapacity is not part of the time limited for the commencement of the action.

A defendant is estopped to assert a defense of the statute of limitations when the expiration of the statute is due to conduct by the defendant inducing the plaintiff to delay the filing of the action.

section.heading: Limitation on liability and sentencing for human trafficking offenses.

para.heading: Accomplice liability for victims of trafficking.
para.text: A person shall not be charged as an accomplice to the commission of an offense under this subchapter if, prior to commission of the offense, the person was themself a victim of an offense under this subchapter by the principal within 3 years prior to the conduct by the principal that constitutes the offense.

para.heading: Conspiracy liability for victims of trafficking.
para.text: A person shall not be charged with conspiracy to commit an offense under this subchapter if, prior to the conspiracy, the person was themself a victim of an offense under this subchapter by a party to the conspiracy within 3 years prior to the formation of the conspiracy.

para.heading: Property subject to forfeiture.
para.text: The following are subject to civil forfeiture:

In fact, all conveyances, including aircraft, vehicles or vessels, which are possessed with intent to be used, or are, in fact, used, to facilitate the commission of an offense under this subchapter; and
In fact, all money, coins, and currency which are possessed with intent to be used, or are, in fact, used, to facilitate the commission of an offense under this subchapter.

para.heading: Requirements for forfeiture.
para.text: All seizures and forfeitures under this section shall be pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 3 of Title 41.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits a first degree act of terrorism when the actor:
In fact, commits murder under § 22A-2101;
With the purpose, in whole or part, of:
Intimidating or coercing a significant portion of the civilian population of the District of Columbia or the United States; or
Influencing the policy or conduct of a unit of government by intimidation or coercion.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits a second degree act of terrorism when the actor:
In fact, commits:
Manslaughter under § 22A-2102;
First degree assault under § 22A-2203(a);
First degree assault on a law enforcement officer under § 22A-2204(a); or
Kidnapping under § 22A-2401;
With the purpose, in whole or part, of:
Intimidating or coercing a significant portion of the civilian population of the District of Columbia or the United States; or
Influencing the policy or conduct of a unit of government by intimidation or coercion.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits a third degree act of terrorism when the actor:
In fact, commits:
Arson under § 22A-3601; or
First degree criminal damage to property under § 22A-3603(a);
With the purpose, in whole or part, of:
Intimidating or coercing a significant portion of the civilian population of the District of Columbia or the United States; or
Influencing the policy or conduct of a unit of government by intimidation or coercion.
First degree act of terrorism is a Class 1 felony.
Second degree act of terrorism is a Class 3 felony.
Third degree act of terrorism is a Class 6 felony.

section.heading: Material support for an act of terrorism.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits material support for an act of terrorism when the actor:
Knowingly provides, or commands, requests, or tries to persuade, any person to provide material support or resources;
With intent that the material support or resources will be used, in whole or in part:
To assist the planning or commission of conduct constituting an act of terrorism under § 22A-2701; or
To flee after committing an act of terrorism under § 22A-2701.

para.heading: Uncommunicated criminal solicitation.
para.text: It is immaterial under subsection (a) of this section that the planned recipient of the actor's command, request, or efforts at persuasion fails to receive the message, if the actor does everything they plan to do to transmit the message to the planned recipient.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Material support for an act of terrorism is a Class 7 felony.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for material support for an act of terrorism merges with any other conviction for being an accomplice to an act of terrorism under § 22A-2701 arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "material support or resources" means:
Expert services or assistance;

Currency, financial securities or other monetary instruments; financial services; lodging; training; false documentation or identification; equipment; facilities; weapons; lethal substances; explosives; personnel; transportation; and other physical assets; or
A weapon of mass destruction.

section.heading: Manufacture or possession of a weapon of mass destruction.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits manufacture or possession of a weapon of mass destruction when the actor:
Either:
Knowingly manufactures or possesses a weapon of mass destruction; or
With intent that it will be used to cause death or serious bodily injury to multiple persons, other than as part of a lawful medical procedure, knowingly manufactures or possesses an item that is:
A toxic or poisonous chemical or its precursors;
A biological agent or toxin; or
Radioactive or nuclear material; and
In fact, the weapon of mass destruction or other item is capable of causing multiple deaths, serious bodily injuries to multiple persons, or an amount of damage to property of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(1)(A) of this section when, in fact, the actor is:
An employee of the District or federal government, who is on duty and acting within the scope of those duties;
Lawfully engaging in the business of manufacturing, repairing, or dealing the weapon involved in the offense;
Lawfully engaging in the business of shipping or delivering the weapon involved in the offense;
Acting within the scope of authority granted by the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department or a competent court; or

A university, research institution, private company, individual, or hospital engaged in scientific or public health research and, as required by federal law, has registered with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention pursuant to Part 121 (commencing with Section 121.1) of Subchapter E of Chapter 1 of Title 9 or pursuant to Part 73 (commencing with Section 73.1) of Subchapter F of Chapter 1 of Title 42 of the Code of Federal Regulations, or any successor provisions.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the weapon or item while, in fact, voluntarily surrendering the weapon or item pursuant to District or federal law.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Manufacture or possession of a weapon of mass destruction is a Class 6 felony.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for manufacture or possession of a weapon of mass destruction merges with any other weapon possession offense arising from the same act or course of conduct under Subchapter I of Chapter 5 of this title or Chapter 25 of Title 7. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in subsections § 22A-212(b) and (c).

section.heading: Use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction when the actor:
With intent to cause serious bodily injury or death to multiple persons, other than as part of a lawful medical procedure;
Knowingly uses, disseminates, or detonates:
A weapon of mass destruction;
A toxic or poisonous chemical or its precursors;
A biological agent or toxin; or
Radioactive or nuclear material; and
In fact, the weapon of mass destruction or other item is capable of causing multiple deaths or serious bodily injuries to multiple persons.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction when the actor:
With intent to cause:
Bodily injury to multiple persons, other than as part of a lawful medical procedure; or
Massive damage to property, including plants and animals, on land owned by a government, government agency, or government-owned corporation;
Knowingly uses, disseminates, or detonates:
A weapon of mass destruction;
A toxic or poisonous chemical or its precursors;
A biological agent or toxin; or
Radioactive or nuclear material; and
In fact, the weapon of mass destruction or other item is capable of causing multiple deaths, serious bodily injuries to multiple persons, or an amount of damage to property of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (b)(1)(B) of this section when, in fact, the actor is:
An employee of the District or federal government, who is on duty and acting within the scope of those duties;
Acting within the scope of authority granted by the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department or a competent court; or

A university, research institution, private company, individual, or hospital engaged in scientific or public health research and, as required by federal law, has registered with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention pursuant to Part 121 (commencing with Section 121.1) of Subchapter E of Chapter 1 of Title 9 or pursuant to Part 73 (commencing with Section 73.1) of Subchapter F of Chapter 1 of Title 42 of the Code of Federal Regulations, or any successor provisions;

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (b)(1)(B) of this section that the actor, in fact, reasonably believes they are acting in compliance with a current license or authority under civil law and with the effective consent of an owner of the property.
First degree use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction is a Class 3 felony.
Second degree use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction is a Class 5 felony.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for use, dissemination, or detonation of a weapon of mass destruction merges with any other weapon possession offense arising from the same act or course of conduct under Subchapter I of Chapter 5 of this title or Chapter 25 of Title 7. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits stalking when the actor:
Purposely engages in a course of conduct directed at a complainant that consists of 2 or more separate occasions of any of the following:
Physically following or physically monitoring the complainant;
Falsely personating the complainant;
Contacting the complainant, by use of a telephone, mail, delivery service, electronic message, in person, or any other means; or
In fact, committing, soliciting, or attempting:
Criminal threats under § 22A-2205;
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Identity theft under § 22A-3305;
Arson under § 22A-3601;
Criminal damage to property under § 22A-3603;
Criminal graffiti under § 22A-3604;
Trespass under § 22A-3701;
Breach of home privacy under § 22A-5205; or
Indecent exposure under § 22A-5206;
Negligent as to the fact that the course of conduct is without the complainant's effective consent; and
Either:
With intent to cause the complainant to:
Fear for the complainant's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress; or
Negligently causing the complainant to:
Fear for the complainant's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress.

An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(1)(C) of this section when, in fact, the actor is expressing an opinion on a political or public matter, and the expression is directed to a complainant who is a law enforcement officer, District official, candidate for elected office, or employee of a business that serves the public, while the complainant is involved in their official duties.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is:
Authorized to engage in the conduct by a court order or District statute, regulation, rule, or license; or
Carrying out a specific, lawful commercial purpose or employment duty, when acting within the reasonable scope of that purpose or duty.

para.heading: Unit of prosecution.
para.text: Under this section, where conduct is of a continuing nature, each 24-hour period constitutes one occasion.
Stalking is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor, in fact:
Violates a court order or condition of release prohibiting or restricting contact with the complainant;
Has one or more prior convictions within 10 years for:
Stalking under § 22A-2801 or a comparable offense; or
Electronic stalking under § 22A-2802 or a comparable offense;
Causes more than $5,000 in financial injury; or
Is 18 years of age or older, is at least 4 years older than the complainant, and is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age.

para.heading: No repeat offender enhancement.
para.text: A person shall not be subject to both a penalty enhancement under paragraph (2)(B) of this subsection and a repeat offender penalty enhancement in § 22A-606 for the same course of conduct.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "safety" means ongoing security from significant intrusions on one's bodily integrity or bodily movement.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits electronic stalking when the actor:
Purposely engages in a course of conduct directed at a complainant that consists of 2 or more separate occasions of:
Creating an image or an audio recording of the complainant, other than a derivative image or audio recording; or
Accessing monitoring equipment or software, on property of another, that discloses the complainant's location;
Negligent as to the fact that the course of conduct is without the complainant's effective consent; and
Either:
With intent to cause the complainant to:
Fear for the complainant's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress; or
Negligently causing the complainant to:
Fear for the complainant's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress.

An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(1)(A) of this section when, in fact, the actor is expressing an opinion on a political or public matter, and the expression is directed to a complainant who is a law enforcement officer, District official, candidate for elected office, or employee of a business that serves the public, while the complainant is involved in their official duties.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(1)(A) of this section when, in fact:
The actor is a party to the communication on the audio recording; or
One of the parties to the communication on the audio recording gives effective consent to the conduct.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is:
Authorized to engage in the conduct by a court order or District statute, regulation, rule, or license; or
Carrying out a specific, lawful commercial purpose or employment duty, when acting within the reasonable scope of that purpose or duty.

para.heading: Unit of prosecution.
para.text: Under this section, where conduct is of a continuing nature, each 24-hour period constitutes one occasion.
Electronic stalking is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor, in fact:
Violates a court order or condition of release prohibiting or restricting contact with the complainant;
Has one or more prior convictions within 10 years for:
Stalking under § 22A-2801 or a comparable offense; or
Electronic stalking under § 22A-2802 or a comparable offense;
Causes more than $5,000 in financial injury; or
Is 18 years of age or older, is at least 4 years older than the complainant, and is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age.

para.heading: No repeat offender enhancement.
para.text: A person shall not be subject to both a penalty enhancement under paragraph (2)(B) of this subsection and a repeat offender penalty enhancement in § 22A-606 for the same course of conduct.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "safety" means ongoing security from significant intrusions on one's bodily integrity or bodily movement.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree voyeurism when the actor:
Knowingly creates:
An image, other than a derivative image, of the complainant's nude or undergarment-clad genitals, pubic area, anus, buttocks, or female breast below the top of the areola;
An image or audio recording, other than a derivative image or audio recording, of the complainant engaging in or submitting to a sexual act or masturbation; or
An image, other than a derivative image, of the complainant urinating or defecating;
Without the complainant's effective consent; and
In fact, the complainant has a reasonable expectation of privacy under the circumstances.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree voyeurism when the actor:
Knowingly observes directly:
The complainant's nude or undergarment-clad genitals, anus, pubic area, buttocks, or female breast below the top of the areola;
The complainant engaging in or submitting to a sexual act or masturbation; or
The complainant urinating or defecating.
Without the complainant's effective consent; and
In fact, the complainant has a reasonable expectation of privacy under the circumstances.
First degree voyeurism is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree voyeurism is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancement.
para.text: The penalty classification of any gradation of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age.

section.heading: Unauthorized disclosure of a sexual recording.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unauthorized disclosure of a sexual recording when the actor:
Knowingly distributes or displays to a person other than the complainant, or makes accessible on an electronic platform to a user other than the complainant or actor:
An image of the complainant's:
Nude genitals or anus; or
Nude or undergarment-clad pubic area, buttocks, or female breast below the top of the areola; or
An image or an audio recording of the complainant engaging in or submitting to a sexual act, masturbation, or sadomasochistic abuse;
Without the complainant's effective consent; and
Either:
After reaching an explicit or implicit agreement with the complainant that the image or audio recording will not be distributed or displayed, with intent to:
Alarm or sexually abuse, humiliate, harass, or degrade the complainant; or
Receive financial gain as a result of the distribution or display; or
In fact, after personally obtaining the image or audio recording by committing an offense that is, in fact:
Voyeurism under § 22A-2803;
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Unauthorized use of property under § 22A-3202; or
Extortion under § 22A-3401.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a licensee under the 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. engaged in activities regulated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is an interactive computer service, as that term is defined in 47 U.S.C. § 230(f)(2), for content provided by another person.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section, that the actor:
With intent, exclusively and in good faith, to report possible illegal conduct or seek legal counsel from any attorney;
In fact, distributes the image or audio recording to a person whom the actor reasonably believes is:
A law enforcement officer, prosecutor, or attorney; or
A teacher, school counselor, school administrator, or a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of a person who is:
Depicted in the image or audio recording; or
Involved in the creation of the image or audio recording.
Unauthorized disclosure of a sexual recording is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by 2 classes when the actor knowingly:
Distributes or displays the image or audio recording to 6 or more persons other than the complainant; or
Makes the image or audio recording publicly accessible on an electronic platform to a user other than the complainant or actor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall have the same meaning as provided in 47 U.S.C. § 153(30).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits distribution of an obscene image when the actor:
Knowingly distributes or displays to a complainant an image that depicts a real or fictitious person engaging in or submitting to an actual or simulated:
Sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation;
Sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering;
Sexual contact; or
Sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola, or buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering;
Without the complainant's effective consent; and
Reckless as to the fact that the image is obscene.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a licensee under 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. engaged in activities regulated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is an interactive computer service, as that term is defined in 47 U.S.C. § 230(f)(2), for content provided by another person.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor distributes or displays an image to a complainant in a location open to the general public or in an electronic forum, unless the actor:
Knowingly distributes or displays the image directly to the complainant; or
Purposely distributes or displays the image to the complainant.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that they are distributing the image to:
A person who is depicted in the image;
A person who was involved in the creation or distribution of the image; or
A person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of a person who the actor reasonably believes is:
Depicted in the image; or
Involved in the creation of the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role; and
Has no control over the selection of the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section, that the actor:
With intent, exclusively and in good faith, to report possible illegal conduct or seek legal counsel from any attorney;
In fact, distributes the image to a person whom the actor reasonably believes is:
A law enforcement officer, prosecutor, or attorney; or
A teacher, school counselor, or school administrator of a person that the actor reasonably believes to be depicted in the image or involved in the creation of the image.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Distribution of an obscene image is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall have the same meaning as provided in 47 U.S.C. § 153(30).

section.heading: Distribution of an obscene image to a minor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits distribution of an obscene image to a minor when the actor:
Knowingly distributes or displays to a complainant an image that depicts a real or fictitious person engaging in or submitting to an actual or simulated:
Sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation;
Sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering;
Sexual contact; or
Sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola or buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering;
Reckless as to the fact that:
The image is obscene; and
The complainant is under 16 years of age; and
In fact, the actor is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a licensee under 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. engaged in activities regulated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is an interactive computer service, as that term is defined in 47 U.S.C. § 230(f)(2), for content provided by another person.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor distributes or displays an image to a complainant in a location open to the general public or in an electronic forum, unless the actor:
Knowingly distributes or displays the image directly to the complainant; or
Purposely distributes or displays the image to the complainant.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that they are distributing the image or audio recording to:
A person who is depicted in the image or audio recording;
A person who was involved in the creation or distribution of the image or audio recording; or
A person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of a person who the actor reasonably believes is:
Depicted in the image or audio recording; or
Involved in the creation of the image or audio recording.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role; and
Has no control over the selection of the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact:
Is married to, or in a domestic partnership with the complainant; and
Reasonably believes that complainant gave effective consent to the conduct.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Distribution of an obscene image to a minor is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall have the same meaning as provided in 47 U.S.C. § 153(30).

section.heading: Creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly:
Creates an image, other than a derivative image, by recording, photographing, or filming the complainant, or produces or directs the creation of such an image;

As a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant, gives effective consent for the complainant to engage in or submit to the recording, photographing, or filming of an image, other than a derivative image;
Displays, distributes, or manufactures with intent to distribute an image;
Makes an image accessible to another user on an electronic platform; or
Sells or advertises an image;
Reckless as to the fact that the image depicts, or will depict, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
A sexual act or simulated sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse or simulated sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation or simulated masturbation; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly:
Creates an image, other than a derivative image, by recording, photographing, or filming the complainant, or produces or directs the creation of such an image;

As a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant, gives effective consent for the complainant to engage in or submit to the recording, photographing, or filming of an image, other than a derivative image;
Displays, distributes, or manufactures with intent to distribute an image;
Makes an image accessible to another user on an electronic platform; or
Sells or advertises an image;
Reckless as to the fact that the image depicts, or will depict, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
An obscene sexual contact; or
An obscene sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola, or the buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a licensee under 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. engaged in activities regulated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is an interactive computer service, as that term is defined in 47 U.S.C. § 230(f)(2), for content provided by another person.
