It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (a) of this section that, in fact, the image has, or will have, serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value, when considered as a whole.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(A), (B), (C), and (D) and (b)(1)(A), (B), (C), and (D) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
The actor is the only person under 18 years of age who is, or who will be, depicted in the image; or

The actor reasonably believes that every person under 18 years of age who is, or who will be, depicted in the image, gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(A), (C), and (D) and (b)(1)(A), (C), and (D) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is at least 18 years of age;
Either:
The actor is married to, or in a domestic partnership with, the complainant; or
The actor is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship with the complainant, and:
When the complainant is under 16 years of age, the actor is less than 4 years older than the complainant; or
When the complainant is under 18 years of age and the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant, the actor is not in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant;
The complainant is the only person who is, or who will be, depicted in the image, or the actor and the complainant are the only persons who are, or who will be, depicted in the image;
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense; and

Under subsections (a)(1)(C) and (D) and (b)(1)(C) and (D) of this section, the actor reasonably believes that the recipient, the planned recipient, or the user of the electronic platform is the complainant.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(C) and (b)(1)(C) of this section for displaying or distributing an image that the actor:
With intent, exclusively and in good faith, to report possible illegal conduct or seek legal counsel from any attorney;
In fact, distributes or displays the image to a person whom the actor reasonably believes is:
A law enforcement officer, prosecutor, or attorney; or

A teacher, school counselor, school administrator, or person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of a person that the actor reasonably believes to be depicted in the image or involved in the creation of the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(C), (D), and (E) and (b)(1)(C), (D), and (E) of this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role; and
Has no control over the creation or selection of the image.
First degree creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree creating or trafficking an obscene image of a minor is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall have the same meaning as provided in 47 U.S.C. § 153(30).

section.heading: Possession of an obscene image of a minor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of an obscene image of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly possesses an image;
Reckless as to the fact that the image depicts, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
A sexual act or simulated sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse or simulated sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation or simulated masturbation; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of an obscene image of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly possesses an image;
Reckless as to the fact that the image depicts, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
An obscene sexual contact; or
An obscene sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola, or the buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a licensee under 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. engaged in activities regulated pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is an interactive computer service, as that term is defined in 47 U.S.C. § 230(f)(2), for content provided by another person.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (a) of this section that, in fact, the image has serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value, when considered as a whole.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
The actor is the only person under 18 years of age who is depicted in the image; or
The actor reasonably believes that every person under 18 years of age who is depicted in the image gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor is at least 18 years of age;
Either:
The actor is married to, or in a domestic partnership with, the complainant; or
The actor is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship with the complainant, and:
When the complainant is under 16 years of age, the actor is less than 4 years older than the complainant; or
When the complainant is under 18 years of age and the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant, the actor is not in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant;
The complainant is the only person who is depicted in the image, or the actor and the complainant are the only persons who are depicted in the image; and
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor:
With intent, exclusively and in good faith, to report possible illegal conduct or to seek legal counsel from any attorney;
In fact, promptly contacts a person whom the actor reasonably believes is:
A law enforcement officer, prosecutor, or attorney; or

A teacher, school counselor, school administrator, or person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant that the actor reasonably believes to be depicted in the image; and
Either:
Promptly distributes the image to one of the individuals specified in subsection (d)(4)(B)(i) or (ii) of this section, without making or retaining a copy; or
Affords a law enforcement officer access to the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role; and
Has no control over the creation or selection of the image.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the image:
With intent, exclusively and in good faith, to permanently dispose of the item; and
In fact, the actor does not possess the item longer than is reasonably necessary to permanently dispose of the item.
First degree possession of an obscene image of a minor is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree possession of an obscene image of a minor is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall have the same meaning as provided in 47 U.S.C. § 153(30).

section.heading: Arranging a live sexual performance of a minor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree arranging a live sexual performance of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly:
Creates, produces, or directs a live performance;

As a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant, gives effective consent for the complainant to engage in or submit to the creation of a live performance; or
Sells admission to or advertises a live performance;
Reckless as to the fact that the live performance depicts, or will depict, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
A sexual act or simulated sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse or simulated sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation or simulated masturbation; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree arranging a live sexual performance of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly:
Creates, produces, or directs a live performance;

As a person with a responsibility under civil law for the health, welfare, or supervision of the complainant, gives effective consent for the complainant to engage in or submit to the creation of a live performance; or
Sells admission to or advertises a live performance;
Reckless as to the fact that the live performance depicts, or will depict, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
An obscene sexual contact; or
An obscene sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola, or the buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (a) of this section that, in fact, the live performance has, or will have, serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value, when considered as a whole.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(A) and (B) and (b)(1)(A) and (B) of this section that, in fact:
The actor is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
The actor is the only person under 18 years of age who is, or who will be, depicted in the live performance; or

The actor reasonably believes that every person under 18 years of age who is, or who will be, depicted in the live performance, gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsections (a)(1)(A) and (b)(1)(A) of this section, that, in fact:
The actor is at least 18 years of age;
Either:
The actor is married to, or in a domestic partnership with, the complainant; or
The actor is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship with the complainant, and:
When the complainant is under 16 years of age, the actor is less than 4 years older than the complainant; or
When the complainant is under 18 years of age and the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant, the actor is not in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant;

The complainant is the only person who is, or who will be, depicted in the live performance, or the actor and complainant are the only persons who are, or who will be, depicted in the live performance;
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense; and
The actor reasonably believes that the actor is the only audience for the live performance, other than the complainant.
It is an affirmative defense to subsections (a)(1)(C) and (b)(1)(C) of this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role;
Has no control over the creation or selection of the live performance; and
Does not record, photograph, or film the live performance.
First degree arranging a live sexual performance of a minor is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree arranging a live sexual performance of a minor is a Class 8 felony.

section.heading: Attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly attends or views a live performance or views a live broadcast;
Reckless as to the fact that the live performance or live broadcast depicts, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
A sexual act or simulated sexual act;
Sadomasochistic abuse or simulated sadomasochistic abuse;
Masturbation or simulated masturbation; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor when the actor:
Knowingly attends or views a live performance or views a live broadcast;
Reckless as to the fact that the live performance or live broadcast depicts, in part or whole, the body of a real complainant under 18 years of age engaging in or submitting to:
An obscene sexual contact; or
An obscene sexual or sexualized display of the breast below the top of the areola, or the buttocks, when there is less than a full opaque covering.

It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the live performance or live broadcast has serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value, when considered as a whole.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor is under 18 years of age; and
Either:
The actor is the only person under 18 years of age who is depicted in the live performance or live broadcast; or

The actor reasonably believes that every person under 18 years of age who is depicted in the live performance or live broadcast gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor is at least 18 years of age;
Either:
The actor is married to, or in a domestic partnership with, the complainant; or
The actor is in a romantic, dating, or sexual relationship with the complainant, and:
When the complainant is under 16 years of age, the actor is less than 4 years older than the complainant; or
When the complainant is under 18 years of age and the actor is at least 4 years older than the complainant, the actor is not in a position of trust with or authority over the complainant;

The complainant is the only person that is depicted in the live performance or live broadcast, or the actor and the complainant are the only persons that are depicted in the live performance or live broadcast;
The actor reasonably believes that the complainant gives effective consent to the actor to engage in the conduct constituting the offense; and
The actor reasonably believes that the actor is the only audience for the live performance or live broadcast, other than the complainant.
It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact:
Is an employee of a school, museum, library, movie theater, or other venue;
Is acting within the reasonable scope of that role;
Has no control over the creation or selection of the live performance or live broadcast; and
Does not record, photograph, or film the live performance or live broadcast.
First degree attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree attending or viewing a live sexual performance of a minor is a Class 9 felony.

section.heading: Aggregation to determine property offense grades.

para.heading: Requirements for aggregation.
para.text: When a single scheme or systematic course of conduct could give rise to multiple charges of an offense listed in subsection (b) of this section, the government instead may bring one charge and aggregate the values, amounts of damage, or quantities of the property involved to determine the grade of the offense.

para.heading: Offenses subject to aggregation.
para.text: Aggregation under subsection (a) of this section may be applied to the following offenses:
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Unlawful creation or possession of a recording under § 22A-3205;
Fraud under § 22A-3301;
Payment card fraud under § 22A-3302;
Check fraud under § 22A-3303;
Forgery under § 22A-3304;
Identity theft under § 22A-3305;
Unlawful labeling of a recording under § 22A-3307;
Financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person under § 22A-3308;
Extortion under § 22A-3401;
Possession of stolen property under § 22A-3501;
Trafficking of stolen property under § 22A-3502;
Alteration of motor vehicle identification number under § 22A-3503; and
Criminal damage to property under § 22A-3603.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree theft when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the consent of an owner;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree theft when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the consent of an owner;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree theft when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the consent of an owner;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property has a value of $5,000 or more; or
The property is a motor vehicle.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree theft when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the consent of an owner;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property has a value of $500 or more; or
The property is taken from a complainant who possesses the property within the complainant's immediate physical control.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree theft when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the consent of an owner;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has any value.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section for conduct that, in fact, constitutes a failure to pay established fare or to present a valid transfer under § 35-252.
First degree theft is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree theft is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree theft is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree theft is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree theft is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unauthorized use of property when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section for conduct that, in fact, constitutes a failure to pay established fare or to present a valid transfer under § 35-252.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor reasonably believes that the property is lost or was stolen by a third party; and
Engages in the conduct constituting the offense with intent to return the property to a lawful owner.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unauthorized use of property is a Class D misdemeanor.

section.heading: Unauthorized use of a motor vehicle.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unauthorized use of a motor vehicle when the actor:
Knowingly operates a motor vehicle;
Without the effective consent of an owner.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
The actor reasonably believes that the motor vehicle is lost or was stolen by a third party; and
Engages in the conduct constituting the offense with intent to return the motor vehicle to a lawful owner.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unauthorized use of a motor vehicle is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits shoplifting when the actor:
Knowingly:
Holds or carries on the actor's person, or conceals;
Removes, alters, or transfers the price tag, serial number, or other identification mark that is imprinted on or attached to; or
Transfers from one container or package to another container or package;
Personal property of another that is:
Displayed or offered for sale; or
Held or stored on the premises in reasonably close proximity to the customer sales area, for future display or sale;
With intent to take or make use of the property without complete payment.

para.heading: No attempt liability.
para.text: The criminal attempt provision in § 22A-301 shall not apply to this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Shoplifting is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Qualified immunity.
para.text: A person who displays, holds, stores, or offers for sale personal property as specified in subsection (a)(2) of this section, or an employee or agent of such a person, who detains or causes the arrest of a person in a place where such property is displayed, held, stored, or offered for sale shall not be held liable for detention, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, defamation, or false arrest, in any proceeding arising out of such detention or arrest, if, in fact:
The person detaining or causing the arrest has, at the time thereof, probable cause to believe that the person detained or arrested committed an offense described in this section;
The manner of the detention or arrest is reasonable;
Law enforcement authorities are notified as soon as practicable; and
The person detained or arrested is released as soon as practicable after the detention or arrest, or is surrendered to law enforcement authorities as soon as practicable.

section.heading: Unlawful creation or possession of a recording.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree unlawful creation or possession of a recording when the actor:
Knowingly makes, obtains, or possesses either:
A sound recording that is a copy of an original sound recording that was fixed before February 15, 1972; or
A sound recording or audiovisual recording of a live performance;
Without the effective consent of an owner;
With intent to sell, rent, or otherwise use the recording for commercial gain or advantage; and
In fact, the number of recordings made, obtained, or possessed is 100 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree unlawful creation or possession of a recording when the actor:
Knowingly makes, obtains, or possesses either:
A sound recording that is a copy of an original sound recording that was fixed before February 15, 1972; or
A sound recording or audiovisual recording of a live performance;
Without the effective consent of an owner;
With intent to sell, rent, or otherwise use the recording for commercial gain or advantage; and
In fact, any number of recordings were made, obtained, or possessed.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when the actor, in fact:
Copies or reproduces a sound recording or audiovisual recording in the manner specifically permitted by Title 17 of the United States Code; or
Copies or reproduces a sound recording that is made by a licensed radio or television station or a cable broadcaster solely for broadcast or archival use.
First degree unlawful creation or possession of a recording is a Class C misdemeanor.
Second degree unlawful creation or possession of a recording is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Forfeiture.
para.text: Upon conviction under this section, the court may, in addition to the penalties provided by this section, order the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of all sound recordings, audiovisual recordings, and equipment used, or attempted to be used, in violation of this section.

section.heading: Unlawful operation of a recording device inside a movie theater.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful operation of a recording device inside a movie theater when the actor:
Knowingly operates a recording device inside a movie theater;
Without the effective consent of an owner of the movie theater; and
With intent to record a motion picture, or any part of it.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful operation of a recording device inside a movie theater is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Qualified immunity.
para.text: An owner of the movie theater specified in subsection (a) of this section, or the owner's employee or agent, who detains or causes the arrest of a person inside, or immediately adjacent to, the movie theater, shall not be held liable for detention, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, defamation, or false arrest in any proceeding arising out of such detention or arrest, if, in fact:

The person detaining or causing the arrest has, at the time thereof, probable cause to believe that the person detained or arrested committed, or attempted to commit, an offense described in this section;
The manner of the detention or arrest is reasonable;
Law enforcement authorities are notified as soon as practicable; and
The person detained or arrested is released as soon as practicable after the detention or arrest, or is surrendered to law enforcement authorities as soon as practicable.

para.heading: Forfeiture.
para.text: Upon conviction under this section, the court may, in addition to the penalties provided by this section, order the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of any recording and all equipment used, or attempted to be used, in violation of this section.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree fraud when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by deception;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property, other than labor or services, has a value of $500,000 or more; or
The property is 2080 hours or more of labor or services.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree fraud when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by deception;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property, other than labor or services, has a value of $50,000 or more; or
The property is 160 hours or more of labor or services.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree fraud when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by deception;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property, other than labor or services, has a value of $5,000 or more; or
The property is 40 hours or more of labor or services.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree fraud when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by deception;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact:
The property, other than labor or services, has a value of $500 or more; or
The property is 8 hours or more of labor or services.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree fraud when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by deception;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has any value.
First degree fraud is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree fraud is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree fraud is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree fraud is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree fraud is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree payment card fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a payment card:
Without the effective consent of the person to whom the payment card was issued;
After the payment card was revoked or canceled;
When the payment card was never issued; or
For the actor's own purposes, when the actor is an employee or contractor and the payment card was issued to the actor for the employer's purposes; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree payment card fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a payment card:
Without the effective consent of the person to whom the payment card was issued;
After the payment card was revoked or canceled;
When the payment card was never issued; or
For the actor's own purposes, when the actor is an employee or contractor and the payment card was issued to the actor for the employer's purposes; and
In fact, the property has a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree payment card fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a payment card:
Without the effective consent of the person to whom the payment card was issued;
After the payment card was revoked or canceled;
When the payment card was never issued; or
For the actor's own purposes, when the actor is an employee or contractor and the payment card was issued to the actor for the employer's purposes; and
In fact, the property has a value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree payment card fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a payment card:
Without the effective consent of the person to whom the payment card was issued;
After the payment card was revoked or canceled;
When the payment card was never issued; or
For the actor's own purposes, when the actor is an employee or contractor and the payment card was issued to the actor for the employer's purposes; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree payment card fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a payment card:
Without the effective consent of the person to whom the payment card was issued; or
After the payment card was revoked or canceled; or
When the payment card was never issued; or
For the actor's own purposes, when the actor is an employee or contractor and the payment card was issued to the actor for the employer's purposes; and
In fact, the property has any value.
First degree payment card fraud is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree payment card fraud is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree payment card fraud is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree payment card fraud is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree payment card fraud is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree check fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a check;
With intent that the check not be honored in full upon presentation to the bank or depository institution drawn upon; and
The amount of loss to the check holder is, in fact, $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree check fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a check;
With intent that the check not be honored in full upon presentation to the bank or depository institution drawn upon; and
The amount of loss to the check holder is, in fact, $500 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree check fraud when the actor:
Knowingly obtains or pays for property by using a check;
With intent that the check not be honored in full upon presentation to the bank or depository institution drawn upon; and
The amount of loss to the check holder is, in fact, any amount.
First degree check fraud is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree check fraud is a Class A misdemeanor.
Third degree check fraud is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree forgery when the actor:
Commits third degree forgery; and
The written instrument appears to be, in fact:
A stock certificate, bond, or other instrument representing an interest in or claim against a corporation or other organization of its property;
A public record, or instrument filed in a public office or with a public servant;
A written instrument officially issued or created by a public office, public servant, or government instrumentality;

A deed, will, codicil, contract, assignment, commercial instrument, or other instrument which does or may evidence, create, transfer, terminate, or otherwise affect a legal right, interest, obligation, or status; or
A written instrument having a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree forgery when the actor:
Commits third degree forgery; and
The written instrument appears to be, in fact:
A token, fare card, public transportation transfer certificate, or other article manufactured for use as a symbol of value in place of money for the purchase of property or services;

A prescription of a duly licensed physician or other person authorized to issue the same for any controlled substance or other instrument or devices used in the taking or administering of controlled substances for which a prescription is required by law; or
A written instrument having a value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree forgery when the actor:
Knowingly does any of the following:
Alters a written instrument without authorization, and the written instrument is reasonably adapted to deceive a person into believing it is genuine;
Makes or completes a written instrument:
That appears:
To be the act of another who did not authorize that act, or
To have been made or completed at a time or place or in a numbered sequence other than was in fact the case, or
To be a copy of an original when no such original existed; and
The written instrument is reasonably adapted to deceive a person into believing the written instrument is genuine; or
Transmits or otherwise uses a written instrument that was made, signed, or altered in a manner specified in subsection (c)(1)(A) or (B) of this section;
With intent to:
Obtain the property of another by deception; or
Harm another person.
First degree forgery is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree forgery is a Class 9 felony.
Third degree forgery is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits identity theft when the actor:
Commits fifth degree identity theft; and
The value of the property intended to be obtained or the amount of the payment intended to be avoided, or the financial injury, whichever is greater, in fact, is $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree identity theft when the actor:
Commits fifth degree identity theft; and
The value of the property intended to be obtained or the amount of the payment intended to be avoided, or the financial injury, whichever is greater, in fact, is $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree identity theft when the actor:
Commits fifth degree identity theft; and
The value of the property intended to be obtained or the amount of the payment intended to be avoided, or the financial injury, whichever is greater, in fact, is $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: A person commits fourth degree identity theft when the actor:
Commits fifth degree identity theft; and
The value of the property intended to be obtained or the amount of the payment intended to be avoided, or the financial injury, whichever is greater, in fact, is $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree identity theft when the actor:
Knowingly creates, possesses, or uses personal identifying information belonging to or pertaining to another person;
Without that other person's effective consent; and
With intent to use the personal identifying information to:
Obtain the property of another by deception;
Avoid payment due for any property, fines, or fees by deception; or
Give, sell, transmit, or transfer the information to a third person to facilitate the use of the identifying information by that third person to obtain property by deception.

para.heading: Unit of prosecution and calculation of time to commence prosecution of offense.
para.text: Creating, possessing, or using a person's personal identifying information in violation of this section shall constitute a single course of conduct for determining the applicable period of limitation under § 23-113(b). The applicable time limitation under § 23-113 shall not begin to run until after the day after the course of conduct has been completed, or the person whose identifying information was taken, possessed, or used knows, or reasonably should have been aware, of the identity theft, whichever occurs earlier.
First degree identity theft is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree identity theft is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree identity theft is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree identity theft is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree identity theft is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Police reports.
para.text: The Metropolitan Police Department shall make a report of each complaint of identity theft and provide the complainant with a copy of the report.

When a person is convicted, adjudicated delinquent, or found not guilty of identity theft under the mental disability affirmative defense in § 22A-504, the court may issue such orders as are necessary to correct any District of Columbia public record that contains false information as a result of a violation of § 22A-3305.

In all other cases, a person who alleges that they are a victim of identity theft may petition the court for an expedited judicial determination that a District of Columbia public record contains false information as a result of a violation of § 22A-3305. Upon a finding of clear and convincing evidence that the person was a victim of identity theft, the court may issue such orders as are necessary to correct any District of Columbia public record that contains false information as a result of a violation of § 22A-3305.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, District of Columbia agencies shall comply with orders issued under subsection (a) of this section within 30 days after the issuance of the order.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree unlawful labeling of a recording when the actor:

Knowingly possesses sound recordings or audiovisual recordings that do not clearly and conspicuously disclose the true name and address of the manufacturer on their labels, covers, or jacket that, in fact, number 100 or more;
With intent to sell or rent the sound recordings or audiovisual recordings.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree unlawful labeling of a recording when the actor:

Knowingly possesses one or more sound recordings or audiovisual recordings that does not clearly and conspicuously disclose the true name and address of the manufacturer on its label, cover, or jacket;
With intent to sell or rent the sound recordings or audiovisual recordings.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when the actor, in fact:

Transfers any sounds or images recorded on a sound recording or audiovisual recording in connection with, or as part of, a radio or television broadcast transmission, or for the purposes of archival preservation; or
Transfers, in their home for their own personal use, any sounds or images recorded on a sound recording or audiovisual recording.
First degree unlawful labeling of a recording is a Class C misdemeanor.
Second degree unlawful labeling of a recording is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Forfeiture.
para.text: Upon conviction under this section, the court may, in addition to the penalties provided by this section, order the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of all sound recordings, audiovisual recordings, and equipment used, or attempted to be used, in violation of this section.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "manufacturer" means the person who affixes, or authorizes the affixation of, sounds or images to a sound recording or audiovisual recording.

section.heading: Financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Commits fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
In fact, the value of the property or the amount of the financial injury, whichever is greater, is $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Commits fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
In fact, the value of the property or the amount of the financial injury, whichever is greater, is $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Commits fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
In fact, the value of the property or the amount of the financial injury, whichever is greater, is $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Commits fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person; and
In fact, the value of the property or the amount of the financial injury, whichever is greater, is $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another:
With consent of an owner obtained by undue influence;
Reckless as to the fact that the owner is a vulnerable adult or elderly person;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has any value; or
Reckless as to the fact that the complainant is a vulnerable adult or elderly person, commits one or more offenses that is, in fact:
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Fraud under § 22A-3301;
Payment card fraud under § 22A-3302;
Check fraud under § 22A-3303;
Forgery under § 22A-3304;
Identity theft under § 22A-3305; or
Extortion under § 22A-3401.
First degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 7 felony.
Third degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 8 felony.
Fourth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class 9 felony.
Fifth degree financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Restitution.
para.text: In addition to the penalties set forth in subsection (f) of this section, a person shall make restitution, before the payment of any fines or civil penalties.

section.heading: Financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person civil provisions.

para.heading: Petition for injunctive relief and protections.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, if the Attorney General for the District of Columbia or the United States Attorney has reason to believe that any person has violated, or intends to violate, section § 22A-3308, the Attorney General or the United States Attorney may bring a civil action in the Court, in the name of the District, which may be by ex parte motion and without notice to the person, to seek any of the following:
A temporary or permanent injunction;
Restitution of money or property;
The cost of the action, including reasonable attorney's fees;

Revocation of all permits, licenses, registrations, or certifications issued by the District authorizing the person to provide services to vulnerable adults or elderly persons, which shall be effective upon the issuance of the Court's judgment, and the person shall not be entitled to a hearing with the relevant licensing board or agency;
Civil penalties of not more than $10,000 per violation; or
Any other relief the court deems just.
In an action under this section:
A related criminal proceeding need not have been initiated, nor judgment secured, prior to bringing the action;
The Attorney General shall not be required to prove damages; and
The burden of proof shall be by a preponderance of the evidence.

para.heading: Standard for court review of petition.
para.text: The court may grant an ex parte motion authorized by subsection (a) of this section without notice to the person against whom the injunction or order is sought if the court finds that facts offered in support of the motion establish that:
There is a substantial likelihood that the person committed financial exploitation of a vulnerable adult or elderly person;
The harm that may result from the injunction or order is clearly outweighed by the risk of harm to the vulnerable adult or elderly person if the injunction or order is not issued; and

If the Attorney General for the District of Columbia or the United States Attorney has petitioned for an order temporarily freezing assets, the order is necessary to prevent dissipation of assets obtained in violation of § 22A-3308.

para.heading: Effect of order to temporarily freeze assets.

para.text: An order temporarily freezing assets without notice to the person under subsections (a) and (c) of this section shall expire on a date set by the court, not later than 14 days after the court issues the order unless, before that time, the court extends the order for good cause shown.

A person whose assets were temporarily frozen under subsections (a) and (c) of this section may move to dissolve or modify the order after notice to the Attorney General for the District of Columbia or the United States Attorney. The court shall hear and decide the motion or application on an expedited basis.

para.heading: Appointment of receiver or conservator.
para.text: The court may issue an order temporarily freezing the assets of the vulnerable adult or elderly person to prevent dissipation of assets; provided, that the court also appoints a receiver or conservator for those assets. The order shall allow for the use of assets to continue care for the vulnerable adult or elderly person, and can only be issued upon a showing that a temporary injunction or temporary restraining order authorized by this section would be insufficient to safeguard the assets, or with the consent of the vulnerable adult or elderly person or their legal representative.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree trademark counterfeiting when the actor:
Knowingly manufactures for sale, possesses with intent to sell, or offers to sell, property bearing or identified by a counterfeit mark; and
In fact, the property consists of 100 or more items, or the property has a total retail value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree trademark counterfeiting when the actor:
Knowingly manufactures for sale, possesses with intent to sell, or offers to sell, property bearing or identified by a counterfeit mark; and
In fact, the property has any value.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section if the actor, in fact, uses a trademark in a manner that is legal under civil law.

para.heading: Seizure and disposal of seized items bearing a counterfeit mark.

para.text: Any items bearing a counterfeit mark shall be seized, and all personal property, including any items, objects, tools, machines, equipment, instrumentalities, or vehicles of any kind, employed or used in connection with a violation of this section may be seized, by any law enforcement officer, including any designated civilian employee of the Metropolitan Police Department, in accordance with the procedures set forth in Chapter 3 of Title 41.
All seized personal property shall be subject to forfeiture pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 3 of Title 41.

Upon the request of the owner of the trademark, service mark, trade name, label, term, picture, seal, word, or advertisement, all seized items bearing a counterfeit mark shall be released to the owner of the trademark, service mark, trade name, label, term, picture, seal, word, or advertisement for destruction or disposition.

If the owner of the trademark, service mark, trade name, label, term, picture, seal, word, or advertisement does not request release of seized items bearing a counterfeit mark, such items shall be destroyed unless the owner of the of the trademark, service mark, trade name, label, term, picture, seal, word, or advertisement consents to another disposition.

para.heading: Evidence of state or federal registration.
para.text: Any state or federal certificate of registration of any trademark, service mark, trade name, label, term, picture, seal, word, or advertisement shall be prima facie evidence of the facts stated therein.
First degree trademark counterfeiting is a Class A misdemeanor.
Second degree trademark counterfeiting is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree extortion when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree extortion when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree extortion when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree extortion when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree extortion when the actor:
Knowingly takes, obtains, transfers, or exercises control over the property of another;
With the consent of an owner obtained by an explicit or implicit coercive threat;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has any value.
First degree extortion is a Class 6 felony.
Second degree extortion is a Class 7 felony.
Third degree extortion is a Class 8 felony.
Fourth degree extortion is a Class 9 felony.
Fifth degree extortion is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree possession of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree possession of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has a value of $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree possession of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to deprive an owner of the property; and
In fact, the property has any value.
First degree possession of stolen property is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree possession of stolen property is a Class 9 felony.
Third degree possession of stolen property is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fourth degree possession of stolen property is a Class B misdemeanor.
Fifth degree possession of stolen property is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree trafficking of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property on 2 or more separate occasions;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to sell, pledge as consideration, or trade the property; and
In fact, the total property trafficked has a value of $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree trafficking of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property on 2 or more separate occasions;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to sell, pledge as consideration, or trade the property; and
In fact, the total property trafficked has a value of $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree trafficking of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property on 2 or more separate occasions;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to sell, pledge as consideration, or trade the property; and
In fact, the total property trafficked has a value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree trafficking of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property on 2 or more separate occasions;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to sell, pledge as consideration, or trade the property; and
In fact, the total property trafficked has a value of $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree trafficking of stolen property when the actor:
Knowingly buys or possesses property on 2 or more separate occasions;
With intent that the property be stolen;
With intent to sell, pledge as consideration, or trade the property; and
In fact, the property trafficked has any value.
First degree trafficking of stolen property is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree trafficking of stolen property is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree trafficking of stolen property is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree trafficking of stolen property is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree trafficking of stolen property is a Class C misdemeanor.

section.heading: Alteration of a motor vehicle identification number.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree alteration of a motor vehicle identification number when the actor:
Knowingly alters a vehicle identification number of a motor vehicle or motor vehicle part;
With intent to conceal or misrepresent the identity of the motor vehicle or motor vehicle part; and
The value of such motor vehicle or motor vehicle part, in fact, is $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree alteration of a motor vehicle identification number when the actor:
Knowingly alters a vehicle identification number of a motor vehicle or motor vehicle part;
With intent to conceal or misrepresent the identity of the motor vehicle or motor vehicle part; and
The motor vehicle or motor vehicle part, in fact, has any value.
First degree alteration of a motor vehicle identification number is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree alteration of a motor vehicle identification number is a Class B misdemeanor.

section.heading: Alteration of a bicycle identification number.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits alteration of a bicycle identification numbers when the actor:
Knowingly alters an identification number of a bicycle or bicycle part;
With intent to conceal or misrepresent the identity of the bicycle or bicycle part.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Alteration of a bicycle identification number is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the terms "bicycle" "and "identification number" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 50-1609(1) and (1A), respectively.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree arson when the actor:
Knowingly starts a fire, or causes an explosion, that damages or destroys a dwelling or building;
Reckless as to the fact that a person who is not a participant in the crime is present inside the dwelling or building; and
In fact, the fire or explosion causes death or serious bodily injury to any person who is not a participant in the crime.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree arson when the actor:
Knowingly starts a fire, or causes an explosion, that damages or destroys a dwelling or building;
Reckless as to the fact that a person who is not a participant in the crime is present inside the dwelling or building.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree arson when the actor knowingly starts a fire, or causes an explosion, that damages or destroys a dwelling or building.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under subsection (c) of this section that the actor, in fact, has a valid blasting permit issued by the Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department, and complied with all the rules and regulations governing the use of such a permit.
First degree arson is a Class 5 felony.
Second degree arson is a Class 7 felony.
Third degree arson is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits reckless burning when the actor:
Knowingly starts a fire or causes an explosion;
Reckless as to the fact that the fire or explosion damages or destroys a dwelling or building.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor, in fact, has a valid blasting permit issued by the Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department, and complied with all the rules and regulations governing the use of such a permit.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Reckless burning is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree criminal damage to property when the actor:
Knowingly damages or destroys the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact, the amount of damage is $500,000 or more.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree criminal damage to property when the actor:
Knowingly damages or destroys the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact, the amount of damage is $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree criminal damage to property when the actor:
Knowingly damages or destroys the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact:
The amount of damage is $5,000 or more;
The property is a cemetery, grave, or other place for the internment of human remains; or
The property is a place of worship or a public monument; or
Recklessly damages or destroys property;
Knowing that it is the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact, the amount of damage is $50,000 or more.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fourth degree criminal damage to property when the actor:
Recklessly damages or destroys property;
Knowing that it is the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact, the amount of damage is $500 or more.

para.heading: Fifth degree.
para.text: An actor commits fifth degree criminal damage to property when the actor:
Recklessly damages or destroys property;
Knowing that it is the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner; and
In fact, there is any amount of damage to the property.
First degree criminal damage to property is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree criminal damage to property is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree criminal damage to property is a Class 9 felony.
Fourth degree criminal damage to property is a Class A misdemeanor.
Fifth degree criminal damage to property is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits criminal graffiti when the actor:
Knowingly places any inscription, writing, drawing, marking, or design on the property of another;
Without the effective consent of an owner.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Criminal graffiti is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree trespass when the actor:
Knowingly enters or remains inside a dwelling, or part thereof;
Without a privilege or license to do so under civil law.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree trespass when the actor:
Knowingly enters or remains inside a building, or part thereof;
Without a privilege or license to do so under civil law.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree trespass when the actor:
Knowingly enters or remains inside or on land, a watercraft, or a motor vehicle, or part thereof;
Without a privilege or license to do so under civil law.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section by, in fact, violating a barring notice issued for District of Columbia Housing Authority properties unless the bar notice is lawfully issued pursuant to the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations on an objectively reasonable basis.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section for conduct that, in fact, constitutes a failure to pay established fare or to present a valid transfer under § 35-252.

para.heading: Permissive inference.
para.text: In a trial determining a violation of this section, a factfinder may, but is not required to, infer that an actor lacks a privilege or license to enter or remain inside or on a location that:
Is otherwise vacant;
Shows signs of a forced entry; and
Either:
Is secured in a manner that reasonably conveys that it is not to be entered; or
Displays signage that is reasonably visible prior to or outside the location's points of entry, and that sign says "no trespassing" or similarly indicates that a person may not enter.
First degree trespass is a Class B misdemeanor.
Second degree trespass is a Class C misdemeanor.
Third degree trespass is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree burglary when the actor:
Knowingly and fully enters or surreptitiously remains inside a dwelling, or part thereof;
Without a privilege or license to do so under civil law;
With intent to commit while inside one or more offenses that is, in fact, an offense under Chapter 2 of this title or a predicate property offense;
Reckless as to the fact that a person who is not a participant in the burglary either is entering with the actor or is already inside; and
In fact, the person directly perceives the actor while the actor is inside.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree burglary when the actor:
Knowingly and fully enters or surreptitiously remains inside:
A dwelling, or part thereof, without a privilege or license to do so under civil law; or
A building, or part thereof, without a privilege or license to do so under civil law:
That is not open to the general public at the time of the burglary;
Reckless as to the fact that a person who is not a participant in the burglary either is entering with the actor or is already inside; and
With intent to commit while inside one or more offense that is, in fact, an offense under Chapter 2 of this title or a predicate property offense.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree burglary when the actor:
Knowingly and fully enters or surreptitiously remains inside:
A building or business yard, or part thereof;
That is not open to the general public at the time of the burglary;
Without a privilege or license to do so under civil law; and
With intent to commit while inside one or more offenses that is, in fact, an offense under Chapter 2 of this title or a predicate property offense.
First degree burglary is a Class 8 felony, but notwithstanding § 22A-603, the maximum term of imprisonment for first degree burglary is 6 years.
Second degree burglary is a Class 8 felony.
Third degree burglary is a Class A misdemeanor.

The maximum penalty for first degree burglary shall be increased by 2 classes if the actor knowingly holds or carries on the actor's person, while entering or surreptitiously remaining in the location, what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation firearm.

The maximum penalty for second degree burglary shall be increased by one class if the actor knowingly holds or carries on the actor's person, while entering or surreptitiously remaining in the location, what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation firearm.

The maximum penalty for third degree burglary shall be increased by 5 years if the actor knowingly holds or carries on the actor's person, while entering or surreptitiously remaining in the location, what is, in fact, a dangerous weapon or imitation firearm.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate property offense" means:
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Unauthorized use of property under § 22A-3202;
Unauthorized use of a motor vehicle under § 22A-3203;
Extortion under § 22A-3401;
Arson under § 22A-3601;
Reckless burning under § 22A-3602; or
Criminal damage to property under § 22A-3603.

section.heading: Possession of tools to commit a property crime.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits possession of tools to commit a property crime when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a tool, or tools, designed or specifically adapted for picking locks, cutting chains, cutting glass, bypassing an electronic security system, or bypassing a locked door;
With intent to use the tool or tools to commit one or more offenses that is, in fact:
Theft under § 22A-3201;
Unauthorized use of property under § 22A-3202;
Unauthorized use of a motor vehicle under § 22A-3203;
Shoplifting under § 22A-3204;
Alteration of motor vehicle identification number under § 22A-3503;
Alteration of bicycle identification number under § 22A-3504;
Arson under § 22A-3601;
Criminal damage to property under § 22A-3603;
Criminal graffiti under § 22A-3604;
Trespass under § 22A-3701; or
Burglary under § 22A-3801.

para.heading: No attempt liability.
para.text: The criminal attempt provision in § 22A-301 shall not apply to this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Possession of tools to commit a property crime is a Class D misdemeanor.

container.heading: Bribery, Improper Influence, and Official Misconduct. [Reserved]
Purjury and Other Official Falsification Offenses.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree impersonation of an official when the actor:
With intent:
To deceive any other person as to the actor's lawful authority; and
Either:
To cause harm to another person; or
That any person receives a personal benefit of any kind;
Knowingly and falsely represents themselves to currently hold lawful authority as a:
Judge of a federal or local court in the District of Columbia;
Prosecutor for the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, or the Attorney General for the District of Columbia;
Notary public;
Law enforcement officer;
Public safety employee;
District official;
District employee with power to enforce District laws or regulations; or
Person authorized to solemnize marriage; and
Performs the duty, exercises the authority, or attempts to perform the duty or exercise the authority pertaining to a person listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree impersonation of an official when the actor:
With intent:
To deceive any other person as to the actor's lawful authority; and
Either:
To cause harm to another person; or
That any person receive a personal benefit of any kind;
Knowingly and falsely represents themselves to currently hold lawful authority as a:
Judge of a federal or local court in the District of Columbia;
Prosecutor for the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, or the Attorney General for the District of Columbia;
Notary public;
Law enforcement officer;
Public safety employee;
District official;
District employee with power to enforce District laws or regulations; or
Person authorized to solemnize marriage.

para.heading: Civil provision regarding use of official uniform insignia.
para.text: The Metropolitan Police Department and the Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department shall have the sole and exclusive rights to have and use, in carrying out their respective missions, the official badges, patches, emblems, copyrights, descriptive or designating marks, and other official insignia displayed upon their current and future uniforms.
First degree impersonation of an official is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree impersonation of an official is a Class B misdemeanor.

section.heading: Misrepresentation as a District of Columbia entity.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits misrepresentation as a District of Columbia entity when the actor:
Knowingly:
Engages in the business of collecting or aiding in the collection of debts or obligations, or of providing private police, investigation, or other detective services; and
Uses the words "District of Columbia", "District", or "D.C." in the business name or in a business communication;
With intent to:
Deceive any other person as to the actor's lawful authority as a District of Columbia entity; and
Receive a personal or business benefit of any kind; and
In fact, the name or communication would cause a reasonable person in the complainant's circumstances to believe that the actor is a District of Columbia government entity or representative.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Misrepresentation as a District of Columbia entity is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "actor" includes a legal entity that is not a natural person.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits perjury when the actor either:
Knowingly makes a false statement in an official proceeding and, in fact:
The actor makes the false statement while testifying, orally or in writing, under oath or affirmation attesting to the truth of the statement;
The oath or affirmation is administered:
Before a competent tribunal, officer, or person; and
In a case or matter in which the law authorizes the taking of such an oath or affirmation; and
The false statement is material to the course or outcome of the official proceeding; or
Knowingly makes a false statement in a sworn declaration or unsworn declaration and, in fact, the statement is:
In a writing with a statement indicating that the declaration is made under penalty of perjury;
Delivered in a case or matter where the law requires or permits the statement to be made in a sworn declaration; and
Material to the case or matter in which the declaration is delivered.

para.heading: Requirement of corroboration.
para.text: In a prosecution under this section, proof of falsity of a statement may not be established solely by the uncorroborated testimony of a single witness.
It is a defense to liability under subsection (a)(1) of this section that, in fact:
The actor retracted the false statement during the course of the official proceeding;
The retraction occurred before the falsity of the statement was exposed; and
The retraction occurred before the false statement substantially affected the proceeding.
It is a defense to liability under subsection (a)(2) of this section that, in fact:
The actor retracted the false statement before the statement was delivered in the case or matter; and
The retraction occurred before the falsity of the statement was exposed.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Perjury is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Competent" means having jurisdiction over the actor and case or matter.
"Tribunal" means any District of Columbia court, regulatory agency, commission, or other body or person authorized by law to render a decision of a judicial or quasi-judicial nature.
"Officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 1-301.45.
"Sworn declaration" means a signed record given under oath or affirmation attesting to its truth including a sworn statement, verification, certificate, or affidavit.
"Unsworn declaration" means a declaration in a signed record that is not given under oath but is given under penalty of perjury in the form specified in § 16-5306 or 28 U.S.C. §1746(2).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits perjury by false certification when the actor:
Knowingly makes a false certification of:
Acknowledgement; or
Another material matter in an acknowledgment; and
In fact, the actor is a notarial official or other officer authorized to take proof or certification.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Perjury by false certification is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Acknowledgement" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 1-1231.01.
"Notarial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 1-1231.01.
"Officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 1-301.45.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits solicitation of perjury when the actor:

Knowingly commands, requests, or tries to persuade another person to engage in conduct, which, if carried out, in fact, will constitute either the offense of perjury or perjury by false certification under District of Columbia law;
Acts with the culpability required for the offense of perjury or the offense of perjury by false certification; and
The other person engages in conduct which constitutes either the offense of perjury or the offense of perjury by false certification under District of Columbia law.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Solicitation of perjury is a Class 8 felony.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits false swearing when the actor:
Knowingly makes a false statement in a writing to a notarial officer or other person while under oath or affirmation attesting to the truth of the statement; and
In fact:
The oath or affirmation was administered by a notarial officer or other person authorized to administer oaths; and
The statement is:
Material to the case or matter in which it was delivered; and
Required by law to be sworn or affirmed before a notarial official or other person authorized to take and certify acknowledgment or proof.
False swearing is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor commits the offense negligent as to the fact that the statement is material to the arrest, detention, prosecution, conviction, sentence, search, or seizure of another person.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: The terms "acknowledgment" and "notarial officer" have the same meanings specified in § 1-1231.01.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits false statements when the actor:
Knowingly makes a false statement in writing, directly or indirectly, to any District of Columbia government agency, department, or instrumentality, including any court of the District of Columbia;
Negligent as to the fact that the writing indicates the making of a false statement is punishable by criminal penalty; and
In fact, the statement is:
Made under circumstances in which the statement could reasonably be expected to be relied upon as true; and
Material to the case or matter to which it was delivered or likely to be delivered.
False statements is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by 2 classes when the actor commits the offense negligent as to the fact that the statement is material to the arrest, detention, prosecution, conviction, sentence, search, or seizure of another person.

section.heading: Impersonation of another before a tribunal, officer, or person.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits impersonation of another before a tribunal, officer, or person when the actor:
Knowingly provides personal identifying information belonging to another person to a competent tribunal, officer, or person;
With intent to deceive the tribunal, officer, or person as to the actor's identity; and
In fact, the personally identifying information was given under circumstances in which the information could reasonably be expected to be relied upon as true.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Impersonation of another before a tribunal, officer, or person is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree obstruction of justice when the actor:
Knowing that an official proceeding or criminal investigation has been initiated for any crime that is, in fact, a predicate felony;
Commits any criminal offense under District of Columbia law;
With the purpose of obstructing or impeding the proper functioning and integrity of the official proceeding or the criminal investigation.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree obstruction of justice when the actor:
Knowing that an official proceeding or criminal investigation has been initiated for any crime;
