In fact, commits any criminal offense under District of Columbia law;
With the purpose of obstructing or impeding the proper functioning and integrity of the official proceeding or the criminal investigation.
First degree obstruction of justice is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree obstruction of justice is a Class A misdemeanor.

A conviction for obstruction of justice shall not merge with a conviction for any offense specified in subsection (a)(2) or subsection (b)(2) of this section when arising from the same act or course of conduct except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

A conviction for obstruction of justice shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).
For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate felony" means:
Any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that requires as an element a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; or

A criminal attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that requires as an element a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death.

section.heading: Tampering with a witness or informant.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree tampering with a witness or informant when the actor:
In fact, commits a crime of violence;
Knowing that an official proceeding or criminal investigation has been initiated or is likely to be initiated;
With the purpose of causing a person to:
Testify or inform falsely in the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Elude legal process summoning the person to testify or supply evidence in the official proceeding;
Be absent from the official proceeding to which the person has been legally summoned; or
Destroy, conceal, remove, or alter a document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object so as to either:
Impair its value as evidence in the official proceeding; or
Prevent its production or use in the official proceeding.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree tampering with a witness or informant when the actor:
Either:
Knowingly, directly or indirectly, offers, confers or agrees to confer upon another person anything of value; or
In fact:
Commits any criminal offense other than obstruction of justice under District of Columbia law;
With intent to cause a person to:
Fear for the person's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress;
Knowing that an official proceeding or criminal investigation has been initiated or is likely to be initiated;
With the purpose of causing a person to:
Testify or inform falsely in the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Elude legal process summoning the person to testify or supply evidence in the official proceeding;
Be absent from the official proceeding to which the person has been legally summoned; or
Destroy, conceal, remove, or alter a document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object so as to either:
Impair its value as evidence in the official proceeding; or
Prevent its production or use in the official proceeding.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree tampering with a witness or informant when the actor:
In fact, commits any criminal offense other than obstruction of justice under District of Columbia law;
Knowing that an official proceeding or criminal investigation has been initiated or is likely to be initiated;
With the purpose of causing a person to:
Testify or inform falsely in the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding or criminal investigation;
Elude legal process summoning the person to testify or supply evidence in the official proceeding;
Be absent from the official proceeding to which the person has been legally summoned; or
Destroy, conceal, remove, or alter a document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object so as to either:
Impair its value as evidence in the official proceeding; or
Prevent its production or use in the official proceeding.
First degree tampering with a witness or informant is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree tampering with a witness or informant is a Class 9 felony.
Third degree tampering with a witness or informant is a Class A misdemeanor.

A conviction for tampering with a witness or informant shall not merge with a conviction for any offense specified in subsection (a)(1) or subsection (b)(1) of this section when arising from the same act or course of conduct except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

A conviction for tampering with a witness or informant shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

section.heading: Tampering with a juror or court official.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree tampering with a juror or court official when the actor:
In fact, commits a crime of violence;
Knowing that an official proceeding has been initiated or is likely to be initiated; and
With the purpose of:
Influencing the vote, opinion, decision, deliberation, or other official action of a juror in the official proceeding;
Influencing the opinion, decisions, or other official action of a court official in the official proceeding;
Causing a juror to withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding; or
Causing a person to be absent from jury service to which the person has been legally summoned or ordered to return.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree tampering with a juror or court official when the actor:
Either:
Knowingly, directly or indirectly, offers, confers or agrees to confer upon another person anything of value; or
In fact:
Commits any criminal offense other than obstruction of justice under District of Columbia law;
With intent to cause a person to:
Fear for the person's safety or the safety of another person; or
Suffer significant emotional distress;
Knowing that an official proceeding has been initiated or is likely to be initiated;
With the purpose of:
Influencing the vote, opinion, decision, deliberation, or other official action of a juror in the official proceeding;
Influencing the opinion, decisions, or other official action of a court official in the official proceeding;
Causing a juror to withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding; or
Causing a person to be absent from jury service to which the person has been legally summoned or ordered to return.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree tampering with a juror or court official when the actor:
In fact, commits any criminal offense other than obstruction of justice under District of Columbia law;
Knowing that an official proceeding has been initiated or is likely to be initiated;
With the purpose of:
Influencing the vote, opinion, decision, deliberation, testimony, or other official action of a juror in the official proceeding;
Influencing the opinion, decisions, testimony, or other official action of a court official in the official proceeding;
Causing a juror to withhold any testimony or information that has the natural tendency to influence, or is capable of influencing, the official proceeding; or
Causing a person to be absent from jury service to which the person has been legally summoned or ordered to return.
First degree tampering with a juror or court official is a Class 7 felony.
Second degree tampering with a juror or court official is a Class 9 felony.
Third degree tampering with a juror or court official is a Class A misdemeanor.

A conviction for tampering with a juror or court official shall not merge with a conviction for any offense specified in subsection (a)(1) or subsection (b)(1) of this section when arising from the same act or course of conduct except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

A conviction for tampering with a juror or court official shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

section.heading: Retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official when the actor:
With the purpose of harming another person because of the person's prior:
Appearance at or testimony in an official proceeding;

Provision of any information, document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object related to a violation of any criminal statute to a court official in an official proceeding or a law enforcement officer in a criminal investigation; or
Performance of their official duties as a juror or court official in an official proceeding;
In fact, commits a crime of violence against any person.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official when the actor:
With the purpose, in whole or part, of harming another person because of the person's prior:
Appearance at or testimony in an official proceeding;

Provision of any information, document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object related to a violation of any criminal statute to a court official in an official proceeding or a law enforcement officer in a criminal investigation; or
Performance of their official duties as a juror or court official in an official proceeding;
In fact, commits a predicate offense against any person.
First degree retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official is a Class B misdemeanor.

A conviction for retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official shall not merge with a conviction for any offense specified in subsection (a)(2) or subsection (b)(2) of this section when arising from the same act or course of conduct except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

A conviction for retaliation against a witness, informant, juror, or court official shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).
For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate offense" means:
Any crime under this title that includes as an element a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death;
Any crime under this title that includes as an element damage to or destruction of a dwelling, building, or the property of another; or
A criminal attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any crime under this title that includes as an element:
A bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, death; or
Damage to or destruction of a dwelling, building, or the property of another.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits tampering with evidence in the first degree when the actor:
Knowingly destroys, conceals, removes, or alters a document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object, regardless of medium, either:
With the purpose of impairing its value as evidence in an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated for a predicate felony; or
With the purpose of preventing its production or use in an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated for a predicate felony; or
Knowingly makes, presents, or uses any document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object, regardless of medium:
With the purpose of deceiving another person as to its veracity; and
With the purpose of affecting the course or outcome of an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated for a predicate felony.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits tampering with evidence in the second degree when the actor:
Knowingly destroys, conceals, removes, or alters a document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object, regardless of medium, either:
With the purpose of impairing its value as evidence in an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated; or
With the purpose of preventing its production or use in an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated; or
Knowingly makes, presents, or uses any document, record, image, audiovisual recording, or other object, regardless of medium:
With the purpose of deceiving another person as to its veracity; and
With the purpose of affecting the course or outcome of an official proceeding or criminal investigation that, in fact, has been or is likely to be initiated.
First degree tampering with evidence is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree tampering with evidence is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for tampering with evidence shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the act or same course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).
For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate felony" means:
Any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that includes as an element in a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; or

A criminal attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that includes as an element a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree hindering apprehension or prosecution when the actor:
With the purpose of impeding or preventing the apprehension, prosecution, conviction, or punishment of another person for prior conduct;
Knowingly:
Harbors or conceals the other person; or
Provides or aids in providing the other person a weapon, transportation, disguise, or other means of avoiding apprehension; and
The prior conduct that the other person is charged with or liable to be charged with, in fact, constitutes a predicate felony.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree hindering apprehension or prosecution when the actor:
With the purpose of impeding or preventing the apprehension, prosecution, conviction, or punishment of another person for prior conduct;
Knowingly:
Harbors or conceals the other person; or
Provides or aids the other person by providing a weapon, transportation, disguise, or other means of avoiding apprehension.
First degree hindering apprehension or prosecution is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree hindering apprehension or prosecution is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for hindering apprehension or prosecution shall merge with a conviction for any other offense under Chapter 4 of this title arising from the same act or course of conduct. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-214(b) and (c).

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "predicate felony" means:
Any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that includes as an element in a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death; or

A criminal attempt, solicitation, or conspiracy to commit any Class 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7 felony under this title that includes as an element a bodily injury, sexual act, sexual contact, confinement, or death.

section.heading: Escape from a correctional facility or officer.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree escape from a correctional facility or officer when the actor:

In fact, is subject to a court order that authorizes the actor's confinement in a correctional facility, secure juvenile detention facility, or cellblock operated by the United States Marshals Service; and

Knowingly, without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services, or the United States Marshals Service, leaves the correctional facility, juvenile detention facility, or cellblock operated by the United States Marshals Service.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree escape from a correctional facility or officer when the actor:
In fact, is in the lawful official custody of a law enforcement officer of the District of Columbia or of the United States; and
Knowingly, without the effective consent of the law enforcement officer, leaves official custody.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree escape from a correctional facility or officer when the actor:
In fact, is subject to a court order that authorizes the person's confinement in a correctional facility or halfway house; and
Knowingly, without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services:
Fails to return to the correctional facility or halfway house;
Fails to report to the correctional facility or halfway house; or
Leaves a halfway house.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (b) of this section when, in fact, the actor is within a correctional facility, juvenile detention facility, or halfway house.
First degree escape from a correctional facility or officer is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree escape from a correctional facility or officer is a Class A misdemeanor.
Third degree escape from a correctional facility or officer is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits tampering with a detection device when the actor:
Knows the actor is required to wear a detection device while:
Subject to a final civil protection order issued under § 16-1005;
On pretrial release in a District of Columbia case;
On presentence or predisposition release in a District of Columbia case;
Committed to the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services or incarcerated, in a District of Columbia case; or
On supervised release, probation, or parole, in a District of Columbia case; and
Either:
Removes the detection device or allows an unauthorized person to do so; or
Interferes with the emission or detection of the detection device or allows an unauthorized person to do so.

para.heading: Jurisdiction.
para.text: An offense under this section shall be deemed to be committed in the District of Columbia, regardless of whether the actor is physically present in the District of Columbia.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Tampering with a detection device is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree correctional facility contraband when the actor:
With intent that an item be received by someone confined to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility:
Knowingly brings the item to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility;
Without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services; and
The item, in fact, is Class A contraband; or
In fact, is someone confined to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility and:
Knowingly possesses an item in a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility;
Without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services; and
The item, in fact, is Class A contraband.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree correctional facility contraband when the actor:
With intent that an item be received by someone confined to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility:
Knowingly brings the item to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility;
Without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services; and
The item, in fact, is Class B contraband; or
In fact, is someone confined to a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility and:
Knowingly possesses an item in a correctional facility or secure juvenile detention facility;
Without the effective consent of the Mayor, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Director of the Department of Youth Rehabilitation Services; and
The item, in fact, is Class B contraband.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section for, in fact, possessing:
A portable electronic communication device, in the course of a legal visit;
A controlled substance that is prescribed to the actor and medically necessary to have immediately or constantly accessible; or
A syringe, needle, or other medical device, that is medically necessary to have immediately or constantly available.

para.heading: Detainment authority.
para.text: If there is probable cause to suspect an actor of committing correctional facility contraband under subsection (a)(1) or subsection (b)(1) of this section, the warden or director of a correctional facility may detain the actor for not more than 2 hours, pending surrender to the Metropolitan Police Department or a law enforcement agency acting pursuant to § 10-509.01.
First degree correctional facility contraband is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree correctional facility contraband is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Resisting arrest or interfering with the arrest of another person.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits resisting arrest or interfering with the arrest of another person when the actor:
With the purpose of preventing the actor or another person from being placed in official custody;
Knowingly:
Uses physical force against a law enforcement officer; or
Engages in conduct other than speech or passive resistance that either:
Creates a substantial risk of causing significant bodily injury to a law enforcement officer; or
Requires substantial physical force by a law enforcement officer to overcome the actor's resistance; and
The actor is reckless as to the fact that:
A law enforcement officer verbally communicated to the person under arrest that the person was under arrest;
The communication would cause a reasonable person in the actor's circumstances to believe that the actor or another person was under arrest; and
The actor was given a reasonable opportunity to:
Submit to arrest; or
Cease or refrain from using force or engaging in conduct interfering with the arrest of another person.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes:
The actor or another person is in imminent danger of significant bodily injury; and
The conduct constituting the offense:
Will protect against such bodily injury; and
Is necessary in degree.

para.heading: Unit of prosecution.
para.text: Where conduct is of a continuing nature, the unit of prosecution is based on the arrest regardless of the number of law enforcement officers involved in the arrest.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Resisting arrest or interfering with the arrest of another person is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Merger of possessory offenses and offenses related to other crime.
para.text: Multiple convictions for 2 or more of the following offenses merge when arising from the same act or course of conduct:
Possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition under § 7-2502.01a;
Possession of a stun gun under § 7-2502.15;
Carrying an air or spring gun under § 7-2502.17;
Carrying a dangerous weapon under § 22A-5104;
Possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime under § 22A-5105; and
Possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime under § 22A-5106.

para.heading: Merger of offenses related to other crime and display or use of weapon.
para.text: When arising from the same act or course of conduct, convictions for possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime under § 22A-5105 or possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime under § 22A-5106 merge with any offense under Chapter 2 or 3 of this title that includes as an element of any gradation or enhancement that the person displayed or used a dangerous weapon.

para.heading: Merger procedure and rule of priority.
para.text: For an actor found guilty of 2 or more offenses that merge under this section the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

section.heading: Exclusions from liability for weapon offenses.

para.heading: Scope of exclusion.
para.text: The exclusions from liability specified in this section apply to the following offenses:
Possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition under § 7-2502.01a;
Possession of a stun gun under § 7-2502.15;
Carrying an air or spring gun under § 7-2502.17;
Carrying a pistol in an unlawful manner under § 7-2509.06A;
Possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory under § 22A-5103; and
Carrying a dangerous weapon under § 22A-5104.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other District law, an actor does not commit an offense specified in subsection (a) of this section when, in fact, the actor is:
A member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, or Marine Corps of the United States;
An on-duty member of the National Guard or Organized Reserves;
A qualified law enforcement officer, as that term is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 926B;

A qualified retired law enforcement officer, as that term is defined in 18 U.S.C. § 926C(c), who carries a concealed pistol that is registered under § 7-2502.07 and is conveniently accessible and within reach;

An on-duty licensed special police officer or campus police officer, who possesses or carries a firearm registered under § 7-2502.07 in accordance with § 5-129.02 and all rules issued pursuant to that section;
An on-duty director, deputy director, officer, or employee of the Department of Corrections who possesses or carries a firearm registered under § 7-2502.07;
An employee of the District or federal government, who is on duty and acting within the scope of those duties;
Lawfully engaging in the business of manufacturing, repairing, or dealing the weapon involved in the offense;
Lawfully engaging in the business of shipping or delivering the weapon involved in the offense; or
Acting within the scope of authority granted by the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department or a competent court.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other District law, an actor shall not be subject to prosecution for an offense specified in subsection (a) of this section if, in fact, the actor:
Holds a valid registration certificate issued under § 7-2502.07; and
Possesses the registered firearm or ammunition for a firearm of the same caliber while:
At the home or place of business designated on the registration certificate;
Transporting the firearm or ammunition, in accordance with § 22A-5111, to or from:
A place of sale;
The person's home or place of business;
A place of repair;
A firearms training and safety class conducted by a firearms instructor; or
A lawful recreational firearm-related activity; or
Transporting the firearm or ammunition for a lawful purpose as expressly authorized by a District or federal statute and in accordance with the requirements of that statute.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other District law, an actor does not commit an offense specified in subsection (a) of this section when, in fact, the actor possesses or carries a firearm while participating in a firearms training and safety class conducted by a firearms instructor.

section.heading: Possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm or explosive;
Reckless as to the fact that the firearm or explosive is:
An assault weapon;
A machine gun;
A sawed-off shotgun;
A restricted explosive; or
A ghost gun.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm accessory;
Reckless as to the fact that the firearm accessory is:
A firearm silencer;
A bump stock; or
A large capacity ammunition feeding device.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in § 22A-5102.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the item while, in fact, voluntarily surrendering the item pursuant to District or federal law.
First degree possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for possession of a prohibited weapon or accessory does not merge with any other offense arising from the same act or course of conduct.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree carrying a dangerous weapon when the actor:
Knowingly possesses:
A firearm, other than a pistol;
A pistol, without a license to carry under § 22A-5112; or
A restricted explosive;
The firearm, pistol, or restricted explosive is conveniently accessible and within reach; and
The actor is in a location:
Other than the actor's home, place of business, or land; and
That, in fact, is:
Within 300 feet of the boundary line of a school, college, university, public swimming pool, public playground, public youth center, public library, or children's day care center; and
Displays clear and conspicuous signage indicating that firearms or explosives are prohibited.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree carrying a dangerous weapon when the actor:
Knowingly possesses:
A firearm, other than a pistol;
A pistol, without a license to carry under § 22A-5112; or
A restricted explosive;
The firearm, pistol, or restricted explosive is conveniently accessible and within reach; and
The actor is in a location other than the actor's home, place of business, or land.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits third degree carrying a dangerous weapon when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a dangerous weapon;
The dangerous weapon is conveniently accessible and within reach;
The actor is in a location other than the actor's home, place of business, or land; and
With intent to use the weapon in a manner that:
Is likely to cause death or serious bodily injury to another person; and
Does not constitute defense of self or another person under § 22A-403.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in § 22A-5102.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the item while, in fact, voluntarily surrendering the item pursuant to District or federal law.
First degree carrying a dangerous weapon is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree carrying a dangerous weapon is a Class 9 felony.
Third degree carrying a dangerous weapon is a Class B misdemeanor.

section.heading: Possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime when the actor:
Knowingly possesses an object designed to explode or produce uncontained combustion;
With intent to use the object to commit a criminal harm that is, in fact:
An offense under Chapter 2 of this title; or
An offense under Chapter 3 of this title.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime when the actor:
Knowingly possesses:
A dangerous weapon; or
An imitation firearm;
With intent to use the imitation firearm or dangerous weapon to commit a criminal harm that is, in fact:
An offense under Chapter 2 of this title; or
Burglary under § 22A-3801.

para.heading: Limitation on attempt liability.
para.text: The criminal attempt provision in § 22A-301 shall not apply to this section if the actor does not actually possess an item with intent to use it to commit an offense under Chapter 2 or 3 of this title.
First degree possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree possession of a dangerous weapon with intent to commit a crime is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm;
In furtherance of and while committing what, in fact, is an offense under Chapter 2 of this title.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime when the actor:
Knowingly possesses:
An imitation firearm; or
A dangerous weapon;
In furtherance of and while committing what, in fact, is an offense under Chapter 2 of this title.
First degree possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree possession of a dangerous weapon during a crime is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm; and
Has a prior conviction for what is, in fact, a crime of violence other than conspiracy, or a comparable offense.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm; and
In addition:
Is a fugitive from justice;
Has a prior conviction for what is, in fact:
A District offense that is currently punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year, or a comparable offense, committed within 10 years of the current possession of a firearm;
An offense under this subchapter, or a comparable offense, committed within 5 years of the current possession of a firearm; or

An intrafamily offense, as that term is defined in § 16-1001(8), that requires as an element confinement, a sexual act, sexual contact, bodily injury, or threats, or a comparable offense, committed within 5 years of the current possession of a firearm; or
Is subject to a final civil protection order issued under § 16-1005 or a final anti-stalking order issued under § 16-1064.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section for, in fact, possessing a firearm within the first 24 hours of the prior conviction or service of the protection order, or, when the judicial officer sentencing the actor or issuing the protection order specifically orders a shorter period of time for the actor to retrieve and safely transport the firearm or relinquish ownership, within the time specified by the judicial officer.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the item while, in fact, voluntarily surrendering the item pursuant to District or federal law.
First degree possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person is a Class 8 felony.
Second degree possession of a firearm by an unauthorized person is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "fugitive from justice" means a person who has an open arrest warrant for:
Fleeing to avoid prosecution for a crime;
Fleeing to avoid giving testimony in a criminal proceeding; or
Escape from a correctional facility or officer under § 22A-4401.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits negligent discharge of a firearm when the actor:
Negligently discharges a projectile from a firearm outside a licensed firing range; and
In fact, does not have:
A written permit issued by the Metropolitan Police Department; or
Other permission under District or federal law.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Negligent discharge of a firearm is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Alteration of a firearm identification mark.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits alteration of a firearm identification mark when the actor:
Knowingly alters or removes from a firearm:
The name of the maker;
The model;
The manufacturer's number; or
Other identifying mark;
With intent to conceal or misrepresent the identity of the firearm.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Alteration of a firearm identification mark is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "manufacturer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 7-2505.03(2).

section.heading: Civil provisions for prohibitions of firearms on public or private property.

para.text: The District may prohibit or restrict the possession of firearms on its property and any property under its control.

Private persons or entities owning property in the District may prohibit or restrict the possession of firearms on their property by any person other than a law enforcement officer while that law enforcement officer is lawfully authorized to enter onto the private property.

section.heading: Civil provisions for lawful transportation of a firearm or ammunition.

para.text: Notwithstanding any other District law, a person shall be permitted to transport a firearm or ammunition under the following circumstances:
The person is not otherwise prohibited by law from possessing a firearm or ammunition;
The transportation of the firearm or ammunition is:
For any lawful purpose;
From any place where the person may lawfully possess the firearm or ammunition; and
To any place where the person may lawfully possess the firearm or ammunition;
When the firearm is transported in a motor vehicle, the firearm is unloaded, and:

If the motor vehicle has a compartment separate from the passenger area, neither the firearm nor any ammunition is conveniently accessible and within reach from the passenger area of the motor vehicle; or
If the motor vehicle does not have a compartment separate from the passenger area, the firearm and any ammunition is in a locked container other than the glove compartment or console; and
When the firearm is not transported in a motor vehicle, the firearm is:
Unloaded;
Inside a locked container; and
Separate from any ammunition.

section.heading: Civil provisions for issuance of a license to carry a pistol.

para.text: The Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department may, upon the application of a person having a bona fide residence or place of business within the District of Columbia, or of a person having a bona fide residence or place of business within the United States and a license to carry a pistol concealed upon their person issued by the lawful authorities of any state or subdivision of the United States, issue a license to such person to carry a pistol concealed upon their person within the District of Columbia for not more than 2 years from the date of issue, if it appears that the person is a suitable person to be so licensed.

A non-resident who lives in a state or subdivision of the United States that does not require a license to carry a concealed pistol may apply to the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department for a license to carry a pistol concealed upon their person within the District of Columbia for not more than 2 years from the date of issue; provided, that the person meets the same reasons and requirements set forth in subsection (a) of this section.

For any person issued a license pursuant to this section, or renewed pursuant to § 7-2509.03, the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department may limit the geographic area, circumstances, or times of the day, week, month, or year in which the license is effective, and may subsequently limit, suspend, or revoke the license as provided under § 7-2509.05.

The application for a license to carry shall be on a form prescribed by the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department and shall bear the name, address, description, photograph, and signature of the licensee.

Except as provided in § 7-2509.05(b), any person whose application has been denied or whose license has been limited or revoked may, within 15 days after the date of the notice of denial or notice of intent, appeal to the Concealed Pistol Licensing Review Board established pursuant to § 7-2509.08.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful sale of a pistol when the actor:
Knowingly sells a pistol;
Reckless as to the fact that the purchaser is:
Not of sound mind;
Prohibited from possessing a firearm by § 22A-5107; or
Under 21 years of age, except when the purchaser is a child or ward of the actor.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful sale of a pistol is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful transfer of a firearm when the actor:
Knowingly, as the seller of a firearm, delivers the firearm to a purchaser:
Fewer than 10 days after the date of the purchase, except in the case of sales to law enforcement officers; or
In a manner other than as specified in § 22A-5111;

Knowingly, as the purchaser of a firearm, fails to sign in duplicate and deliver to the seller a statement containing the purchaser's full name, address, occupation, date and place of birth, the date of purchase, the caliber, make, model, and manufacturer's number of the firearm and a statement that the purchaser is not prohibited from possessing a firearm under § 22A-5107;

Knowingly, as the seller of a firearm, fails to sign and attach their address to the purchaser's statement described in subsection (a)(2) of this section and deliver one copy to such person or persons as the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department may designate, and retain the other copy for 6 years; or
Knowingly sells an assault weapon, machine gun, or sawed-off shotgun:
To any person other than the persons designated in § 22A-5102(b) as entitled to possess the same; or
Without prior permission to make such sale obtained from the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is a wholesale dealer selling a firearm to a dealer licensed under § 22A-5116.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful transfer of a firearm is a Class 9 felony.

section.heading: Sale of a firearm without a license.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits sale of a firearm without a license when the actor knowingly:
As a retail dealer:
Sells, exposes for sale, or possesses with intent to sell, a firearm;
Without a license under § 22A-5116; or
As a wholesale dealer, sells, or possesses with intent to sell, a firearm to any person other than a dealer licensed under § 22A-5116.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful sale of a firearm without a license is a Class 9 felony.

section.heading: Civil provisions for licenses of firearms dealers.

para.text: The Mayor of the District of Columbia may, in their discretion, grant licenses and may prescribe the form thereof, effective for not more than one year after the date of issue, permitting the licensee to sell a firearm at retail within the District of Columbia. Any license issued under this section shall require the licensee to follow the licensure requirements described in subsection (b) of this section.
Firearm sales shall occur only in the building designated in the license.
The license or a copy thereof, certified by the issuing authority, shall be clearly and conspicuously displayed on the premises.
No firearm shall be sold if the purchaser is:
Not of sound mind;
Prohibited from possessing a firearm under § 22A-5107;
Under 21 years of age; or
Unknown to the seller, unless the purchaser presents clear evidence of the purchaser's identity.

No assault weapon, machine gun, or sawed-off shotgun shall be sold to any person other than the persons specified in § 22A-5102(b) as entitled to possess the same, and then only after permission to make such sale has been obtained from the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department.

A true record shall be made of all firearms in the possession of the licensee, in a form prescribed by the Mayor. The record shall contain the date of purchase, the caliber, make, model, and manufacturer's number of each weapon, to which shall be added, when sold, the date of sale.

A true record in duplicate shall be made of every firearm sold, in a form prescribed by the Mayor. The record shall be personally signed by the purchaser and by the person effecting the sale, each in the presence of the other, and shall contain the date of sale; the name, address, occupation, and place of birth of the purchaser; so far as applicable, the caliber, make, model, and manufacturer's number of the weapon; and a statement by the purchaser that the purchaser is not a person prohibited from possessing a firearm under § 22A-5107. A copy of the record shall, within 7 days after the sale, be forwarded by mail to the Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department and the other copy retained by the seller for 6 years after the sale.

No firearm or imitation firearm or placard advertising the sale of a firearm or imitation firearm shall be clearly and conspicuously displayed on the premises, where it can readily be seen from outside.
Any license shall be subject to forfeiture for any violation of the requirements specified in subsection (b) of this section.

Any license issued under this section shall be issued by the Metropolitan Police Department as a Public Safety endorsement to a basic business license under the basic business license system as set forth in Subchapter I-A of Chapter 28 of Title 47.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "manufacturer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 7-2505.03(2).

section.heading: Unlawful sale of a firearm by a licensed dealer.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful sale of a firearm by a licensed dealer when the actor:
In fact, is a licensed dealer under § 22A-5116; and
Recklessly violates a licensure requirement specified in § 22A-5116(b).

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful sale of a firearm by a licensed dealer is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Use of false information for purchase or licensure of a firearm.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits use of false information for purchase or licensure of a firearm when the actor knowingly gives false information or false evidence of identity to:
Purchase a firearm; or
Apply for a license to carry a pistol under § 22A-5112.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Use of false information for purchase or licensure of a firearm is a Class A misdemeanor.

section.heading: Civil provisions for the taking and destruction of dangerous articles.

para.text: A dangerous article unlawfully owned, possessed, or carried is hereby declared to be a nuisance.

When a police officer, in the course of a lawful arrest or lawful search, or when a designated civilian employee of the Metropolitan Police Department in the course of a lawful search, discovers a dangerous article that the officer reasonably believes is a nuisance under subsection (a) of this section the officer shall take it into their possession and surrender it to the Property Clerk of the Metropolitan Police Department.

Within 30 days after the date of such surrender, any person may file in the office of the Property Clerk of the Metropolitan Police Department a written claim for possession of such dangerous article. Upon the expiration of the period, the Property Clerk shall notify each claimant, by registered mail addressed to the address shown on the claim, of the time and place of a hearing to determine which claimant, if any, is entitled to possession of such dangerous article. The hearing shall be held within 60 days after the date of such surrender.

At the hearing, the Property Clerk shall hear and receive evidence with respect to the claims filed under paragraph (1) of this subsection. Thereafter the Property Clerk shall determine which claimant, if any, is entitled to possession of such dangerous article and shall reduce their decision to writing. The Property Clerk shall send a true copy of the written decision to each claimant by registered mail addressed to the most recent address of the claimant.

Any claimant may, within 30 days after the day on which the copy of the decision was mailed to such claimant, file an appeal in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. If the claimant files an appeal, the claimant shall at the same time give written notice thereof to the Property Clerk. If the decision of the Property Clerk is so appealed, the Property Clerk shall not dispose of the dangerous article while the appeal is pending and, if the final judgment is entered by the court, the Property Clerk shall dispose of the dangerous article in accordance with the judgment of the court. The court is authorized to determine which claimant, if any, is entitled to possession of the dangerous article and to enter a judgment ordering a disposition of the dangerous article consistent with subsection (e) of this section.
If there is no appeal, or if the appeal is dismissed or withdrawn, the Property Clerk shall dispose of the dangerous article in accordance with subsection (e) of this section.

The Property Clerk shall make no disposition of a dangerous article under this section, whether in accordance with their own decision or in accordance with the judgment of the court, until the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia or the Attorney General for the District of Columbia certifies to the Property Clerk that the dangerous article will not be needed as evidence.
A person claiming a dangerous article shall be entitled to its possession only if:
The claimant shows, on satisfactory evidence that the ownership is lawful and:
The person is the owner of the dangerous article; or
The person is the accredited representative of the owner and has a power of attorney from the owner;

The claimant shows, on satisfactory evidence, that at the time the dangerous article was taken into possession by a police officer or a designated civilian employee of the Metropolitan Police Department, it was not unlawfully owned and was not unlawfully possessed or carried by the claimant or with their awareness or consent; and
The receipt of possession by the claimant does not cause the article to be a nuisance.

If a person claiming a dangerous article is entitled to its possession as determined under subsections (c) and (d) of this section, possession of such dangerous article shall be given to the claimant. If no person so claiming is entitled to its possession as determined under subsections (c) and (d) of this section, or if there is no claimant, the dangerous article shall be destroyed or, upon order of the Mayor of the District of Columbia, transferred to and used by any federal or District government law enforcement agency. A District government agency receiving a dangerous article under this section shall establish responsibility and records for the item.
The Property Clerk shall not be liable in damages for any action performed in good faith under this section.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "dangerous article" means:
A bump stock;
A firearm;
A firearm silencer;
A large capacity ammunition feeding device; or
A restricted explosive.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits endangerment with a firearm when the actor:
Knowingly discharges a projectile from a firearm outside a licensed firing range; and
Either:
The discharged projectile creates a substantial risk of death or bodily injury to another person; or
In fact:
The actor or the discharged projectile is in a location that is:
Open to the general public at the time of the offense;
A communal area of multi-unit housing; or
Inside a public conveyance or a rail station; and
The actor does not have permission to discharge a projectile from a firearm under:
A written permit issued by the Metropolitan Police Department; or
Other District or federal law.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Endangerment with a firearm is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Multiple convictions for related offenses.
para.text: A conviction for an offense under this section and a conviction for another offense that has as an objective element in the offense definition or applicable penalty enhancement the use or display, or attempted use or display, of a firearm, imitation firearm, or dangerous weapon shall merge when the convictions arise from the same act or course of conduct and the same complainant.

para.heading: Merger procedure and rule of priority.
para.text: For an actor found guilty of 2 or more offenses that merge under this section, the sentencing court shall follow the procedures specified in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits disorderly conduct when the actor:
In fact, is in a location that is:
Open to the general public at the time of the offense;
Inside a public conveyance or a rail transit station; or
A communal area of multi-unit housing; and
Engages in any of the following conduct:
Recklessly, by conduct other than speech, causes any person present to reasonably believe that they are likely to suffer immediate criminal bodily injury, taking of property, or damage to property;

Purposely commands, requests, or tries to persuade any person present to cause immediate criminal bodily injury, taking of property, or damage to property, reckless as to the fact that the harm is likely to occur;

Purposely directs abusive speech to any person present, reckless as to the fact that such conduct is likely to provoke immediate retaliatory criminal bodily injury, taking of property, or damage to property; or
Knowingly continues or resumes fighting with another person after receiving a law enforcement officer's order to stop.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(2)(A) of this section when, in fact, the other person present is a law enforcement officer in the course of official duties.

An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a)(2)(C) of this section when, in fact, the conduct is directed to or likely to provoke a law enforcement officer in the course of official duties.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Disorderly conduct is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree public nuisance when the actor purposely causes significant interruption to:
The orderly conduct of a meeting by a District or federal public body;
A person's reasonable, quiet enjoyment of their dwelling, between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and continues or resumes the conduct after receiving oral or written notice to stop;
A person's lawful use of a public conveyance; or
A religious service, funeral, or wedding, that is, in fact, lawful and in a location that is open to the general public at the time of the offense.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree public nuisance when the actor:
Knowingly makes an unreasonably loud noise between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.;
That is likely to annoy or disturb one or more other persons in their residences.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.
First degree public nuisance is a Class D misdemeanor.
Second degree public nuisance is a Class E misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the terms "meeting" and "public body" shall have the same meanings as provided in § 2-574(1) and (3), respectively.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits blocking a public way when the actor:
Knowingly blocks a street, sidewalk, bridge, path, entrance, exit, or passageway;
While on land or inside a building that is owned by a government, government agency, or government-owned corporation; and
Continues or resumes the blocking after receiving a law enforcement officer's order that, in fact, is lawful, to stop.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Blocking a public way is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful demonstration when the actor:
Knowingly engages in a demonstration;
In a location where the demonstration, in fact, is otherwise unlawful under District or federal law; and
Continues or resumes engaging in the demonstration after receiving a law enforcement order to stop.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Unlawful demonstration is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits breach of home privacy when the actor:
Knowingly and surreptitiously observes inside a dwelling, by any means; and
In fact, an occupant of the dwelling would have a reasonable expectation of privacy.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Breach of home privacy is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree indecent exposure when the actor:
Knowingly engages in:
A sexual act;
Masturbation; or
A sexual or sexualized display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering; and
The conduct is:
Visible to the complainant;
Without the complainant's effective consent; and
With the purpose of alarming or sexually abusing, humiliating, harassing, or degrading the complainant.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree indecent exposure when the actor:
Knowingly engages in:
A sexual act;
Masturbation; or
A display of the genitals, pubic area, or anus, when there is less than a full opaque covering;
In, or visible from, a location that is:
Open to the general public at the time of the offense;
Inside a public conveyance or a rail transit station; or
A communal area of multi-unit housing; and
Reckless as to the fact that the conduct:
Is visible to the complainant;
Is without the complainant's effective consent; and
Alarms or sexually abuses, humiliates, harasses, or degrades any person.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a) of this section when, in fact:
The actor is inside their own individual dwelling unit; and
The conduct is not visible to any person outside the dwelling.
An actor shall not be subject to prosecution under this section when, in fact, the actor is:
An employee of a licensed sexually-oriented business establishment; and
Acting within the reasonable scope of that role.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of subsection (b) of this section.
First degree indecent exposure is a Class B misdemeanor.
Second degree indecent exposure is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "sexually-oriented business establishment" shall have the same meaning as provided in 11 DCMR § 199.1.

para.heading: Offense
para.text: : An actor commits public urination or defecation when the actor knowingly urinates or defecates in a public place, other than a urinal or toilet.

para.heading: Penalty.
para.text: Public urination or defecation is a Class E misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits failure to disperse when the actor:
Knowingly fails to obey a law enforcement officer's dispersal order;

Reckless as to the fact that 8 or more people are each personally and simultaneously committing or attempting to commit a criminal bodily injury, taking of property, or damage to property, in the area reasonably perceptible to the actor; and
In fact, the actor's presence substantially impairs the ability of a law enforcement officer to safely prevent or stop the criminal conduct.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Failure to disperse is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits prostitution when the actor knowingly:
Pursuant to a prior agreement, explicit or implicit, engages in or submits to a sexual act or sexual contact in exchange for the actor or a third party receiving anything of value;
Agrees, explicitly or implicitly, to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact in exchange for the actor or a third party receiving anything of value; or
Commands, requests, or tries to persuade any person to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact in exchange for the actor or a third party receiving anything of value.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor is under 18 years of age.

The Metropolitan Police Department and any other District agency designated by the Mayor shall refer any person under 18 years of age that is suspected of violating subsection (a) of this section to an organization that provides treatment, housing, or services appropriate for victims of sex trafficking of a minor under § 22A-2605.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Prostitution is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Judicial deferral and dismissal of proceedings.

para.text: When a person is found guilty of prostitution under this section, the court may, without entering a judgment of guilty and with the consent of the person, defer further proceedings on that offense and place the person on probation upon such reasonable conditions as it may require and for such period, not to exceed one year, as the court may prescribe. Upon violation of a condition of the probation, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed as otherwise provided. The court may, in its discretion, dismiss the proceedings against such person and discharge the person from probation before the expiration of the maximum period prescribed for such person's probation. If during the period of probation the person does not violate any of the conditions of the probation, then upon expiration of such period the court shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceedings against the person. Discharge and dismissal under this subsection shall be without court adjudication of guilt. Such discharge or dismissal shall not be deemed a conviction with respect to disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a crime or for any other reason.

Upon the dismissal of such proceedings and discharge of the person under paragraph (1) of this subsection, such person may apply to the court for an order to expunge from all official records (other than the nonpublic records to be retained under paragraph (1) of this subsection) all recordation relating to their arrest, indictment or information, trial, finding of guilty, and dismissal and discharge pursuant to this subsection. If the court determines, after hearing, that the proceedings were dismissed and the person discharged, it shall enter such order. The effect of such order shall be to restore such person, in the contemplation of this law, to the status they occupied before such arrest or indictment or information. No person as to whom such order has been entered shall be held thereafter under any provision of any law to be guilty of perjury or otherwise giving a false statement by reason of failure to recite or acknowledge such arrest, or indictment, or trial in response to any inquiry made of them for any purpose.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits patronizing prostitution when the actor knowingly:
Pursuant to a prior agreement, explicit or implicit, engages in or submits to a sexual act or sexual contact in exchange for the actor giving another person anything of value;
Agrees, explicitly or implicitly, to give anything of value to another person in exchange for that person or a third party engaging in or submitting to a sexual act or sexual contact; or
Commands, requests, or tries to persuade any person to engage in or submit to a sexual act or sexual contact in exchange for the actor giving another person anything of value.
Patronizing prostitution is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that the person patronized is under 18 years of age, or, in fact, the person patronized is under 12 years of age; or
Is reckless as to the fact that the person patronized is:

Incapable of appraising the nature of the sexual act or sexual contact or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the sexual act or sexual contact, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness; or
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the sexual act or sexual contact.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits trafficking in commercial sex when the actor:
With intent to receive anything of value as a result, purposely:
Causes, procures, provides, recruits, or entices a person to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person; or
Provides or maintains a location for a person to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person;
Knowingly receives anything of value as a result of:
Causing, procuring, providing, recruiting, or enticing a person to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person; or
Providing or maintaining a location for a person to engage in or submit to a commercial sex act with or for another person; or

Obtains anything of value from the proceeds or earnings of a commercial sex act that a person has engaged in or submitted to, either without consideration or when the consideration is providing or maintaining a location for a commercial sex act.
Trafficking in commercial sex is a Class 9 felony.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of this offense shall be increased by one class when the actor:
Is reckless as to the fact that the person trafficked is under 18 years of age, or, in fact, the person trafficked is under 12 years of age; or
Is reckless as to the fact that the person trafficked is:

Incapable of appraising the nature of the commercial sex act or of understanding the right to give or withhold consent to the commercial sex act, either due to a drug, intoxicant, or other substance, or, due to an intellectual, developmental, or mental disability or mental illness when the actor has no similarly serious disability or illness; or
Incapable of communicating willingness or unwillingness to engage in the commercial sex act.

para.heading: Property subject to forfeiture.
para.text: The following are subject to civil forfeiture:

In fact, all conveyances, including aircraft, vehicles, or vessels, which are possessed with intent to be used, or are, in fact, used, to facilitate the commission of trafficking in commercial sex under § 22A-5403; and
In fact, all money, coins, and currency which are possessed with intent to be used, or are, in fact, used, to facilitate the commission of trafficking in commercial sex under § 22A-5403.

para.heading: Requirements for forfeiture.
para.text: All seizures and forfeitures under this section shall be pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 3 of Title 41.
[Reserved].

section.heading: Contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits contributing to the delinquency of a minor when the actor:
In fact, is 18 years of age or older and at least 4 years older than the complainant;
Is reckless as to the fact that the complainant is under 18 years of age; and
In fact, either:
Is an accomplice to the complainant under § 22A-210 for any District offense, a violation of § 25-1002, or a comparable offense or comparable violation; or
Engages in criminal solicitation of the complainant under § 22A-302 for any District offense, a violation of § 25-1002, or a comparable offense or comparable violation.

An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, during a demonstration, the complainant's conduct constitutes, or, if carried out, would constitute, a trespass under § 22A-2601, a public nuisance under § 22A-5202, blocking a public way under § 22A-5203, an unlawful demonstration under § 22A-5204, an attempt to commit any such an offense, or a comparable offense.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the requirements specified under § 7-403.

para.heading: Relationship to minor's conduct.
para.text: An actor may be convicted of an offense under this section even though the complainant has been acquitted, or has not been arrested, prosecuted, convicted, or adjudicated delinquent.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor engages in the conduct constituting the offense:
With intent to safeguard or promote the welfare of the complainant; and
In fact, such conduct:
Is reasonable in manner and degree, under all the circumstances; and
Does not create a substantial risk of, or cause, death or serious bodily injury.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Contributing to the delinquency of a minor is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits bigamy when the actor knowingly misrepresents the existence or status of a previous marriage or domestic partnership on a District of Columbia:
Marriage license application; or
Domestic partnership declaration.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when the actor, in fact, for 5 successive years or more immediately prior to the application or declaration, both:
Has had no contact with the spouse or domestic partner; and
Is not aware that the spouse or domestic partner is living.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor reasonably believes that the spouse or domestic partner is deceased.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Bigamy is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Merger.
para.text: A conviction for an offense under this section and a conviction for false statements under § 22A-4207 shall merge when the convictions arise from the same act or course of conduct and the same complainant. The sentencing court shall follow the procedures in § 22A-212(b) and (c).

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits promoting gambling when the actor:
Knowingly:
Induces or tries to induce another person to engage in any gambling activity; or
Installs or operates a game of skill machine at any location reckless as to the fact that such installation or operation violates subchapter III of Chapter 6 in Title 36;
With intent that the actor or another person receive financial gain other than personal gambling winnings; and
In fact, the actor is not engaging in conduct:
Solely as a player; or
Authorized by a District law, regulation, rule, or license.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: It is an exclusion from liability under this section that the gambling activity in question was, in fact, social gambling.

para.heading: Forfeiture.
para.text: Upon conviction under this section, the court may, in addition to the penalties provided by this section, order the forfeiture and destruction or other disposition of any equipment or money used, or attempted to be used, in violation of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Promoting gambling is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Game of skill machine" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 36-641.01.
"Player" means a person engaged in gambling activity solely as a contestant or bettor.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree rigging a publicly exhibited contest when the actor:
Knowingly:
Offers or gives anything of value to any person;
Demands or requests anything of value from any person; or
Makes an explicit or implicit coercive threat to any person;
With the purpose of causing a contest participant or contest official in a publicly exhibited contest to agree to engage in conduct that affects:
The course or outcome of the publicly exhibited contest; and
The outcome of any wager or bet on the publicly exhibited contest.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree rigging a publicly exhibited contest when the actor:
Knowingly agrees to accept anything of value from another person;
In exchange for the actor or another person engaging in conduct as a contest participant or contest official in a publicly exhibited contest that affects:
The course or outcome of the publicly exhibited contest; and
The outcome of any wager or bet on the publicly exhibited contest.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor engages in the conduct constituting the offense with the purpose of encouraging a contest participant or contest official to perform with a higher degree of skill, ability, or diligence in the publicly exhibited contest.
First degree rigging a publicly exhibited contest is a Class 9 felony.
Second degree rigging a publicly exhibited contest is a Class A misdemeanor.

Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to prohibit participation in, or operation, advertisement, or promotion of any gambling activity that is authorized by District law, regulation, rule, or license and regulated, licensed, or operated by the Office of Lottery and Gaming.

Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to prohibit advertising a lottery by the Maryland State Lottery so long as Maryland does not prohibit advertising or otherwise publishing an account of a lottery by the District of Columbia.

container.heading: ADDITIONAL REVISED CRIMINAL OFFENSES AND PROVISIONS.

section.text: The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975, effective September 24, 1976 (D.C. Law 1-85; D.C. Official Code § 7-2501.01 et seq.), is amended as follows:

para.text: Section 201 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2502.01) is amended as follows:
The section heading is amended to read as follows:

Subsection (a) is amended by striking the phrase "Except as otherwise provided in this act, no person or organization in the District of Columbia ("District") shall receive, possess, control, transfer, offer for sale, sell, give, or deliver any destructive device, and no person or organization in the District shall possess or control any firearm, unless the person or organization holds a valid registration certificate for the firearm. A registration" and inserting the phrase "A registration" in its place.
Subsection (b) is repealed.
Subsection (c) is repealed.
A new section 201a is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition when the actor knowingly possesses:
A destructive device;
One or more restricted pistol bullets; or
A firearm without, in fact, being the holder of a registration certificate issued under section 207 for that firearm.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition when the actor knowingly possesses ammunition without, in fact, being the holder of a registration certificate issued under section 207 for a firearm of the same caliber.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a) of this section for, in fact, possessing a firearm frame, receiver, muffler, or silencer.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a) of this section for, in fact, possessing a lacrimator or sternutator.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a) of this section when, in fact, the actor is a nonresident of the District of Columbia who is:
Participating in a lawful recreational firearm-related activity inside the District; or
Traveling to or from a lawful recreational firearm-related activity outside the District and:
Is transporting the firearm in accordance with the requirements specified in D.C. Official Code § 22A-5111; and
Upon demand of a law enforcement officer, the actor exhibits proof that:
The actor is traveling to or from a lawful recreational firearm-related activity outside the District; and
The actor's possession or control of the firearm is lawful in the actor's jurisdiction of residence.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (b) of this section when, in fact, the actor is the holder of an ammunition collector's certificate effective on or before September 24, 1976.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (b) this section for, in fact, possessing one or more empty cartridge cases, shells, or spent bullets.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in D.C. Official Code § 22A-5102.
