para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that the actor possesses the item while, in fact, voluntarily surrendering the item pursuant to District or federal law.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.
First degree possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition is a Class A misdemeanor.
Second degree possession of an unregistered firearm, destructive device, or ammunition is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Administrative disposition.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia may, in its discretion, offer an administrative disposition under Subtitle A of Title III of the First Amendment Assembly Enforcement and Procedure Act of 2004, effective April 13, 2005 (D.C. Law 15-352; D.C. Official Code § 5-335.01 et seq.), for a violation of this section.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.
Section 212 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2502.12) is repealed.
Section 213 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2502.13) is repealed.
Section 215 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2502.15) is amended to read as follows:

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits possession of a stun gun when the actor knowingly possesses a stun gun and:
Is under 18 years of age; or
Is in a location that:
Is a building, building grounds, or part of a building, that is occupied by the District of Columbia;
Is a building, building grounds, or part of a building, that is occupied by a preschool, a primary or secondary school, public recreation center, or a children's day care center; or
Displays clear and conspicuous signage indicating that stun guns are prohibited.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in D.C. Official Code § 22A-5102.

para.heading: Affirmative defense.
para.text: It is an affirmative defense to liability under this section that, in fact:
A person lawfully in charge of the location gave effective consent to the conduct charged to constitute the offense; or
The actor reasonably believes that a person lawfully in charge of the location gave effective consent to the conduct charged to constitute the offense.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Possession of a stun gun is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.
A new section 217 is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Carrying an air or spring gun.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits carrying an air or spring gun when the actor:
Knowingly possesses any instrument or weapon of the kind commonly called an air rifle, air gun, air pistol, B-B gun, spring gun, blowgun, or bowgun;
While outside a building; and
The instrument or weapon is conveniently accessible and within reach.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section if, in fact, the conduct occurs:
As part of a lawful theatrical performance, athletic contest, or educational or cultural presentation;
In a licensed firing range; or
With the permission of the Metropolitan Police Department.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section if, in fact, the actor:
Is 18 years of age or older; and
Transports the instrument or weapon while it is unloaded and securely wrapped.
An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in D.C. Official Code § 22A-5102.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Carrying an air or spring gun is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.
Section 601 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2506.01) is repealed.
Section 702 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2507.02) is amended to read as follows:

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits unlawful storage of a firearm when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a firearm that is:
Not conveniently accessible and within reach;
Not in a securely locked container; and
Not in another location that, in fact, a reasonable person would believe to be secure; and
Is negligent as to the fact that:
A person other than the actor who is under 18 years of age is able to access the firearm without the permission of their parent or guardian; or
A person other than the actor who is prohibited from possessing a firearm under District law is able to access the firearm.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.
Unlawful storage of a firearm is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalty enhancements.
para.text: The penalty classification of unlawful storage of a firearm shall be increased by one class when, in fact, a person under 18 years of age accesses and uses the firearm to cause either:
A criminal bodily injury; or
A bodily injury to themselves.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.
Section 706 (D.C. Official Code § 7-2507.06) is amended to read as follows:

Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this act shall be fined no more than the amount set forth in section 101 of the Criminal Fine Proportionality Amendment Act of 2012, effective June 11, 2013 (D.C. Law 19-317; D.C. Official Code § 22-3571.01), or incarcerated for no more than one year, or both, except as provided in:
Subsection (b) of this section;
Section 201a;
Section 205;
Section 208;
Section 215;
Section 217;
Section 301;
Section 702;
Section 807;
Title IX; and
Section 1011.

A person who knowingly or intentionally sells, transfers, or distributes a firearm, destructive device, or ammunition to a person under 18 years of age shall be fined no more than the amount set forth in section 101 of the Criminal Fine Proportionality Amendment Act of 2012, effective June 11, 2013 (D.C. Law 19-317; D.C. Official Code § 22-3571.01), or incarcerated for no more than 10 years, or both.
A new section 906a is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Carrying a pistol in an unlawful manner.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits carrying a pistol in an unlawful manner when the actor:
Knowingly possesses a pistol;
While outside the actor's home or place of business;
The pistol is conveniently accessible and within reach; and
In addition:
The actor possesses ammunition that is conveniently accessible and within reach and is either:
More than is required to fully load the pistol twice; or
More than 20 rounds;
The pistol is not entirely hidden from public view; or
The pistol is not in a holster on the actor's person in a firmly secure manner that is reasonably designed to prevent loss, theft, and accidental discharge of the pistol.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact, the actor satisfies the criteria in D.C. Official Code § 22A-5102.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Carrying a pistol in an unlawful manner is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.

section.text: Title 16 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

para.text: Section 16-705 is amended to read as follows:
A trial in a criminal case in Superior Court shall be by jury when:
According to the Constitution of the United States, the defendant is entitled to a jury trial; or
The defendant is charged with:
An offense which is punishable by a fine or penalty of more than $1,000 or by imprisonment for more than 180 days (or for more than 6 months, in the case of the offense of contempt of court);
Trespass under § 22A-3701 or attempted trespass, where the trespass is to public property;
Two or more offenses which are punishable by a cumulative fine or penalty of more than $4,000 or a cumulative term of imprisonment of more than 2 years; or
One of the following offenses, when the person who is alleged to have been subjected to the offense is a law enforcement officer, as that term is defined in § 22A-101 or former § 22-405(a):
Assault under § 22A-2203 or former § 22-404(a)(1);
Resisting arrest or interfering with the arrest of another person under § 22A-4404 or former § 22-405.01;
Criminal threats under § 22A-2205 or former § 22-407; or
Offensive physical contact under § 22A-2206.

In addition to the circumstances described in subsection (a) of this section, beginning 2 years after the applicability date of the Revised Criminal Code Reform Act of 2022, passed on 2nd reading on November 15, 2022 (Enrolled version of Bill 24-416), a trial in a criminal case in Superior Court shall be by jury when:
The defendant is charged with:
An offense that is punishable by a fine of more than $1,000 or imprisonment for more than 60 days;
A lifetime registration offense or registration offense, as those terms are defined in § 22-4001; or
Two or more offenses which are punishable by a cumulative fine or penalty of more than $1,000 or a cumulative term of imprisonment of more than 60 days; or
The person who is alleged to have been subjected to an offense is a law enforcement officer, as that term is defined in § 22A-101 or former § 22-405(a).

In addition to the circumstances described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, beginning 4 years after the applicability date of the Revised Criminal Code Reform Act of 2022, passed on 2nd reading on November 15, 2022 (Enrolled version of Bill 24-416), a trial in a criminal case in Superior Court shall be by jury when the defendant is charged with:
An offense that is punishable by a fine of more than $500 or imprisonment for more than 10 days; or
Two or more offenses which are punishable by a cumulative fine or penalty of more than $500 or a cumulative term of imprisonment of more than 10 days.

In addition to the circumstances described in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section, beginning 5 years after the applicability date of the Revised Criminal Code Reform Act of 2022, passed on 2nd reading on November 15, 2022 (Enrolled version of Bill 24-416), a trial in a criminal case in Superior Court shall be by jury when the defendant is charged with:
An offense that is punishable by a fine of more than $250 or by any imprisonment;

An offense that, if the defendant were a non-citizen and were convicted of the offense, could result in the defendant's deportation from the United States under federal immigration law, or denial of naturalization under federal immigration law; or
Two or more offenses which are punishable by a cumulative fine of more than $250 or by any imprisonment.
A trial in a criminal case in Superior Court shall be by a single judge whose verdict shall have the same force and effect as that of a jury in any case:
Not specified in subsection (a), (b), (c), or (d) of this section; or

Specified in subsection (a), (b), (c), or (d) of this section, if the defendant, in open court, expressly waives trial by jury and requests trial by the court more than 10 days before the scheduled trial or, with the consent of the court, within 10 days of the scheduled trial.

If a defendant in a criminal case is charged with 2 or more offenses, and the offenses include at least one jury demandable offense and one non-jury demandable offense, the trial for all offenses charged against that defendant shall be by jury, unless the defendant, in open court, expressly waives trial by jury and requests trial by the court, in which case, the trial shall be by a single judge, whose verdict shall have the same force and effect as that of a jury.

The jury shall consist of 12 persons, unless the parties, with the approval of the court and in the manner provided by rules of the court, agree to a number less than 12. Even absent such agreement, if, due to extraordinary circumstances, the court finds it necessary to excuse a juror for just cause after the jury has retired to consider its verdict, in the discretion of the court, a valid verdict may be returned by the remaining 11 jurors.
A new section 16-1005a is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Criminal contempt for violation of a civil protection order.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits criminal contempt for violation of a civil protection order when the actor:
Knows they are subject to a protection order that, in fact:
Is one of the following:
A temporary civil protection order issued under § 16-1004;
A final civil protection order issued under § 16-1005; or
A valid foreign protection order;
Is in writing;
Advises the actor of the consequences for violating the order, including immediate arrest, the issuance of a warrant for the person's arrest, and the criminal penalties under this section; and
Is sufficiently clear and specific to serve as a guide for the actor's conduct; and
Knowingly fails to comply with the order.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a judicial officer gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Jurisdiction.
para.text: An oral or written statement made by an actor located outside the District of Columbia to a person located in the District of Columbia by means of telecommunication, mail, or any other method of communication shall be deemed to be made in the District of Columbia.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Criminal contempt for violation of a civil protection order is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Foreign protection order" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 16-1041(2).
"Judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 16-1001(10).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.
Section 16-1021 is amended as follows:
Paragraph (2) is repealed.
Paragraph (3) is amended to read as follows:

"Lawful custodian" means a person who is authorized to have custody under District law, or by an order of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia or a court of competent jurisdiction of any state, or a person designated by the lawful custodian temporarily to care for the child.
Section 16-1022 is amended to read as follows:

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits the offense of first degree parental kidnapping when the actor:
Commits fourth degree parental kidnapping;
Knowingly takes, conceals, or detains the child outside of the District for more than 24 hours; and
The child is, in fact, outside the custody of the lawful custodian for more than 30 days.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits the offense of second degree parental kidnapping when the actor:
Commits fourth degree parental kidnapping;
Knowingly takes, conceals, or detains the child outside of the District for more than 24 hours; and
Fails to release the child without injury in a safe place prior to arrest.

para.heading: Third degree.
para.text: An actor commits the offense of third degree parental kidnapping when the actor:
Commits fourth degree parental kidnapping; and
Knowingly takes, conceals, or detains the child outside of the District for more than 24 hours.

para.heading: Fourth degree.
para.text: An actor commits the offense of fourth degree parental kidnapping when the actor:
Knowingly takes, conceals, or detains a person who has another lawful custodian;
With intent to prevent a lawful custodian from exercising rights to custody of the person;
The person taken, concealed, or detained is, in fact, under 16 years of age; and
The actor is a relative of the complainant, or a person who believes they are acting pursuant to the direction of a relative of the complainant.

para.heading: Exclusion from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section when, in fact:
The actor is a parent who reasonably believes they are fleeing from imminent physical harm to the parent;
The actor has the effective consent of the other parent; or
The actor has intent to protect the child from imminent physical harm.
If a person engages in conduct constituting a violation of this section, the person may file a petition in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia that:
States that at the time the act was done, a failure to do the act would have resulted in a clear and present danger to the health, safety, or welfare of the child; and

Seeks to establish custody, to transfer custody, or to revise or to clarify the existing custody order; except that if the Superior Court of the District of Columbia does not have jurisdiction over the custody issue, the person shall seek to establish, transfer, revise, or clarify custody in a court of competent jurisdiction.

It is a defense to liability under this section that the actor filed a petition as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection within 5 business days of the action taken, and that the court finds that at the time the act was done, a failure to do the act would have resulted in a clear and present danger to the health, safety, or welfare of the child.

para.heading: Continuous offense.
para.text: The offense prohibited by this section is continuous in nature and continues for so long as the child is concealed, detained, or otherwise unlawfully physically removed from the lawful custodian.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.
First degree parental kidnapping is a Class A misdemeanor.
Second degree parental kidnapping is a Class B misdemeanor.
Third degree parental kidnapping is a Class D misdemeanor.
Fourth degree parental kidnapping is a Class E misdemeanor.

para.heading: Reimbursement of expenses.
para.text: Any expenses incurred by the District in returning the child shall be assessed by the court against any person convicted of the violation and reimbursed to the District. Those expenses reasonably incurred by the lawful custodian and child victim as a result of a violation of this section shall be assessed by the court against any person convicted of the violation and reimbursed to the lawful custodian.

para.heading: First and second degree parental kidnapping designated as felonies.
para.text: Notwithstanding the maximum authorized penalties, first and second degree parental kidnapping shall be deemed felonies under § 23-563.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.
Section 16-1023 is repealed.
A new section 16-1023a is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Protective custody and return of child.

para.text: A law enforcement officer may take a child into protective custody if it reasonably appears to the officer that any person is in violation of this subchapter and unlawfully will flee the District with the child.
A child who has been detained or concealed shall be returned by a law enforcement officer to the lawful custodian or placed in the custody of another entity authorized by law.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "law enforcement officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 22A-101.
Section 16-1024 is repealed.
Section 16-1025 is repealed.
Section 16-1026 is amended to read as follows:

section.heading: Expungement of parental kidnapping conviction.
section.text: Any parent convicted in the Superior Court of the District of Columbia of violating any provision of this subchapter with respect to their child may apply to the court for an order to expunge from all official records all records relating to the conviction at such time that the parent's youngest child has reached the age of 18 years; provided, that the parent has no more than one conviction for a violation of this subchapter at the time that the application for expungement is made. Any other person convicted of violating the provisions of this subchapter may apply to the court for an order to expunge all records relating to the conviction 5 years after the conviction, or at such time as the child has reached the age of 18 years, whichever shall later occur; provided, further that the person has no more than one conviction for violating any provision of this subchapter at the time that the application for expungement is made.
Title 23 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

para.text: Section 23-585(b) is repealed.
A new section 23-586 is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Failure to appear after release on citation or bench warrant bond.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree failure to appear after release on citation or bench warrant bond when the actor:
Knows that they are released on a condition to appear before a judicial officer on a specified date and time either:
By a citation that, in fact, is issued under § 23-584 for a felony; or
After knowingly posting a bond that is, in fact, for a bench warrant issued from the Superior Court of the District of Columbia in a felony case; and
Knowingly fails to appear or remain for the hearing.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree failure to appear after release on citation or bench warrant bond when the actor:
Knows that they are released on a condition to appear before a judicial officer on a specified date and time either:
By a citation that, in fact, is issued under § 23-584 for a felony or misdemeanor; or
After knowingly posting a bond that is, in fact, for a bench warrant issued from the Superior Court of the District of Columbia in a felony or misdemeanor case; and
Knowingly fails to appear or remain for the hearing.
It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a releasing official, prosecutor, or judicial officer gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.
It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor makes good faith, reasonable efforts to appear or remain for the hearing.
First degree failure to appear after release on citation or bench warrant bond is a Class B misdemeanor.
Second degree failure to appear after release on citation or bench warrant bond is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term:
"Judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-501(1).
"Releasing official" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1110(1).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.
Section 23-1327 is amended to read as follows:

section.heading: Failure to appear in violation of a court order.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree failure to appear in violation of a court order when the actor:
Knows that they are required to appear before a judicial officer on a specified date and time by a court order for what is, in fact, a hearing:
In a case in which the actor is charged with a felony; or
In which the actor is scheduled to be sentenced; and
Knowingly fails to appear or remain for the hearing.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree failure to appear in violation of a court order when the actor:
Knows that they are required to appear before a judicial officer on a specified date and time by a court order for what is, in fact, a hearing:
In a case in which the actor is charged with a felony or misdemeanor; or
In which the actor is scheduled to appear as a material witness in a criminal case; and
Knowingly fails to appear or remain for the hearing.
It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a judicial officer gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.
It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, the actor makes good faith, reasonable efforts to appear or remain for the hearing.
First degree failure to appear in violation of a court order is a Class A misdemeanor.
Second degree failure to appear in violation of a court order is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Forfeiture.
para.text: Upon conviction under this section, the court may, subject to the provisions of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, order the forfeiture of any security which was given or pledged for the actor's release.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1331(1).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.
Section 23-1329 is amended as follows:
Subsection (a-1) is repealed.
Subsection (c) is repealed.
A new section 23-1329a is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Criminal contempt for violation of a pretrial release condition.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits criminal contempt for violation of a pretrial release condition when the actor:
Knows they are subject to a conditional release order that, in fact:
Is issued under § 23-1321;
Is in writing;

Advises the actor of the consequences for violating the order, including immediate arrest or the issuance of a warrant for the actor's arrest, the criminal penalties under this section, the pretrial release penalty enhancements under § 22A-607, and the criminal penalties for obstruction of justice under § 22-722; and
Is sufficiently clear and specific to serve as a guide for the actor's conduct; and
Knowingly fails to comply with the conditional release order.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a judicial officer gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: A judicial officer or a prosecutor may initiate a proceeding for contempt under this section.

para.heading: Non-jury hearing.
para.text: A proceeding determining a violation of this section shall be by a single judge, whose verdict shall have the same force and effect as that of a jury.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Criminal contempt for violation of a pretrial release condition is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1331(1).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.
A new section 23-1329b is added to read as follows:

section.heading: Criminal contempt for violation of a post-conviction no contact order.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits criminal contempt for violation of a post-conviction no contact order when the actor:
Knows they are subject to a condition of release that, in fact:
Was issued as a release condition of supervised release, probation, or parole;
Requires that the actor stay away from, or have no contact with, specific individuals or locations;
Is in writing;
Advises the actor of the consequences for violating the order, including immediate arrest or the issuance of a warrant for the actor's arrest, and the criminal penalties under this section; and
Is sufficiently clear and specific to serve as a guide for the actor's conduct; and
Knowingly fails to comply with the post-conviction conditional release order.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a judicial officer gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: A judicial officer or a prosecutor may initiate a proceeding for contempt under this section.

para.heading: Non-jury hearing.
para.text: A proceeding determining a violation of this section shall be by a single judge, whose verdict shall have the same force and effect as that of a jury.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Criminal contempt for violation of a post-conviction no contact order is a Class B misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1331(1).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.

section.text: The District of Columbia Work Release Act, approved November 10, 1966 (80 Stat. 1519; D.C. Official Code § 24-241.01 et seq.), is amended as follows:

para.text: Section 6(b) (D.C. Official Code § 24-241.05(b)) is repealed.
A new section 6a is added to read as follows:

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits violation of work release when the actor:
In fact, is granted a work release privilege under section 3; and
Knowingly fails to return at the time and to the place of confinement designated in their work release plan.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that, in fact, a judicial officer, the Director of the Department of Corrections, or the Chairman of the United States Parole Commission gives effective consent to the conduct constituting the offense.

para.heading: Prosecutorial authority.
para.text: The Attorney General for the District of Columbia shall prosecute violations of this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Violation of work release is a Class C misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "judicial officer" shall have the same meaning as provided in D.C. Official Code § 23-1331(1).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.

section.text: An Act to Establish a Board of Indeterminate Sentence and Parole for the District of Columbia and to determine its functions, and for other purposes, approved July 15, 1932 (47 Stat. 697; D.C. Official Code § 24-403 et seq.), is amended as follows:

para.text: Section 3a (D.C. Official Code § 24-403.01) is amended to read as follows:

section.heading: Sentencing, supervised release, and good time credit for felonies committed on or after August 5, 2000.

para.text: For any felony committed on or after August 5, 2000, the court shall impose a sentence that:
Reflects the seriousness of the offense and the criminal history of the person found guilty;
Provides for just punishment and affords adequate deterrence to potential criminal conduct of the person found guilty and others; and
Provides the person found guilty with needed educational or vocational training, medical care, and other correctional treatment.

If a person found guilty is sentenced to imprisonment, or to commitment pursuant to section 4 of the Youth Rehabilitation Amendment Act of 1985, effective December 7, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-69; D.C. Official Code § 24-903), under this section, the court shall impose an adequate period of supervision ("supervised release") to follow release from the imprisonment or commitment.
If the court imposes a sentence of more than one year, the court shall impose a term of supervised release of:
Not more than 5 years, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is 24 years or more;
Not more than 3 years, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is 8 years or more, but less than 24 years; or
Not more than one year, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is less than 8 years.

In the case of a person sentenced for an offense for which registration is required by the Sex Offender Registration Act of 1999, effective July 11, 2000 (D.C. Law 13-137; D.C. Official Code § 22-4001 et seq.), the court may, in its discretion, impose a longer term of supervised release than that required or authorized by paragraph (2) of this subsection, of:
Not more than 10 years; or
Not more than life if the person is required to register for life.

The term of supervised release commences on the day the incarcerated person is released from imprisonment, and runs concurrently with any federal, state, or local term of probation, parole, or supervised release for another offense to which the person is subject or becomes subject during the term of supervised release. A term of supervised release does not run during any period in which the person is imprisoned in connection with a conviction for a federal, state, or local crime unless the period of imprisonment is less than 30 days.

Persons on supervised release shall be subject to the authority of the United States Parole Commission until completion of the term of supervised release. The Parole Commission shall have and exercise the same authority as is vested in the United States District Courts by 18 U.S.C. § 3583(d)-(i), except that:
The procedures followed by the Parole Commission in exercising such authority shall be those set forth in Chapter 311 of Title 18 of the United States Code; and
An extension of a term of supervised release under 18 U.S.C. § 3583(e)(2) may be ordered only by the court upon motion from the Parole Commission.
A person whose term of supervised release is revoked may be imprisoned for a period of:
Not more than 5 years, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is 40 years or more;
Not more than 3 years, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is 24 years or more, but less than 40 years;
Not more than 2 years, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is 8 years or more, but less than 24 years; or
Not more than one year, if the maximum term of imprisonment authorized for the offense is less than 8 years.

The maximum term of imprisonment authorized upon revocation of supervised release pursuant to subsection (b)(6) of this section shall not be deducted from the maximum term of imprisonment or commitment authorized for such offense.

Except as provided under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a sentence under this section of imprisonment, or of commitment pursuant to section 4 of the Youth Rehabilitation Amendment Act of 1985, effective December 7, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-69; D.C. Official Code § 24-903), shall be for a definite term, which shall not exceed the maximum term allowed by law or be less than any minimum term required by law.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, if the person committed the offense for which they are being sentenced under this section while under 18 years of age:
The court may issue a sentence less than the minimum term otherwise required by law; and
The court shall not impose a sentence of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole or release.

A person sentenced under this section to imprisonment, or to commitment pursuant to section 4 of the Youth Rehabilitation Amendment Act of 1985, effective December 7, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-69; D.C. Official Code § 24-903), shall serve the term of imprisonment or commitment specified in the sentence, less any time credited toward service of the sentence under subsection (f) of this section and subject to section 3c, if applicable.

Notwithstanding any other law, a person sentenced to imprisonment, or to commitment pursuant to section 4 of the Youth Rehabilitation Amendment Act of 1985, effective December 7, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-69; D.C. Official Code § 24-903), under this section for any offense may receive good time credit toward service of the sentence only as provided in 18 U.S.C. § 3624(b).

A person sentenced to imprisonment under this section for a nonviolent offense may receive up to a one-year reduction in the term the person must otherwise serve if the person successfully completes a substance abuse treatment program in accordance with 18 U.S.C. § 3621(e)(2).
For the purposes of this subsection, the term "nonviolent offense" means any crime other than those included within the definition of the term "crime of violence" in D.C. Official Code § 23-1331(4).
Section 3c (D.C. Official Code § 24-403.03) is amended as follows:
The section heading is amended by striking the phrase "imprisonment for violations of law committed before 25 years of age." and inserting the phrase "imprisonment." in its place.
Subsection (a) is amended to read as follows:
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the court shall reduce a term of imprisonment imposed upon a defendant for an offense if:
The defendant:

Was under 25 years of age at the time the offense was committed, was sentenced pursuant to section 3 or 3a or committed pursuant to section 4 of the Youth Rehabilitation Amendment Act of 1985, effective December 7, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-69; D.C. Official Code § 24-903), and has served at least 15 years in prison; or
Was 25 years of age or older at the time the offense was committed, was sentenced pursuant to section 3 or 3a, and has served at least 20 years in prison; and

The court finds, after considering the factors set forth in subsection (c) of this section, that the defendant is not a danger to the safety of any person or the community and that the interests of justice warrant a sentence modification.
Subsection (b) is amended as follows:
Paragraph (1) is amended by striking the phrase "offense committed before the defendant's 25th birthday may" and inserting the phrase "offense may" in its place.

Paragraph (3)(B) is amended by striking the phrase "after the defendant's 18th birthday but before the defendant's 25th birthday may" and inserting the phrase "after the defendant's 18th birthday may" in its place.
Subsection (g) is amended by striking the phrase "after the defendant's" and inserting the phrase "on or after the defendant's" in its place.

section.text: Section 25-1001 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended to read as follows:

section.heading: Possession of an open container of alcohol.

para.heading: First degree.
para.text: An actor commits first degree possession of an open container of alcohol when the actor:
Knowingly:
Consumes an alcoholic beverage; or
Possesses an alcoholic beverage in an open container;
In the passenger area of a motor vehicle on a public highway, or the right-of-way of a public highway.

para.heading: Second degree.
para.text: An actor commits second degree possession of an open container of alcohol when the actor:
Knowingly consumes an alcoholic beverage or possesses an alcoholic beverage in an open container in or upon any of the following places:
A street, alley, park, or sidewalk;
A vehicle in or upon any street, alley, or park;
A premises not licensed under this title where food or nonalcoholic beverages are sold or entertainment is provided for compensation;
Any place to which the public is invited and for which a license to sell alcoholic beverages has not been issued under this title;

Any place to which the public is invited for which a license to sell alcoholic beverages has been issued under this title at a time when the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises is prohibited by this title or by the regulations promulgated under this title; or
Any place licensed under a club license at a time when the consumption of the alcoholic beverages on the premises is prohibited by this title or by regulations promulgated under this title.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (a) of this section when, in fact, the actor is:
Located in:
The passenger area of a motor vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of persons for compensation; or
The living quarters of a house coach or house trailer; and
Not operating the motor vehicle.
An actor does not commit an offense under subsection (b) of this section when, in fact, the possession of the open container of alcohol occurs at an event licensed by the Board.

para.heading: No attempt liability.
para.text: The criminal attempt provision in § 22A-301 shall not apply to this section.
First degree possession of an open container of alcohol is a Class C misdemeanor.
Second degree possession of an open container of alcohol is a Class E misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "highway" shall have the same meaning as provided in section 3a(7) of the Anti-Drunk Driving Act of 1982, effective April 27, 2013 (D.C. Law 19-266; D.C. Official Code § 50-2206.01(7)).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: Chapter 1 of Title 22A shall apply to this offense.

section.text: Section 1 of An Act To establish a code of law for the District of Columbia, approved March 3, 1901 (31 Stat. 1189; D.C. Official Code § 45-401), is amended as follows:

para.text: Subsection (a) is amended by striking the phrase "some provision of the 1901 Code"
and inserting the phrase "some provision of the 1901 Code, or an Act of the Council" in its place.
Subsection (b) is amended to read as follows:

Common law offenses are abolished and no act or omission shall constitute an offense unless made so by an Act of Congress, an act of the Council, or the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations. This subsection shall not affect the power to punish for contempt, or to employ any sanction authorized by law for the enforcement of an order or a civil judgment or decree. This subsection shall not be construed to repeal any common law defenses or any legal precedent other than that which recognizes common law offenses.

section.text: The District of Columbia Uniform Controlled Substances Act of 1981, effective August 5, 1981 (D.C. Law 4-29; D.C. Official Code § 48-901.01 et seq.), is amended by adding new sections 412, 413, and 414 to read as follows:

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits possession of drug manufacturing paraphernalia when the actor knowingly possesses an object with intent to use the object to manufacture a controlled substance.

para.heading: Exclusions from liability.
para.text: An actor does not commit an offense under this section:
If the object possessed is, in fact, 50 years of age or older;
If the actor possesses an object with intent solely to use the object to package or repackage a controlled substance for the actor's own use; or

If the actor, in fact, satisfies the requirements specified under section 3 of An Act To relieve physicians of liability for negligent medical treatment at the scene of an accident in the District of Columbia, effective March 19, 2013 (D.C. Law 19-243; D.C. Official Code § 7-403).

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Possession of drug manufacturing paraphernalia is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: The general provisions of Chapter 1of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits trafficking of drug paraphernalia when the actor:
Knowingly sells or delivers, or possesses with intent to sell or deliver, an object;
With intent that another person will use the object to introduce into the human body, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, store, conceal, manufacture, or measure a controlled substance.

para.heading: Defenses.
para.text: It is a defense to liability under this section that the object specified in subsection (a)(1) of this section is, in fact:

Testing equipment or other objects used, planned for use, or designed for use in identifying or analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of a controlled substance or for ingestion or inhalation of a controlled substance; provided, that the actor is a community-based organization, an employee of the District government acting within the scope of their official duties, or a contractor or grantee of the District government engaged to combat opioid overdoses;
An unused hypodermic syringe or needle;

An item planned for use in a medical procedure or treatment permitted under District or federal civil law, to be performed by a licensed health professional or by a person acting at the direction of a licensed health professional; or
An object that is 50 years of age or older.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Trafficking of drug paraphernalia is a Class D misdemeanor.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: For the purposes of this section, the term "community-based organization" shall have the same meaning as provided in section 4(a)(1) of An Act To relieve physicians of liability for negligent treatment at the scene of an accident in the District of Columbia, approved November 8, 1965 (79 Stat. 1302; D.C. Official Code § 7-404(a)(1)).

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: The general provisions of Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.

para.heading: Offense.
para.text: An actor commits the offense of maintaining methamphetamine production when the actor knowingly maintains or opens any location with intent that the location will be used to manufacture, other than by mere packaging, repackaging, labeling, or relabeling, methamphetamine, its salts, isomers, or salts of its isomers.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Maintaining methamphetamine production is a Class A misdemeanor.

para.heading: Interpretation of statute.
para.text: The general provisions of Chapter 1 of Title 22A of the District of Columbia Official Code shall apply to this offense.
